The ER doctors, patient, diagnosed patient with a hemiplegic migraine.  patient had never experienced any of these symptoms previously. patient is scheduled to follow up with a neurologist on 12/15/2021.

All_symptoms: Chest pain
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Stabbing pain, upper left side of chest; This is a spontaneous report from a contactable consumer, the patient. A 15-year-old male patient received the first dose of BNT162b2 (PFIZER-BIONTECH COVID-19 mRNA VACCINE; Lot Number: FF2588) via an unspecified route of administration in the left arm on an unknown date in Sep2021 at 12:00 (at the age of 15-years-old) as a single dose for COVID-19 immunisation. The medical history included asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and COVID-19 infection. The patient had no known allergies. Prior to vaccination, the patient was diagnosed with COVID-19. The patient did not receive any other vaccines within four weeks prior to the vaccination. The concomitant medications included fluticasone furoate/ umeclidinium bromide/vilanterol trifenatate (TRELEGY), dexamfetamine sulfate/amfetamine sulfate/ dexamfetamine saccharate/amfetamine aspartate monohydrate (MYDAYIS), salbutamol sulfate (PROAIR), paracetamol (TYLENOL) and guanfacine (MANUFACTURER UNKNOWN); all for unknown indications from unknown dates and unknown if ongoing. On an unknown date in Sep2021 at 17:00, the patient experienced stabbing pain in the upper left side of chest for two weeks before improving gradually over next two weeks. The adverse event resulted in doctor or other healthcare professional office/clinic visit and emergency room/department or urgent care. Therapeutic measures were not taken as a result of the reported event. Since the vaccination, the patient had not been tested for COVID-19. The clinical outcome of the event 'stabbing pain, upper left side of chest' was resolved on an unknown date in 2021.
HISTORY: Medical History/Concurrent Conditions: ADHD; Asthma; COPD; COVID-19 (Prior to vaccination, was the patient diagnosed with COVID-19?:Yes)

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient had no initial side effects until Day 6 after getting the vaccine. He had a seizure for the first time at around 7:10am when he was getting ready for school. He had just begun to brush his teeth when he collapsed and had a seizure. He has no medical reason to have seizures and had never had one until 6 days after getting the vaccine. Patient had to be taken the the ER to be monitored because it was his 1st seizure and then had to follow up the next day with his regular pediatrician. He will have to see Neurology, but won't see that department until January 2022. No medications were given for him to take and his was cleared to resume all normal activities again.
LAB_DATA: At this time no medical tests have been done but we are waiting for Patient to be seen by Neurology to see if they can determine why he had a seizure.

All_symptoms: Erythema Pruritus Rash
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Itchy; Severe rash all over his body; Red especially in his arms, elbows, face, neck, ears, legs; This is a spontaneous report received from a contactable consumer (patient's mother) from the Medical Information Team. A 6-year-old male patient received BNT162B2 (PFIZER-BIONTECH COVID-19 VACCINE), administered in the left arm, administration date 10Nov2021 14:00 (lot number: FK5127) at the age of 6 years as dose 1, single for COVID-19 immunization. Relevant medical history included: ""Allergy"" (unspecified if ongoing). Concomitant medications included an unspecified flu nasal spray from 27Oct2021. The following information was reported: On 11Nov2021 08:00, the patient experienced severe rash all over his body and the patient was really itchy. The mother also noticed that the patient was red especially in his arms and elbows, then on a Monday (unspecified date in Nov2021), it started on his face and neck, and on a Tuesday (unspecified date in Nov2021), it was in his ears and legs too. The patient's mother started him on Zyrtec on Sunday night (unspecified date in Nov2021) and the doctor changed it to Allegra liquid 5mg once a day, so the patient does not get drowsy or sleepy to go to school during the day. Hydrocortisone 2.5% was used as needed for when the patient was very itchy on his elbow. The events were occurring more and more on the patient's body even with the medications. The mother was concerned for the patient, and his next shot was scheduled on 01Dec2021. The events resulted in emergency room visit and physician office visit. The outcome of the events was not recovered.  The lot number for BNT162B2, was not provided and will be requested during follow-up.

All_symptoms: Dizziness Feeling hot Oropharyngeal pain Pruritus
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Right arm and leg pruritus; he was feeling hot; throat pain; dizziness; This is a spontaneous report received from a contactable reporter(s) (Other HCP). A 9- year-old male patient received Bnt162b2 (BNT162B2), intramuscular, administered in arm right, administration date 17Nov2021 14:29 (Lot number: FK5127) at the age of 9 years as dose 1, single for COVID-19 immunisation. Relevant medical history included: ""known allergies: peanuts"" (unspecified if ongoing). The patient's concomitant medications were not reported. The following information was reported: pruritus (medically significant) with onset 17Nov2021 14:45, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""Right arm and leg pruritus""; feeling hot (medically significant) with onset 17Nov2021 14:45, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""he was feeling hot""; oropharyngeal pain (medically significant) with onset 17Nov2021 14:45, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""throat pain""; dizziness (medically significant) with onset 17Nov2021 14:45, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""dizziness"". The events ""right arm and leg pruritus"", ""he was feeling hot"", ""throat pain"" and ""dizziness"" were evaluated at the emergency room visit. Therapeutic measures were taken as a result of pruritus, feeling hot, oropharyngeal pain, dizziness. Events details was reported as follow: The patient was vaccinated Pfizer-BionTech COVID-19 Vaccine at 14:29 17Nov2021. Around 14:40 the observation nurse noted that the patient was fanning himself. The patient complained that he was feeling hot, Right arm and leg pruritus, new ""throat pain"" and dizziness. The observation nurse and POD lead then called 9-1-1 at 14:45 and initiated the anaphylaxis protocol. An epipen JR was administered (Lot #LFN341) IM to right thigh at 14:51 and at 14:57 0.4ml of Diphenhydramine (lot # 080008) was administered IM to R Deltoid by Nurse withheld. EMS arrived at 14:58 and hand off occurred to the EMS crew at 14:59. Transport to the ER occured at 15:05.  No follow-up attempts are possible. No further information is expected.; Sender's Comments: As per available information, the causal association between the reported events and the suspect drug BNT162B2 cannot be excluded. The impact of this report on the benefit/risk profile of the Pfizer product is evaluated as part of Pfizer procedures for safety evaluation, including the review and analysis of aggregate data for adverse events. Any safety concern identified as part of this review, as well as any appropriate action in response, will be promptly notified to regulatory authorities, Ethics Committees, and Investigators, as appropriate.

All_symptoms: Asthenia Fatigue Hypoaesthesia Incorrect dose administered Paraesthesia
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient came on 12/2/21 for second COVID19 vaccine. He was accidentally given adult dose from 12/1/21 (unrefrigerated overnight). Discussed with mom right after it was administered. Reviewed potential risk for additional or more severe side effects (most likely arm pain, fatigue, headaches). Can give Motrin or Tylenol. Will have him return in 3 weeks to get second dose of 5-11 year old Pfizer. Mom agreeable to plan. Mother of Child called on 12/3/21 with concerns of patient starting to feel numbness on both of his legs and feet, fatigue, fever, and just ""looking out of it."" She states that yesterday he just had a fever and felt weak which she knows would be a side effect of the COVID vaccine. Per physician schedule for apt today. Mother of child called shortly after and stated she would be taking the child to the ED.

All_symptoms: Dizziness Gait disturbance Headache Unresponsive to stimuli
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient came in for her 2nd Pfizer-COVID vaccine. Patient stated having dizziness after her first vaccine, so we had her stay longer than 15mins for observation. Vaccine given at 9:18am. At 9:33am I checked on patient, she reported dizziness. She was given a sack while waiting. At 9:48, checked on patient for a second time and she reported still having dizziness and now headaches. APRN notified and came to check on patient. She was then given water and tried talking with her. She began walking to the room so we can closely monitor her, while walking she began swaying as she walked. Once in the room the APRN had her lay down, from there the patient became unresponsive to verbal and physical prompting. I was in the room with APRN ready with an Epipen to administer to patient. Epi was administered at 9:54am. Placed SpO2 on patient index finger to monitor pulse and oxygen, also checked her blood pressure. Monitored vitals till First Responders and EMS came. EMS to transport to nearest ER for observation.
LAB_DATA: none reported.

All_symptoms: Dermatitis Erythema Periorbital swelling Pruritus Rash erythematous
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient received dose #1 of pediatric Pfizer on 11/9/21 in left deltoid LOT: FK5127 EXP: 01/17/22 Well tolerated per Mother.  Patient received dose #2 of pediatric Pfizer on 11/30/21 in right deltoid LOT: FK5127 EXP: 01/17/22  Patient tolerated well and sat the required 15 minutes following immunization. Mom contacted office on 12/2 stating that beginning the evening of 12/1 patient complained of itchy skin. On 12/2 Mom noticed a scattered red rash on trunk, collar bone, and back. She also looked ?red and puffy? under her eyes. As mother called just prior to clinic closing, APRN advised Mom take patient to ensure this was a simple dermatitis rather than other disease process. APRN called Mother the morning of 12/3 and Mom confirmed that  examined the patient and confirmed suspected dermatitis related to vaccine. Patient was treated with Benadryl and per Mom is doing better today. Of note, patient did experience significant post-injection swelling of the arm following a flu vaccine ?in a trial? years ago. Per Mom she has never had reaction to any other vaccinations or medication and does have sensitive skin.
LAB_DATA: NONE

All_symptoms: Ataxia Blood electrolytes normal Blood glucose normal Condition aggravated Dyskinesia
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Briefly this is a 5 yo F with hx of neonatal stroke with L sided weakness and epilepsy presenting with breakthrough seizure. Pt had COVID-19 vaccine 2 days ago. Visiting. No fevers, URI sx. Typical seizure starts with vomiting, hand jerking/shaking, and L eye deviation. Last breakthrough seizure in Feb 2021. Sibling with runny nose. 5 yo F with epilepsy and breakthrough seizure. No symptoms of illness. Unclear if COVID vaccination was trigger for breakthrough seizure. Upon arrival, pt was post-ictal with intermittent L eye deviation and now with hand jerking which was concerning for ongoing seizure activity. Pt was given intranasal midazolam with improvement, but seizure activity returned prompting IV ativan and IV keppra load. Seizure activity stopped and pt became responsive to voice but post-ictal. 2nd IV access obtained. Labs sent with normal glucose, reassuring CBC and electrolytes. Depakote level is in therapeutic range. Pt given home dose of depakote IV (missed AM dose). Neuro at the bedside throughout resuscitation.    COVID neg.     Care transitioned to the inpatient  Neurology attending. Pt was stable at the time of admission. MRI Brain 11/12/21: IMPRESSION: Images were significantly degraded by motion artifact. 1.No evidence of acute intracranial abnormality within limitation of motion artifact. 2.Posterior frontal porencephalic cyst with associated paucity of posterior frontal and right parietal periventricular white matter. On the morning of discharge, smile was symmetric, but she was noted to be ataxic, although much less than the day prior, so we drew a peak VPA level which was 150 (peak), with otherwise normal LFTs, normal platelets and no other signs of VPA toxicity. Thus, it was felt that the ataxia is likely secondary to medication effects in the last 24-48hrs with relatively high depakote level, Midaz 0.5mg/kg total, IV Ativan, and addition of Levetiracetam. Higher level of depakote was attributed to increased bioavailability of IV medication.  We observed her through the afternoon and felt that she was stable for discharge with close Neurology follow-up with Dr. calling on Tuesday 11/16/21. We will request Neurology follow up in clinic prior to  at the end of the month.  Family is considering whether they will get her the 2nd dose of COVID vaccine.  Risks and benefits discussed.  Discussed not flying back within 2 days of dose as much harder to manage if she were to have a prolonged seizure in flight.
LAB_DATA: MRI

All_symptoms: Acoustic stimulation tests abnormal Ataxia Audiogram abnormal Balance disorder Central nervous system lesion
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Pediatrician:Had covid vaccine Friday 11/5/2021, fine sat/Sunday.  Yesterday after school reported ringing of right ear.  Reporting diminished hearing on right ear.  Today reporting vertigo, dizziness. Reporting feeling like she just got off a merry-go-round.  This morning vomited after breakfast - around 9 am this morning.  Currently doing well at home.  Playing video games.  Still reporting not being able to walk straight.  Asked mother to have patient stand with arms outstretched and close eyes, mother reports she is wobbling when she does this. ER Doctor:12:58 PM. One episode of vomiting.  Zofran ordered. Trial of meclizine ordered.1:28 PM. Discussed with Dr.  (pediatric nephrologist on call) who is concerned about ataxia caused by a cerebellar lesion / infarct. Recommended MRI without / with contrast. 8:12 PM. MRI without abnormal findings. Patient reports feeling much better.Discussed with Dr.  (HNS surgeon on call) who reports that Meniere's virtually never is in children but definitely a vestibular pathology. Recommends referral to their service and course of steroids.  Also review with neurology to see if they want to follow up with her as possible vestibular migraines. ASSESSMENT;1.RIGHT LABYRINTHITIS; 2.RIGHT HEARING LOSS  3.RIGHT SUBJECTIVE TINNITUS; Audiologist; Progress Notes. at 12/1/2021  9:44 AM Status: Signed.  9 year old female seen today for hearing evaluation. Patient accompanied by her mother. Chief Complaint; Patient presents with HEARING LOSS. Reason: vestibular dysfunction, right tinnitus, right hearing loss; Mother reports patient with sudden-onset right hearing loss with tinnitus and vertigo since getting 1st dose of COVID vaccine on 11/05/21. Mother reports patient had no medical issues prior to this. Procedure: Comprehensive Audiometry and Tympanometry; Results:Otoscopic inspection revealed clear external auditory canals bilaterally.Tympanometry: Bilateral normal type A response.Ipsilateral acoustic reflex present at 1 kHz in both ears. DPOAEs (1-8 kHz) with reduced responses in right ear consistent with audio. Inserts; Headphones; Circumaural Headphones; ?Recorded MLV ?SRTs were 5 dB HL in bilateral ear(s), consistent with audiogram.Speech discrimination performance was excellent in right ear(s) at 100 % at an intensity of 45 dB HL.Speech discrimination performance was excellent in left ear at 100 % at an intensity of 40 dB HL.Impression:Right ear-Mild to moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Left ear-Normal hearing. Plan: HNS appointment follows today. Recheck post-HNS. Discussed good communication techniques. Preferential classroom seating at school. See audiogram/OAE report in imaging tab. The evaluation results were discussed with the parent, and all questions were answered to the best of my knowledge and scope of practice.  An After Visit Summary was printed and given to the parent. A copy of the audiological results was also provided. Electronically signed by: Audiologist; Department of Head and Neck Surgery/Audiology; 12/1/2021; 9:44 AM; Neurologist; STUDIES REVIEWED Audiogram 12/1/2021; Right ear-Mild to moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Left ear-Normal hearing. DPOAEs (1-8 kHz) with reduced responses in right ear consistent with audio. untitled image;ASSESSMENT:1. RIGHT SUDDEN HEARING LOSS; 2.RIGHT SUBJECTIVE TINNITUS ; PLAN/ORDERS: Right sudden SNHL. Recommend high dose prednisone x 2 weeks with taper. Risks, benefits and alternative were reviewed with the patient, including cataracts, worsening glycemic control, infection, blood clots and avascular necrosis. Patient's mother elects to proceed with steroid course. RTC 1 month with repeat audiogram. Orders Placed This Encounter; prednisone (PREDNISONE INTENSOL) 5 mg/mL Oral Conc.
LAB_DATA: MRI Brain and Brainstem 11/09/2021; Normal;Hearing Test 12/01/2021;  Right ear-Mild to moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Left ear-Normal hearing.

There has been no fever, no URI symptoms, no cough, no shortness of breath or trouble breathing, no throat tightness or chest pain.  Denies tongue swelling.    Past MedHx: ADHD, asthma, o/w reviewed and not relevant to current encounter  SurgHx: reviewed and not relevant to current encounter  SocialHx: Lives with family  FamHx: reviewed and not relevant to current encounter  Meds: Concerta, melatonin  Immunizations: Up to date Medical Decision Making       Patient with hives as above, may be related to COVID vaccine. All_symptoms: Facial pain Neurological examination normal Tooth disorder
SYMPTOM_TEXT: In summary, this is a 7-year-old previous healthy fully vaccinated male who comes into the emergency department with improving right-sided facial pain after getting his second COVID-19 vaccine this morning. He does have what appears to be an erupting mandibular right molar. However, otherwise, I cannot fully explain his facial pain today. I discussed with pharmacy and together we have not heard of this is a side effect of the Pfizer vaccine though we will certainly write it up and send it and should this become a problem with this very new therapy. I do not think he needs emergent imaging now given that his pain is nearly completely resolved and his neurological exam is normal.  We talked about warning signs such as tingling weakness facial droop as signs to come back emergently for further work-up. They will also come back if his pain gets more severe. However, given such rapid decline in his pain I think that we can observe watchful waiting with return should symptoms worsen or change. Final Diagnosis: 1. Facial pain R51.9.

All_symptoms: Aldolase normal Arthralgia Asthenia Blood creatine phosphokinase normal C-reactive protein normal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient woke up on Thursday (Dec 2) complaining of widespread muscle/joint pain.  no headache, neck pain only when moving head, walking like 80 yo man. Significant limp was present, and he was almost unable to walk up/down stairs. Right leg is worse, hurts to bend knee. little to no energy and not wanting to move around. Unable to bend to pick things up off the floor.  Drinking significantly less than normal. Took him to urgent care - they tested for covid (negative) and said to follow up with doctor after a few weeks. We talked to the nurse at the pediatricians office that same day - they made an appointment for that afternoon. We saw the doctor he did a number of tests (I'll include those in the next line), did an assessment and said it was likely post-viral myositis. (negative for strep, both flu's, and negative urine sample) Sent us home to push liquids and rest.  Patient slept poorly, waking frequently (which is not normal for him.) When he woke up Friday morning (Dec 3) around 6:30 am he was unable to keep liquids down. He puked 3-4 times over a 2-3 hour period before being able to slowly rehydrate. His energy was really low, and he had a dusty looking rash over/around his left eye (with mild swelling).  Symptoms started diminishing Saturday morning (Dec 4), and had reduced to only mild limping by the time of our follow up that afternoon. Lab results were all normal.  Symptoms almost entirely gone today (Dec 6) at our 2nd follow up.
LAB_DATA: All lab results were negative/within normal ranges. All done on Dec 2nd.  Covid-19 CK COMPREHENSIVE METABOLIC PANEL C-REACTIVE PROTEIN SEDIMENTATION RATE ALDOLASE URINALYSIS  INFLUENZA A/B  STREP A

All_symptoms: Arteriovenous malformation Body temperature increased Brain stem haemorrhage Decreased appetite Epistaxis
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On Sunday, November 21, the patient woke up with mild headache, body aches, and vomiting every time she ate food or drink liquids.  She did have temperatures in the range of 99-100 that day.  On Monday, November 22nd, she had a nosebleed that parents report was uncontrollable and continued for about 30 minutes.  She has not had this previously.  She also developed neck pain on Nov 22 as well, primarily and neck flexion.  She had a temperature to 101 on Monday evening.  The following day, November 23rd, she continued to have an extremely poor appetite with mild headache, she vomited once in the morning after Tylenol and continued to complain of stiff neck.  She continued to have temperatures in the 99 range.  They did take her to urgent care who referred her to ED,  discharged after supportive care. The following day, Wednesday November 24th, she seemed to improve to about 75% of normal.  This continued until Nov 28. On Sunday, November 28th, she awoke with severe neck pain and stiffness as well as a 10/10 headache, the worst of her life.  She vomited x1 prior to eating but may have had a few sips of water at that point. She was subsequently identified as having an arterial venous malformation in the medulla with apparent focus of hemorrhage.
LAB_DATA: MRI Brain w/wo Contrast, November 29, 2021 12:39 CST IMPRESSION:  Arteriovenous malformation in the medulla with apparent focus of hemorrhage.

Since the vaccination, the patient hasn't been tested for COVID-19.  No follow-up attempts are needed. No further information is expected.

All_symptoms: Blood test Chest X-ray Electrocardiogram Eye swelling Inflammation
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On Thursday afternoon, patient experienced a swollen and inflamed right knee. On Friday morning, he developed a swollen bottom lip. By Friday afternoon, he had a swollen and inflamed left knee. We took him to urgent care and the ER and all other theories  for its cause came back negative. On Saturday, he had swollen and inflamed hands right around his thumb joints  and a swollen upper lip. On Sunday, he developed swelling around his eyes and a rash. All swelling lasted for about 12 hours before it hopped to another part of the body. The swelling was debilitating for that period of time (swollen knees made it impossible to walk, swollen hands made it impossible to grasp things). Patient is now doing better but he was perfectly healthy before taking the vaccine.

Patient also began complaining of vaginal pain and swelling. Her mother states she took a look and noticed an ulcer on her labia.. They were seen by her PCP who obtained an HSV swab and recommended topical benzocaine but there was no improvement of her symptoms. Patient was seen by an OB/GYN  today where the patient had a debridement and was prescribed cephalexin, triamcinolone, and lidocaine. Took patient to the pediatrician and allergist, where she received epi x1 and prescribed prednisone (3 day course) and zyrtec. Patient was feeling well  on 12/2-12/3, but on 12/4, patient started to complain more of joint pain, mostly complaining of pain in her neck, back, thighs, and feet, and became less mobile (refusing to get off the couch). All_symptoms: Cold sweat Cyanosis Nausea Vomiting
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient's mother alerted us that patient was feeling nauseous. Patient is an 8 year old male only medical history reported by mother of asthma and allergic reaction to amoxicillin (reported side effect of nausea/vomiting). Mother also reported symptoms of nausea with the first dose but no vomiting related to anxiety. Patient received his second dose of 0.2ml of Pfizer in the left arm, with no symptoms for the first 10min noted. Mother reported to the nursing staff that patient wanted to vomit, patient vomited 200cc of light brown emesis. Staff nurse assessed patient was A&Ox4, no loss of consciousness, no signs of SOB, rash, or hives. Patient was cyanotic and clammy, patient was lowered down to the ground with his legs elevated on a chair. First set of vital signs with no reading, second set after lowering him on the ground was B/P: 98/58, P:80, R:20, O2 sat: 98% RA. Second blood pressure reading was B/P: 78/40, P: 68, R:24, O2sat: 98% RA.  Reassessed airways, no SOB or tongue swelling. Patient was given a lollipop to keep him stimulated and alcohol pads were placed under his nose to have him breathe. No onset of SOB, swollen tongue, stayed with patient at all times. 911 was called and fire engine responded. EMS took vitals at 1419 with 108/72 79 HR, and 100% oxygenation. Patient was taken to Hospital by ambulance with permission of the mother.

All_symptoms: Fatigue Influenza A virus test negative Influenza B virus test Influenza virus test negative Lethargy
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient started acting lethargic the morning of 12/7/2021 and developed a low fever (100). The fever increased to 101, a dose of Tylenol was given, and about 10 minutes later he had a seizure lasting ~3.5 minutes at 3:45pm. An ambulance was called and he was taken to the hospital. Temp in ER was 102. They treated with Ibuprofen. Tests for Covid, flu A & B, and RSV were negative. Doctor ruled out ear infection and throat infection with examination. We were discharged after 3 hours when fever was 99.9. Treatment at home was alternating Ibuprofen and Tylenol every three hours. When weaning off of medication, fever returned to 101.3 at 8pm on 12/7/2021. Treating now with Ibuprofen every 6-8 hours. No other symptoms besides fever and fatigue.
LAB_DATA: Covid, Flu A & B, and RSV swabs were negative in the ER on 12/7/2021.
HISTORY: Global coordination disorder, childhood apraxia of speech

Mom picked him up and while driving home, he had a seizure (right hand posturing, body turned to left, emesis and turned blue, he gasped)…this lasted 4-5 minutes.  Emergency was called and in the ambulance, he had a second witnessed tonic clonic seizure with eyes deviated.  He was given 2.5 mg of Versed IM  He was taken to hospital.  Temp was noted to be 103.8 rectally.  Child quickly back to baseline and was discharged to home that afternoon.  He has remained well this week.  Neurology followup planned 12/14/21

All_symptoms: Full blood count Joint swelling Laboratory test Metabolic function test Pain in extremity
SYMPTOM_TEXT: With 1st vaccine on 11/09/2021, mom noted that about 4 days later patient developed a bruise type rash around her lower abdomen/buttock area with some petechiae as well as some swelling and pain of fingers.   Improved and resolved over a few days. With 2nd dose on 11/30/22021,, within 8 hours she began to develop bruising/purpura type rash on her buttocks and around her lower legs/ankles and developed swelling and pain of her legs, ankle, and feet.   Upon return from being out of town, she came in to my office on 12/06/2021 at which time the swelling was still evident, but improved and the purpuric rash and petechiae were evident but much improved.  A CBC, Comprehensive Metabolic Panel, and Sed Rate as well as a Urinalysis was normal. On 12/08, and today, 12/09, the swelling on her legs, ankles, and feet has returned and the purpura has also returned.   No fever.  She was seen at Emergency Room, and I spoke with the ER physician, and she felt, as I did, that it appeared to be a Henoch Schonlein Purpuric type reaction.
LAB_DATA: CBC, CMP, Sedimentation Rate, and urinalysis on 12/06/2021  appeared normal.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: child had a generalized seizure; lost consciousness; stopped breathing; This is a spontaneous report received from a contactable reporter (Other HCP).  A 6 year-old female patient (not pregnant) received bnt162b2 (PFIZER-BIONTECH COVID-19 VACCINE), administered in arm left, administration date 18Nov2021 16:00 (Lot number: FK5618) at the age of 6 years as dose 1 (tris), single for covid-19 immunisation. The patient had no relevant medical history. The patient took concomitant medications included children's multivitamin. The following information was reported: SEIZURE (hospitalization, medically significant, life threatening) with onset 25Nov2021 09:00, outcome ""recovering"", described as ""child had a generalized seizure""; LOSS OF CONSCIOUSNESS (hospitalization, medically significant, life threatening) with onset 25Nov2021 09:00, outcome ""recovering"", described as ""lost consciousness""; RESPIRATORY ARREST (hospitalization, medically significant, life threatening) with onset 25Nov2021 09:00, outcome ""recovering"", described as ""stopped breathing"". The patient was hospitalized for seizure, loss of consciousness, respiratory arrest (hospitalization duration: 2 day(s)). The events ""child had a generalized seizure"", ""lost consciousness"" and ""stopped breathing"" were evaluated at the physician office visit and emergency room visit. On 25Nov2021, around 9am the patient had a generalized seizure, lost consciousness and stopped breathing. The patient was transported via ambulance to hospital where she was seen in the emergency department and admitted to the hospital for a 2-day stay. The patient has no previous history of seizures or any other significant medical events. The patient received a multitude of tests at the hospital including blood work, urinalysis, CT scan and EEG on 25Nov2021. All test results have come back normal at this time and care providers cannot identify another causal factor for the seizure. Child will continue to be evaluated by pediatrician and pediatric neurologist for further testing and follow-up care. There is no covid prior vaccination. The patient tested Covid at hospital on 25Nov2021 post vaccination, Covid test result was negative. The is no other vaccine in four weeks. Therapeutic measures were taken as a result of seizure, loss of consciousness, respiratory arrest.; Sender's Comments: Based on the available information and a possible contributory role of suspect product BNT162B2 to the development of events seizure, loss of consciousness and respiratory arrest cannot be totally excluded. The impact of this report on the benefit/risk profile of the Pfizer product is evaluated as part of Pfizer procedures for safety evaluation, including the review and analysis of aggregate data for adverse events. Any safety concern identified as part of this review, as well as any appropriate action in response, will be promptly notified to RAs, Ethics Committees, and Investigators, as appropriate.

All_symptoms: Arthralgia Blood test Conversion disorder Gait inability Headache
SYMPTOM_TEXT: PT woke up with a headache and vertigo.  By 11:30 AM vertigo was so bad she couldn't walk (feet wouldn't move in the right directions).  Pediatrician tested and got negative results for COVID, flu, and strep and sent us on to ER.  PT developed knee pain in both knees and also hand tremors while at the pediatrician.  At the ER continued to have symptoms and also had slight blurriness in left eye peripheral at one point.  All bloodwork normal except for slightly low White blood cell and MPV.  MRI without contrast performed and determined to be normal.  PT continued to have symptoms and was admitted for overnight observation.  Neuro consult the next day concluded she'd had a migraine which lead to the vertigo, but also gave her a diagnosis of functional neurological disorder.  She had also developed a rash on her left arm 2 days after the second dose which went away after 2 days and wasn't present when the more serious symptoms started.  Over the course of this week PT has started experiencing panic attacks lasting up to 2 hours in length, with as many as 4 per day. She had no anxiety attacks or other issues prior to the shots.
LAB_DATA: 12/3 blood work and MRI completed.  12/4 Consult from Neurology department. 12/4 call with on call Dr. 12/5 visit with pediatrician Dr.  12/12 on call discussion with Dr.

Corticosteroids were used urgently. I arrived with stable hemodynamics but a sensation of pain, burning in the throat plus a sensation of closure or a foreign body in the throat, (which did not become complete) plus a sensation of having to make an effort to breathe well.

One minute later the child was observed with jerky movements of upper and lower extremities. Myself and another nurse assisted the child in the supine position and stayed monitoring her.911 was called along with the child's mother and teacher. After 3 minutes, the child regained consciousness and she was assessed for safety. Vital signs taken: BP: 92/60, Pulse: 94. Child was alert and oriented times three. Child mentioned she had not eaten that day. The paramedics arrived at 10:17 am and took over child's care. Mother arrived at 10:21 am and accompanied child to hospital via paramedics

All_symptoms: Abnormal behaviour Aggression Agitation Anger Blood test
SYMPTOM_TEXT: About 5:00pm, she became agitated.  She was screaming and saying she wanted to run away.  We kept her home.  Per doctor, administered additional doses  of peptide bpc-157, thc free cbd oil, took  an epsom salt bath, evening medications.  Felt better but had a hard time falling asleep.   Next day, seemed to be ok.  Administered morning medications and sent her off to school.  Arrived off bus a little down and not feeling well.  Over the course of the next few hours, she became agitated, raged, hit staff, screamed and yelled, tried to exit classroom.   She attends a therapeutic school with special education teachers.  They tried everything to get her to calm down, including restraint when she was hitting or trying to exit the building.  This went on for an hour and after 6 holds, the school called me.  Administrator informed me of situation and when i tried to talk to her on the phone, she screamed into it.  That was when everyone knew something was seriously wrong and they call 911.  She went to emergency room.  After a few hours she completely calmed down but due to the severity of the episode, the doctors wanted to keep her.  She was evaluated by a psychiatrist and was sent to inpatient hospital the next day due to bed unavailability.  She is now at streamwood behavioralhealth, arriving tuesday, 12/14/2021.  No medications were changed.  She attends therapy and they are watching her.  She is doing well and will be discharged monday, 12/20/2021.  Doctors and i agree that this seems to be a one time reaction.  However after inpatient, she will attend intensive outpatient therapy and i will work on securing the rest of her outpatient assistance.
LAB_DATA: Negative covid test, cmp all within range.  Blood work is similar tp what it usually is.  Hospital did not adminster any medication.

All_symptoms: Abdominal adhesions Abdominal cavity drainage Abdominal distension Abdominal pain Abscess drainage
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 12/7/21 - vomiting and nausea lasting 5 hours starting 8:30pm  12/8/21-12/9/21 constipation, loss of appetite , still nausea, excessive gas and bloat pain. bowel movements occur after honey water in night time. feels okay after.  12/10/21-12/12/2021 diarrhea starts once mild fever and nausea, 1 vomit leading to Er visit. 12/13/2021 - Findings:         Appendix: Perforated/infected: hole or blown-out tip and Abscess    Fluid amount: Diffuse (throughout the peritoneal cavity)    Fluid character: Thin serous/clear throughout, Fibrinopurulent/purulent localized to within right lower quadrant mesentery (contained abscess)    Other pertinent findings: distal small bowel obstruction due to fibrinous adhesions to proximal rectum/abscess cavity within distal small bowel mesentery.       Procedure in Detail: After informed consent was obtained the patient was transported to the OR. A timeout was performed and perioperative antibiotics were given. The patient was prepped and draped in the normal sterile fashion.   A 12mm port was inserted in the umbilical position under direct visualization and the abdomen was insufflated. A 5mm 30 degree laparoscope was introduced. Two additional ports were inserted, one in the suprapubic position and one in the left lower quadrant, under direct laparoscopic visualization without incident. There were numerous dilated small bowel loops with distally decompressed bowel loops as well as serous fluid throughout the peritoneal cavity, likely a reaction to the distal small bowel obstruction. The appendix was tucked under the distal ileal mesentery, where it had perforated, and upon mobilizing the distal ile um and its mesentery an abscess cavity was released, draining purulent fluid which was suctioned out. The appendix had a blown-out hole in its mid-body. The appendix was exposed and retracted anteriorly and inferiorly, splaying open the appendiceal mesentery. A window was made in the appendiceal mesentery with the Maryland ligasure cautery and then the appendiceal mesentery was then taken with the ligasure cautery. The base of the appendix was transected with an endoGIA stapler. The appendix was removed via the umbilical port site using a specimen retrieval bag and then the peritoneal cavity was suctioned out. The small bowel was run proximally starting at the terminal ileum, and some loose fibrinous adhesions from the small intestine to the proximal rectum/distal sigmoid were released bluntly. The transition point of the obstruction was positively identified and easily released. We ran the bowel proximally for several more feet, and there were no other points of obstruction. The bowel was still fairly dilated but was all viable.   Once this was completed the surgical bed was inspected and the staple line was noted to be intact and the hemostasis was adequate. A rectus sheath block was performed using 0.2% plain ropivacaine under laparoscopic visualization. The ports were removed under direct visualization and the abdomen was desufflated. The incisions were closed in layers with absorbable sutures, cleaned and dried, and sterile dressings were applied.

She had 3 on her left arm, 1 on her right arm, 1 on her lower abdomen, and 1 on her lower back.  The entire week prior, she has complained she is cold (has the chills), has head and tummy pain, and incredibly itchy.  The doctors here in Westford say there is no correlation to the vaccine, but she had a reaction to the first dose as well.  I am worried I vaccinated too early from her being positive.  But i was advised otherwise.  I am also worried this will affect her long term, as she is not over this yet.

All_symptoms: Acute respiratory failure Alpha haemolytic streptococcal infection Angiogram cerebral abnormal Arterial catheterisation Arterial spasm
SYMPTOM_TEXT: In brief, patient is a previously healthy 15 year old who had acute headache and collapse at home, concern for posturing versus seizure, and ultimately found to have cerebral and intraventricular hemorrhage with mass effect secondary to ruptured aneurysm. S/p coiling of aneurysm, bilateral EVD placement and R decompressive craniectomy. She has acute respiratory failure, strep viridans bacteremia, and concurrent COVID-19 infection.  Presented 12/2/21 with aneurysm and incidentally found to be COVID positive.   NEURO: On arrival, she was somewhat responsive and by the time she arrived at ED she was posturing versus seizing. Head CT revealed hemorrhage 3x3x3 hemorrhagic focus anterior and inferior to the right basal ganglion with mass effect, also with intraventricular blood in lateral and third ventricles with acute subarachnoid hemorrhage in suprasellar cistern and bilateral sylvian fissures. At that time, reportedly pupils equal, 3-4, minimally reactive. At ED, received Mannitol bolus, and 4mg Ativan administered. Flight for Life activated and upon arrival to CW was admitted to the PICU with plan for emergent EVD placement. Neurosurgery placed EVD at bedside. Repeat head CT and CTA performed and demonstrated bilobed aneurysm arising from right ICA terminus with enlarging intraparenchymal hematoma along superior aspect mostly likely representing a ruptured aneurysm, increased intraventricular hemorrhage, similar subarachnoid hemorrhage, increased mass effect, effacement of basal cisterns, worsened midline shift. Optimized neuroprotection management with sedation, neuromuscular blockade, ventilator management, and hypertonic saline. R pupil became dilated and nonreactive and patient demonstrated persistently elevated ICPs >50. She underwent emergent IR coiling and R decompressive craniectomy with second right-sided EVD placement. Patient continued to demonstrate ICPs in 20s. Worked with Neurosurgery to optimize sedation. Repeat head CT demonstrated increased hypoattenuation in right frontal and parietal lobes, left parietal lobe, and splenium of corpus callosum. Loss of gray-white differentiation concerning for ischemic change. Increased right to left midline shift. TCDs demonstrated moderate spasm of the L MCA. EEG without seizure. Started Pentobarbital coma. On 12/9, an occurred episode while in transport to MRI and patient was noted to be obtunded. ICP 11 during episode, EVDs patent. She was not connected to LTM during episode, as she was in transport. She was started on epi drip and became more responsive, moving spontaneously and withdrawing to pain. On 12/10, her neurostorming medication regimen was optimized and no further changes were made.    Given poor neurologic prognosis, patient was given adequate sedation for pain management during terminal extubation on 12/18.  CV: Had periods of hypotension intraoperatively requiring initiation of Epinephrine and Norepinephrine infusions to maintain goal MAP > 80, SBP > 120. Returned to PICU with femoral CVL, arterial line, sedated with Fentanyl and Dexmedetomidine infusions, and on Vecuronium infusions, Nimodipine. On 12/4 echocardiogram report noted significant for left ventricular mid-inferoseptal hypokinesis and moderately diminished left ventricular systolic function, with an LVEF 41%. She required titration of pressors to maintain goal pressures. Added stress dose Hydrocortisone. Repeat echocardiogram demonstrated significant improvement in LV systolic function, consistent with the hypothesis that myocardium was neurologically stunned. 12/6-12/8 Patient weaned from sedation and pressors. On 12/9 she experienced a hypotensive episode while in transport to MRI.  HR dropped to 40s-50s. 105 mcg Epi dwindle given, then started on Epi drip, given 500 mL NS push pull. HR and BP normalized. On 12/10, patient was weaned from pressors and stress dose steroids. She remained hemodynamically appropriate leading to terminal extubation on 12/18.   RESP: Intubated in the OR. Notably, course complicated by significant pulmonary edema with poor compliance. On 12/10, her ventilator settings were weaned to CPAP/PS. She remained hemodynamically appropriate with CPAP/PS until terminal extubation on 12/18.   FEN/GI: On 12/10 patient was started on enteral feeds which were discontinued after terminal extubation on 12/18.   ID: At ED, she was incidentally found to be COVID positive. Blood cultures were drawn at that time positive for strep viridans. She started on empiric Cefepime and Vancomycin due to concern for septic shock given pressor requirements. Initiated thermoregulation. Patient continued to be intermittently febrile and remained on Ceftriaxone per family's wishes until 12/19.   RENAL: Initially had significantly increased urine output. Labs concerning for DI, although could also be secondary to 3% boluses. Initiated DI protocol. This later resolved and she continued to have urine output appropriate for age leading to her terminal extubation on 12/18.   OTHER: On 12/5 ,discussion took place between provider and mother and placed partial code status, including no bolus cardiac resuscitative medications, no defibrillation, no chest compressions. Care Conference took place on 12/10, during which mother voiced she would like to get MRI for further neuroprognostication before changing goals of care. Care conference on 12/14 to discuss MRI results with family. Neurology explained likely deficits patient will experience as a result of her brain injury including weakness of both sides of her body, inability to walk, inability to effectively eat PO, personality changes, cognitive dysfunction. Mother voices ""Patient would not want to live like this,"" but requests time to discuss these options with family before making any decisions. Another discussion between providers and family on 12/15 during which family voiced they would not want patient to be reintubated once extubated, would not want her to receive blood products, and would like to continue with enteral feeding. Tentative plans for extubation on 12/17 or 12/18 once family from out of state has come to say their goodbyes. Family later decided to move forward with terminal extubation on 12/18. She was extubated 12/18 to room air and passed away on 12/19/2021 @ 20:37 PM with mother, brother and step father at the bedside.
LAB_DATA: Head CT, MRI, Echocardiogram, multiple ultrasounds, angiogram

All_symptoms: Dyspnoea Electrocardiogram abnormal Pain Painful respiration Pericarditis
SYMPTOM_TEXT: After my daughter received her second shot on 10/10/2021 she woke up around midnight and stated that it hurt to breathe.  So we had her take a shower, take some Tylenol and take a nebulizer treatment to try help her lungs open up.  After doing this it didn't help but she was able to fall back to sleep on and off. I did take her to the ER the next day because her pediatrician stated to go there.  When we got the ER which after only 45 minutes then sent us home and said it was nothing to worry about.  She wasn't getting any better so on 10/12/2021 I brought her to the walk in clinic for hospital for a second option. They stated that they couldn't read what ever ER wrote for the EKG so they were going back and forth with the ER's trying to figure out what we should do.  After listening to her and trying to read the EKG they had thought that the wall of the heart was was swollen and said we could go home but they made an appointment for her to see a Cardiologist at Hospital.  When we saw MD, he also stated that he couldn't read ER's EKG so he would have to do another one.  After reading the EKG that he ran he did state that he did believe that the wall around he heart was swollen.  He stated that it is a rare case that it happens in girls because they have been seeing it more in boys.  He also said that it should heal on it's own but could take a few weeks to a month to heal.  After about 3 weeks it did seem to go away but about once a week to every other week she will get some pains and says it is hard to breathe again.   This will last a few minutes to a few hours and then goes away.
LAB_DATA: 2 EKG's done (in 2 different hospitals on different days)

All_symptoms: Dry skin Fall Hyperhidrosis Lethargy Loss of consciousness
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 9 year old male with fall and syncope episode approximately 5 minutes after receiving first COVID 19 Pfizer vaccine.   Responded to mother calling for help after patient fell down to floor. On arrival to other side of room, patient was noted awake but lethargic, responding to verbal stimuli with spontaneous respirations. Mother reported LOC for ""a few seconds"" and is uncertain if patient hit his head.  Once patient more alert, encouraged to drink juice and assisted on to gurney. Patient reporting inability to move lower extremities and noted diaphoretic/pale.  MD called by Lead RN. MD team arrived to vaccine clinic. Initial BP 79/43, HR 61, RR 34, Oxygen Saturation 100%. Patient appears pale. FSBS 118 obtained by MD Team. Repeat VS 65/38, HR 56, RR 34.   Care taken over by MD Dr. and RN.  Please see their documentation for interventions done by MD team (IV insertion, IV fluid administration)  MD orders for 911 to be called for transport to ED at 1431.  Patient left Vaccine clinic at 1450 transported by EMS team.  VS at time of departure 103/74, HR 75, RR 26, 100% oxygen saturation. Patient denies pain. Skin color improving, skin is dry and no longer diaphoretic, patient awake and alert. Able to transfer self from clinic gurney to EMS gurney.

All_symptoms: Incorrect dose administered Product preparation issue Product use issue
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Pt-went for second covid vaccination. Appointment time was 9:30am, but we had to wait for vaccine to thaw.  Vaccine was given at 10:05am into Right arm by pharmacy tech. I was notified sixteen minutes later by pharmacist, that wrong dose was given and instructed to watch for fevers and treat symptomatically. I was told that the vaccine was not diluted as recommended. I called back 35 minutes later to inquire regarding more details and spoke with pharmacist. At that time, I was told that the adult and pediatric vials were mixed together and my son was given a combination of both. When speaking with him, he said that he was unsure if the vials had dilutant in them or the amount of each vial that was combined.  He said that he would call me back after he figured out more numbers.  At approx 1300, he called back and instructed me to take my son to the ED if he develops any symptoms. He stated that he could not give me any more information. If I wanted further information, I needed to contact facility liability insurance company.   I spoke with pharmacy manager at approx 10am on 12/20/2021. At that time, he explained that he had not spoken with either staff member, but he did review report submitted by pharmacist. He stated that the adult and pediatric vials of pfizer covid vaccine were combined. He is unsure if full vials were combined or how much from each vial was added to the other vial.  He stated that the vaccines were not diluted as recommended. 0.2ml of concentrated combined Adult/Pediatric vaccine was drawn up and given to my 6 year old son.
LAB_DATA: n/a

All_symptoms: Dyspnoea Nausea Pallor Seizure Syncope
SYMPTOM_TEXT: A technician administered the flu and covid vaccines, then walked back to the pharmacy. About a minute later someone in the lobby reported an emergency, I (pharmacist) went to the lobby area to see the matter. Patient was on the floor and appeared to be waking up, his mother stated she thought he had convulsed then fainted. Patient stated he had difficulty breathing and was very pale, I administered 10mL of benadryl 12.5mg/5mL solution. Patient reported nausea and prepared to vomit, but he did not vomit. I stayed with patient to monitor him for changes while his mother called 911, patient stated he did not feel better or worse. EMS arrived shortly after and took over care. Patient's family refused transport to hospital via EMS but did say they would drive to the hospital afterward.  Of note, patient's mother stated he had not had a reaction to a vaccine like this in the past, including the flu vaccine.

Her pain was retrosternal without any radiation and she had no palpitation and no sweating.  Because the pain was persistent she was brought to the emergency room.  She had no associated shortness of breath..  Had no cough or wheezing.  She thought sometimes the pain was more when she was breathing in.  She had no lightheadedness dizziness or syncope. Hospitalized for potential myocarditis in the pediatric intensive care unit on December 24th

All_symptoms: Abdominal pain Alanine aminotransferase normal Aspartate aminotransferase increased Bilirubin conjugated Blood albumin decreased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient is a 9yo adopted male without significant past medical history. His two adoptive mother's are now separated and he spends time between both homes. Patient had suspected COVID 19 infection in November 2020 (not lab confirmed but symptomatic). He has not had clinically apparent COVID 19 infection in 2021 to mother's knowledge, but did have exposure to neighbor with symptoms consistent with COVID 19 (though their testing was reportedly negative) around the end of November 2021.   Patient was vaccinated with his first dose of Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine on 12/17/21. Starting 12/20/21 he began to experience lethargy, abdominal pain, some emesis, diarrhea, subjective fever (no temp taken), malaise, decreased oral intake. He was under care at one parent's home. He was seen by PCP who recommended supportive care measure for suspected viral illness. On 12/24 he returned to the care of his other parent's home. He was then taken to the hospital for evaluation and found to have work up consistent with MIS-C.

All_symptoms: Blood test Electrocardiogram Magnetic resonance imaging Seizure
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On 12/20/2021 at about 9:12PM, patient had her first-ever seizure. It lasted about 4 minutes. She had follow-up care at the ER at Health Hospital, where she had a clean MRI and no indicators of infection or fever were found in her bloodwork. Patient then had her second seizure at about 5:00AM on 12/26/2021. She was unable to communicate or move her arms. We went to the ER at The Hospital. They did an EKG, and the results were normal. They recommended that she stay in the hospital overnight to undergo an EEG, but we had to decline, as our health insurance would not cover it. We had to arrange to take an emergency flight back home so she can receive follow-up care through the specialty system ER.
LAB_DATA: On 12/20/2021, patient underwent an MRI and bloodwork, all of which showed no anomalies or indicators of fever or infection. On 12/26/2021, she underwent an EKG, which also showed normal results.

All_symptoms: Abdominal X-ray Abdominal discomfort Arthralgia Chest X-ray Chest pain
SYMPTOM_TEXT: First symptom was stomach discomfort and constipation then flare ups of pain began soon after followed by the following symptoms?   Throat hurt and had sores on back of tongue and red throat Tongue had little red spots  Said bottom front teeth have felt dirty  Hurt to swallow  Said her saliva tasted bad  Roof of mouth hurt complained of an itchy tongue  Skin got red and irritated easily  When she wore a mask, her cheeks got red and she looked flushed  Stomach pains and felt nauseous - stomach pains were sometimes in the lower tummy below her belly button.  Other times the pain was around the entire belly.   Bowel movements were loose and normal at times (no signs of constipation after the first week symptoms began) Had an appetite,  but wasn?t eating as much as normal  Flare-ups of pain in joints and random parts of her body (bottom of feet, head, chin, front and back bottom, chest, finger tips, toes, legs, arms, neck) Her pain in her feet was so uncomfortable at times, she wanted to wear tennis shoes in the house  Holding on to her tennis racket made her fingers hurt  A little redness in eyes that I noticed one day that came and went  Eyes hurt sometimes and felt dry or itchy  Based on chest x-Ray, she was misdiagnosed with bronchiolitis She was then diagnosed with possible walking pneumonia - the only symptom I observed was chest pain, but it was more like the flare ups of pain that occurred in different parts of her body (arthralgia) Hives all over legs and feet, especially after warm bath Hives also have appeared on elbows, abdomen, behind her ears, neck, arms, tummy  Discomfort on her private areas - redness/irritation around the vagina, small rash similar to red pimples on her buttocks, pain/discomfort when wiping after a bowel movement  It did not hurt when she urinated or had a bowel movement.  It was the outside skin that was sensitive and irritated She was bruising more easily - we thought it was her new bike riding skills but it seemed more than just her legs  Her temperature hovered around 99, which is above normal for her  She didn?t want to play as much because of all the discomfort  Her knees have turned red and itchy and felt warm to the touch   Medicines prescribed -  Miralax  Azithromycin  Prednisolone  Cefdinir  Hydroxyzine  Pepcid
LAB_DATA: November 25 - stomach X-ray showed moderate amount of stool in colon, strep test negative, COVID test negative  November 29 - lab work showed low white blood cell count  December 9 - chest x ray showed possible bronchiolitis, but it was a misdiagnosis  December 10 - lab work normal other than slightly low white blood cell count  December 14 - ct scan showed large adenoids but not sinus or ear infection as previously thought  December 15 - lab work normal  December 16 - EKG showed possible left ventricle hypertrophy  December 21 - echocardiogram was normal

All_symptoms: Abdominal lymphadenopathy Abdominal pain Alanine aminotransferase normal Amylase decreased Anion gap increased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 11/27/21 patient started to have multiple episodes of emesis with no real preceding symptoms of acute illness. She was COVID negative on 11/29/21. The emesis continued until 12/2/21, when she was determined to be constipated, noted to have mesenteric adenopathy and also an ileoileal intussusception. After receiving a bowel regimen at that ED visit and stooling well, the emesis resolved completely. She was stooling well on her own without any medication and healthy overall, just seemed fatigued to parents. She did lose 7-10 pounds during the time frame of the emesis but regained all that weight without any issue on her own by this past week. On 12/14/21, she received her second COVID vaccine. On 12/21/21, she started again with abdominal pain and then started vomiting again on 12/22/21, which family attributed to constipation again. Because they didn't get much stool output and pain continued, she came to ED, where she received a soap sud enema and got some stool out and was sent home. Because pain and emesis continued, they returned to ED within 24hrs and was admitted. Family notes that at home, she would vomit about 15 minutes after drinking sips and that she was vomiting green, no blood

All_symptoms: Limb discomfort Muscular weakness Throat tightness Tinnitus
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient brought into Covid Observation area after reporting ringing in Left ear, tightness to left side of throat and tired feeling in legs few minutes after receiving Pfizer Vaccination 2nd dose. Accompanied by dad who states patient did not experience any of these symptoms after first dose of Pfizer. Patient alert and oriented x 4. Able to speak in complete sentences. Denies any difficulty breathing, denies throat feeling swollen or itchy. No swelling noted to face, lips or tongue. Provided patient with water and juice, patient able to swallow fluids without difficulty. 4:50 pm- VS- Temp 98.1, BP 120/53, HR 76, RR 18, 02 SATs 100% RA.    4:58 pm- VS- BP 129/83, HR, 73, RR 18, 02 SATs 100% RA. Patient reports left side of throat still feels a ""little tight"".    5:04 pm- Call placed to on call ED physician, Dr., informed of patient symptoms above. Per Dr., if patient vital signs stable, no rash, vomiting or wheezing, then ok to continue to monitor for 10-15 minutes and discharge patient home. Patient to go to  ED  If symptoms worsen. Dad informed of above.   5:14 pm- VS: BP 117/76, HR 87. RR 18, 02 SATs 99% RA.    5:21: Patient states legs no longer feel tired, denies ringing in left ear, states throat still feels a ""little tight"". Denies any difficulty breathing, able to speak in complete sentences, swallowing saliva and fluids normally.    5:29 pm- VS- Temp 98.1, BP 115/63, HR 79, RR 18, 02 SATs 100% RA. Patient states left side of throat still feels a ""little tight"".   5:35- Call placed to on call physician, Dr., informed of patient symptoms not improving. Per Dr., dad to bring patient to Urgent Care or ED for physician evaluation.    5:42: Patient discharged from Covid Observation Area. Dad states he will take patient to ED for further evaluation.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient returned to pharmacy after her vaccine stating  that is was laboring to take a full breath in.  She was still getting enough oxygen to stand, walk and talk; however, she felt like it was difficult for her to fully fill her lungs.  Patient denied any mouth/throat swelling, nausea, dizziness, or itching.  Patient presented with out a rash or fever.  Patient sat by the pharmacy for over 20 minutes as we watched her.  Patient's condition was not getting any worse but was not getting any better.  The mother, who was with the patient, took the patient to a clinic setting so that she could get a full exam workup.

All_symptoms: Dyspnoea Malaise Pallor Sensation of foreign body
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patients came in with her parents to get her pfizer shot for covid-19.  The shot was administered by RPh into the left deltoid with a 5/8 inch needle for a dose of 0. 2 ml of NDC. The dose was given at 2:35 PM and within 5 minutes, pts mother got the pharmacist's attention to say that she was not feeling well. This occurred immediately after the father, got his moderna shot. The child indicated that there was something in her throat and that she had trouble breathing. Pt looked pale but her airway was unobstructed the entire time. She was given two doses of ammonia inhalant to keep her from fainting. I counseled the parents on the possible need for an epipen in the event that she starts have physical signs of hypoxia or an obstructed airway. No epipen was given since there was not airway obstruction or signs of hypoxia. The parents ask if we could give her some water but I advised against it due to choking risk. No hives we observed. Paramedics arrived at about 2:50 PM and did an assessment, which her Oxygen levels were above 98 and indicated that they were within normal limits and confirmed that no hives were present. The patient remained alert and orientated the entire time and was speaking normally. The mom did indicate that the child had a heart murmur after the child started to have symptoms post vaccination; however, this was not indicated on the PCQF. The parents called after patient was taken to the hospital to ask about how much vaccine was given (the dose) and asked us to email them the copy. I sent the copy to them as requested and also pointed out that the information was also on the white covid vaccination card that we gave them along with the sheet for Pfizer.
HISTORY: Heart Murmur- was not indicated on questionnaire- was disclosed after vaccination

All_symptoms: Blood test Fatigue Feeling abnormal Headache Influenza like illness
SYMPTOM_TEXT: My daughter received her first vaccine on June 10th. She felt ok after receiving it. After her second dose , two weeks later, she seemed ok. Her arm was sore, but that seemed to be about it. A few weeks later it went from muscle soreness to extreme fatigue and flu like symptoms. I took her to the doctor and they said it was a virus. A week later she was still feeling badly but the doctor, tested her for Covid and strep previously, still stated that it was a virus  but gave her some medicine because we were traveling by plane in a few days and her ears felt blocked. She did not get worse on the medicine, her ears seemed to clear and that was about it. She still felt tired and run down. The fatigue,  progressively got worse, the muscle aches, headaches and nausea increasingly kept getting worse. We saw the pediatrician on numerous occasions and reached out to her allergist. We had numerous blood panels and tests and nothing came up. She progressively got these symptoms and they worsened in severity up until September. She still has these symptoms but they aren?t getting worse. We have seen a rheumatologist, the primary care dr, her allergist.  She is now on xolair(er uticaria was under control with Allegra before this) and now we are set to see a cardiologist this month because her heart rate and blood flow seem to be off. All of his started after her second dose of the vaccine. We have all of the appts in our health portal and they all coincide with after she got the second dose of the vaccine

All_symptoms: Blood culture Brain natriuretic peptide C-reactive protein COVID-19 Coagulation factor
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Concern for MISC. 5 yo with 11 days of fever in association with conjunctivitis diarrhea and emesis; labs showing systemic inflammation and COVID Ab positive, PCR negative. He had one dose of COVID vaccine; our antibody test does not distinguish between antibodies from environmental infection and those from vaccination. The source of his prolonged fevers was unclear. Infection, malignancy, incomplete KD, MIS-C were possibilities. Given continued fever showing continued active inflammation we treated for MIS-C with IVIG and IV steroids. ECHO was reassuring to cardiac function but views of the coronary arteries were technically limited. He had good clinical response with cessation of fevers.

Diagnosed w/presumed viral gastroenteritis. Symptoms persisted and then he developed conjunctivitis on 1/1/21 as well. Due to worsening of his symptoms he returned to the ED on 1/2/21. SYMPTOM_TEXT: Pt with MIS-C, fevers starting around 12/17/21; diagnosed w/ MIS-C on 1/1/21 when presented with fevers, abdominal pain, rash, conjunctivitis and elevated inflammatory markers, including cardiac enzymes. Ended up intubated on 2 pressors (epi and milrinone I believe, transferred to teriary care center). COVID IgG positive to nucleocapsid, so likely had asymptomatic COVID at time of vaccination. But you guys say to report this so I am. Received IVIG, steroids as well. Improving today, 1/3/22, just extubated per report.

All_symptoms: Back pain Blood test normal Brain natriuretic peptide normal COVID-19 Chest X-ray normal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 12/12: seen in urgent care, rash(hives), wheezing -- > got albuterol and zyrtec, COVID test neg.  Felt better until 12/14 -- > didn't take inhaler and had increased SOB, then chest pain/numbness -- >ER and per pt reprot had normal workup, urine, blood tests, CXR, EKG, sent home.  12/16 -- urgent care-- >ED, tired, lay down and had sharp pain in R upper back then R sided chest pain lasting 1 min folllowed by numbness of L arm and chest tightness, with mild SOB.  It got better when he stood up and walked around, then came back 2 more times with sitting down.  Numbness spread to legs. -- >ED COVID+ and Troponin elevated (0.1) admitted for myocarditis concern. Echo was normal, EKGs varied, and Troponin slowly trended down (not nL prior to discharge) and he still has chest pain although less severe (1/3/22 per mother).  He did not receive remdesivir or monoclonal ab.   He did have recurrence of his non-pruritic urticaria during this stay.  This is most likely be due to COVID but given date of last vaccine I thought I'd submit.  Mom is aware.

All_symptoms: Bell's palsy Dysarthria Ear pain Ear swelling Swelling face
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On 12/2/21, patient received the 1st dose of Pfizer COVID vaccine. On 12/5/21, patient started complaining of left ear pain and swelling. On 12/6/21, patient complained more left ear pain and swelling. On 12/7/21, patient looked normal before going to school. During school, patient started to experience left facial swelling. When returned to school around 3:40 PM, patient's mother noted slurred speech, patient's inability to smile on the left side as well as inability to move his left eyebrow. Patient brought the patient to Hospital's emergency department on 12/7/21 and was diagnosed with left Bell's palsy. Patient followed up with Family Practice office on 12/10/21 where patient continued to have motor deficits on the left face. Patient followed up 393  Family Practice office on 12/20/21, which showed moderate improvement but continued to have motor deficits on the left face. Patient will continue to follow up to monitor the recovery.
LAB_DATA: None

All_symptoms: Generalised tonic-clonic seizure Loss of consciousness Screaming Tremor Urinary incontinence
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Vaccinated: 11:18 Reaction: 11:20 2 minutes after vaccination, patient had a tonic-clonic seizure lasting 30-45 seconds. Patient's head was turned to side and supportive care was given. 911 was called and patient left by EMS at 11:50. Per patient's mother at ED, patient was in the backseat after having gotten her COVID-19 vaccination when she immediately started to scream for her mom and left hand began shaking. Then, the patient lost consciousness and mother called for help. She notes that the patient urinated on herself and was back to being alert 30 seconds to a minute later. Patient reported to be very anxious about getting the vaccine. Patient noted to hvae rhinorrhea and sneezing prior to getting COVID-19 vaccine. Vitals: @9:44: 150/110, 10 -> @1142: 125/84, 101, O2 93% -> @13:36: 116/66, 87, 18, O2 99% Patient reports she is back to baseline in ED taking PO and ambulating normally. Patient also appeared nontoxic in appearance with normal vital signs and normal neurologic exam.  and provider recommended patient be discharged with Keppra. During follow-up call, mother expressed concern over using Keppra on daily basis and was reassured that because it was a singular event triggered by getting a vaccine, routine use of Keppra will not be necessary at this time. Mother also plans on getting next COVID vaccine in controlled environment with proper observation and provider advised that if she has any involvement of left side that is concerning for seizure, patient will need daily anticonvulsant.
HISTORY: PMH of meningitis, syncopal episodes over the last few years, hx of needle phobia

All_symptoms: Anaphylactic reaction Dyspnoea Feeling abnormal General physical health deterioration Immediate post-injection reaction
SYMPTOM_TEXT: My son vaccination was at the Pharmacy issued by pharmacist.  Immediately after received the injection he mentioned to me that he was feeling weird.  We walked around the store to fulfill the observation period.  His complaints started increasing.  We walked back to the pharmacy area about 10 minutes later and he continued to the complain and we let the pharmacist know.  She started asking questions.  His throat was tightening, he was complained about his breathing, he seemed as though he was about to vomit,  he was lethargic,  he was certainly declining.  The pharmacists called 911 and she have him an EpiPen.  Shortly thereafter the paramedics arrived.  We were then taken to the ER.   He experienced an anaphylactic reaction.
HISTORY: Patient tested positive for Covid on 10/13/2021.  He is experiencing long haul affects of Covid.  He is scheduled to be seen by the Hospital Post-Covid Program on 3/9/2022

All_symptoms: Asthenia Bacterial test Blood culture negative Blood lactic acid COVID-19
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Pt received the COVID-19 vaccine on 12/28/2021. The next day, she developed fever, vomiting, and poor appetite. After 3 days of these symptoms, she also developed headache and weakness. She was brought to a local Hospital where a spinal tap showed evidence of aseptic meningitis, and was started on IV Vancomycin, Ceftriaxone, and Acyclovir. She was also found to have COVID-19 infection. 1 day later, she developed an episode of stiffening and eye blinking concerning for seizure for which she received Keppra and Phenytoin, prior to transfer to another Hospital for video EEG (later negative). Over the following 3 days, her mental status and hydration status improved, and she returned back to baseline.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: On 1/5/2022, Patient woke up with a flush face, with a fever, swollen lips and red patched on her face. I immediately called her pediatrician and explained all of the symptoms. She advised me to give her an antihistamines/ Tylenol. The Tylenol helped a little with her fever, which would be up and down. On 1/6/202, Patient still had swollen lips and now her eyelids were swollen as well. I then gave her about 4 dose of Benadryl, which did not help with the swollen of her lips and eyelids. On 1/8/2022, I took Patient to the ER, upon arrival she had 102 fever and her lips were swollen and the swollen in her eyelids had went down a little but they were red from the allergic reaction. She's saw a doctor, and was given, dexamethasone (Decadron), Ketorolac Tromethamine (Toradol), and lactide ringer IV Bolus. They did a chest x-ray which showed no acute pleural pulmonary diseases and bloodwork was normal as well and Covid-19 test, came back negative.
LAB_DATA: On 1/8/2022, Patient saw a doctor and was given dexamethasone (Decadron), Ketorolac Tromethamine (Toradol), and lactide ringer IV Bolus. They did a chest x-ray which showed no acute pleural pulmonary diseases (chest and lungs looked normal) and bloodwork was normal as well and Covid-19 test, came back negative.

All_symptoms: Blood glucose normal Confusional state Discomfort Dysarthria Eye movement disorder
SYMPTOM_TEXT: I was called to attend an emergency that happened during COVID Clinic.  The medical assistant reported 10year old boy was there for his routine first COVID vaccine.  5 minutes after the COVID shot, he was sweating and appeared to be in discomfort.  The Nurse practitioner was called who mentioned that pt was initially responding  to verbal command but later he had decreased responsiveness.  Help was called immediately. By the time I arrived, he was sitting on the chair and was looking to the side with up rolling of his eyes. No involuntary movements of his limbs. I immediately laid him down on the floor. He appeared very pale and was diaphoretic. Pt did not response to voice commands. Sternal rub was done couple of times for tactile stimulation, patient had minimal response/grimacing. I asked help to get his vitals Oxygen saturation, Blood pressure, Blood glucose and for Oxygen.   EMS was called.  His heart sounds were muffled on examination and the NP did not appreciate any pulse in the groin. Epipen was given by NP.  Within 60 seconds, his heart rate was pounding, he started responding to pain, his speech was slurred was confused.  Patient?s Oxygen saturation was maintained throughout at 98%, pulse 62 and blood pressure was 90/65. Blood sugar was 90mg/dl.  Upon reevaluation, pt. started responding to the questions in a slow manner, he still appeared sweaty and pale.   Paramedics arrived and we provided details about the patient. He was referred to a local Hospital for further evaluation.    After 4 hours, I Spoke with the attending at the Hospital who mentioned pt was doing well.  However, prior to discharge he got diaphoretic and was readmitted at Emergency Department for observation. IV fluids were given. CBC showed elevation of WBC. Normal CMP. Discharged home with diagnosis of syncope and advised to follow up with PCP.     Parents were asking whether patient can receive the second dose of Pfizer vaccine.  Based on the experience below, please suggest if its okay to give second Pfizer vaccine and please advice on precautions we need to take. I appreciate your input and help. Thank you.
LAB_DATA: CBC , CMP IN THE HOSPITAL.ELEVATED CBC, PLAN TO REPEAT IN FEW WEEKS

All_symptoms: Blood test normal Fatigue Henoch-Schonlein purpura Influenza virus test negative Parasite blood test
SYMPTOM_TEXT: My son received the second dose of Pfizer vaccine on 26NOV2021, and had no adverse reaction other than fatigue. On 06JAN2022 6 weeks following vaccination, he began to experience petechiae on both legs and feet, progressing in severity. On 09JAN2022 I took him to Urgent Care to be seen regarding the rapidly spreading petechiae and purpura now all over his legs and feet including the soles of the feet. Following bloodwork and COVID and FLU tests (both negative) he was seen the following day 10JAN2022 by his pediatrician who diagnosed Henoch-Schonlein Purpura.  He has had no illness that we know of that could have triggered the HSP, which is typically seen following viral illness but could come from any number of triggers. I share the information on VAERS not because I think the vaccine caused this condition but because I want to contribute information in case there is an increase of HSP cases surrounding vaccination and/or covid exposure. Thank you for your work to monitor vaccine safety and effectiveness!
LAB_DATA: Covid-19/Flu Combo 09JAN2022 -- Not detected / Not detected CMP 09JAN2022 - All results in range CBC 09JAN2022 - All results in range Blood Parasites 09JAN2022 - Negative Lyme Total AB IGG/IGM 09JAN2022 - Negative

She started to panic, that time I called the family doctor office and spoke with a physician on call. My husband already had her in the car heading to ER. She started to vomit and she was given ondansetron ODT, she was tested for COVID and the flu but was negative. She was still having issues with her throat after hours of vomiting(probably vomited 30 times while at the ER) she was given diphenhydramine.  She was released around 6:30am and we had to continue the Benadryl every 6 hours until Sunday.
