All_symptoms: Computerised tomogram head normal Dizziness Drug screen negative Fatigue Gait disturbance
SYMPTOM_TEXT: headaches, dizziness and L arm twitching s/p COVID administration on 1/3/21 @ 1900.  Patient reports that after receiving her first COVID vaccine yesterday she started complaining of being ""tired and achy."" She confirms that she subsequently developed a bitemporal pounding headache 5/10 pain that lasted an hour with associated blurry vision. No associated photophobia, phonophobia, nausea or vomiting. MOC also noted several episodes of patient's left arm ""twitching"" in the arm that was injected with some associated swelling. Each episode involved entire UE and resolved within a couple of minutes. Patient had another 30 minute long headache this morning, characterized as pounding bitemporal. She continued to have intermittent dizziness, did not develop any syncope, URI symptoms, diarrhea or vomiting. Patient was given a one time Advil dose that improved the headache. The dizziness has made it more difficult for her to ambulate, but she has not fallen and has not had any pre-syncope.
LAB_DATA: In the ED visual acuity was checked which was Rt 20/70 and Left 20/50. CT head without contrast without evidence of ICH, mass or midline shift. CMP was normal. x1 NaCl bolus was given. Patient had headache upon arrival to ED and was given Motrin which improved the headache.  COVID PCR negative, UDS negative
HISTORY: Vasovagal syncope Chronic tension headaches Recurrent Acute otitis media

All_symptoms: Chest pain Dyspnoea exertional Electrocardiogram Hypomenorrhoea Injection site pain
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Previously healthy 14-year-old male with a history of extrinsic asthma, GERD, and allergic rhinitis, brought to the emergency department by his father complaining of fever, malaise, myalgias, worsening chest pain, and exertional dyspnea.  He had his Covid booster on Friday, and on Saturday he began to feel some generalized malaise, soreness at the injection site, and mild chest pain.  Over the last 24 hours the chest pain has worsened and he has developed exertional dyspnea with subjective feelings of shortness of breath at rest.  No vomiting or diarrhea, but has worsening myalgias and malaise.
LAB_DATA: Twelve-lead EKG shows sinus tachycardia at 102 bpm normal axis, PR interval, QRS duration, and QTc 432 ms.  Leads I and aVL are suspicious for 1 mm ST elevation and possibly PR depression that is not seen in the other leads.  In lead III there is about a 0.5 mm J-point depression with inverted/biphasic T waves.  There are no abnormal findings in the precordial leads.   Repeat twelve-lead EKG at 1:26 PM, performed about 2 h after the initial EKG, shows persistent ST elevation in leads I and aVL with 0.5 mm ST depression in lead III only.  Compared to the prior ECG of 11:16 AM there is no significant interval change.   I discussed this patient with the Hospital transfer center who placed me in contact with pediatric cardiology attending Dr., who recommended that the child be transferred to the Hospital for serial troponins, a formal pediatric echo, and ongoing evaluation for what appears to be an evolving myocarditis.  It is unclear whether this might be immune mediated as a adverse reaction to the booster or whether this might represent a viral myocarditis or myocarditis of another etiology.
HISTORY: extrinsic asthma, GERD, and allergic rhinitis

All_symptoms: Antibody test positive Autoantibody positive Autoimmune haemolytic anaemia Blood lactate dehydrogenase increased Cold agglutinins positive
SYMPTOM_TEXT: This is a patient with transfusion dependent beta thalassemia major who had a known warm autoantibody that had intermittently caused hemolysis in the past. She was transfused as scheduled on the day of her vaccine. About 10 days after receiving her first dose of Pfizer vaccine, she was noted to be more fatigued and labs showed an acute drop in hemoglobin to 4.9 with elevated markers of hemolysis. She was also febrile at the time, though our in-house respiratory viral panel did not yield any viral pathogens (including Sars-CoV2). She was transfused and started on IV steroids, transitioned to oral steroids for presumed autoimmune hemolytic anemia. She continues to have low level hemolysis despite continuing on steroids, though the hemolytic rate has slowed and she is clinically doing well. We plan to taper steroids over the next few weeks and continue to monitor hemoglobin closely. We do plan to give her a second dose of pfizer vaccine.
LAB_DATA: Hemoglobin on 12/18 (prior to transfusion on 12/20) was 7.4. She was transfused 640 mL blood (CBC not checked to assess post-transfusion response). On 12/30, Hb was 5.5 and on recheck was 4.9. Additional labs on 12/30 were elevated plasma free hemoglobin of 70, haptoglobin <10, LDH 458. She was transfused 3 units of PRBC with an appropriate response, Hb 11., though plasma free hemoglobin and LDH remained elevated. She has had a persistently positive antibody screen and direct antiglobulin (coombs) test, even preceding her vaccination, likely related to a prior warm autoantibody. Blood bank testing showed a known Anti Jsa alloantibody and no new alloantibodies. She also had both cold and warm reactive red cell autoantibodies detected.
HISTORY: transfusion dependent beta thalassemia major Transfusion related iron overload

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Developed URI symptoms the week following the injection. Then on the 19th, parents noted a distinct targetoid lesion on the tongue with concentric bright red annular rings. this was non painful. These occurred in the setting of a URI.  Seen in Urgent Care on 12/24. Diagnosed with LLL pneumonia and started on azithromycin. Pictures taken and saved in patients chart for reference. Dermatology reviewed images and felt most consistent with geographic tongue. He continues to improve, but lesions on tongue still present. I have seen a lot of geographic tongue, but never one that has a targetoid appearance.  No other skin findings by report. He is overall healthy now. Planning to get second Pfizer injection tomorrow.
LAB_DATA: Chest xray 12/24/21 - possible perinhilar pneumonia.

All_symptoms: Anxiety Blood test normal Chest X-ray normal Chest pain Chest scan
SYMPTOM_TEXT: My 12 year old daughter had the first dose of Pfizer on 8/9/2021. Upon arriving home after the shot, she had severe vomiting and diarrhea. She was dazed and zoned out for 1-2 days after the vaccine.  She then received the second dose of Pfizer on 9/17/2021. Again, she arrived home not feeling well and had to lay down. She continued to feel unwell and rest laying down for approximately 2-3 days.  During this time, she was at times unresponsive  while resting and watching television.  Two weeks after getting the second dose of Pfizer, she developed severe anxiety and panic attacks. She had chest pain and was concerned that she was having a heart attack. My daughter had never had any noticeable anxiety or panic attacks prior to this time.  At this point, I took her to the doctor, who ordered a chest x-ray, EKG and blood work. All tests and labs looked normal. Another week or two went by and she continued to have episodes of anxiety and panic attacks.  In early November, she choked on a small piece of pasta, which sent her over the edge with anxiety. She started not wanting to eat much food, which sent us in and out of the doctor's office to monitor her weight. She gradually lost so much weight that she was admitted to the hospital in early December, and then another Hospital, where she spent one month recovering and being re-nourished by an nasogastric tube.  She is now in an intensive outpatient rehabilitation, as she learns how to eat solid foods again.
LAB_DATA: Chest scan, EKG, blood work.  Endoscopy.

All_symptoms: C-reactive protein increased Chest pain Electrocardiogram abnormal Myocarditis Tachycardia
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 15 yo M, previously healthy, with 2 d of chest pain s/p COVID mRNA vaccine booster (3rd dose) on 1/8, with tachycardia, normotension, elevated CRP, significantly elevated troponin, and abnormal EKG, all most consistent with myocarditis, timing suggestive of COVID vaccine-associated myocarditis -- however, given other etiologies of myocarditis should also be considered, e.g. viral. Overall pattern of presentation less suggestive of MIS-C or systemic autoimmune disease.

All_symptoms: Dysarthria Fatigue Feeling abnormal Feeling cold Hallucination
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On Sunday 01/09/2022 at  11am my son got the first dose vaccine of Pfizer on his left shoulder. On 01/10/2022 he felt fatigued, and went to school. He then told me he felt like that his head was moving. I bathed him and he got really cold and had high fever, highest 38 degrees. At 9pm I gave him Tylenol. At 5am, he started to hallucinate. He was telling his father ""that  why his dad wanted to kill him"". He was screaming that his dad was his friend. At that moment he started to vomit. At 09:30am, he vomited and gastric juices, yellow and liquid. I took him to the pediatric clinic 01/11/2022. Dr. is who saw him at the clinic. He was given pills for the vomiting and was sent home. At 1pm, he was given Tylenol for his hallucinations and he saw everything very big and that he could touch the ceiling. The next day, the vomit went away. His mood changes was that he was excited and talk super fast and then really slow and that his tongue got twisted. The participant states that his tongue was twisted, slurred speech. 01-13-2022,  I took him to Healthcare. My son has sensitivity to the light, photophobia. Before the vaccine he was fine. The Doctor revised him and gave him acetaminophen and continue observation. Up until yesterday, he felt he felt his head really big. I gave him Pedialyte, made him hot soup so he may feel better.  Today he has some lesions in his upper palate. I also spoke with Dr., healthcare. I paid his medical expenses because he does not have health insurance. I told the pediatrician doctor that I will not let my son get his second vaccine due to what he experienced and felt. They told me at the hospital that my sons symptoms are effects of the vaccine.  At this time, he is recuperating at this time and pray that there are no secondary lasting effects from his symptoms from the vaccine.  I am worried of hat effects my son will have in the future and if other exams can be done on my son. If anything changes in my son status, I will report again.
LAB_DATA: No exams were taken

SYMPTOM_TEXT: D135QW5 3:30pm 1/14/22  At approximately 3:30PM, the minor (14 year-old male) client received his first dose of the Pfizer 12+ vaccine, administered by our vaccinator in his Right Deltoid (IM). The client sat in the observation area with his mother and within three minutes complained of light-headedness. The mother reported that he ate within the hour. The Clinical Lead gave the client a bottle of water and checked his vital signs, which were normal. The client was alert and said ?I don?t feel good?. The Clinical Lead decided to assess the client?s ambulatory status by standing him up with support on both sides when she noticed his legs were weak and that he was lethargic. He was immediately transferred to a stretcher while the clinical lead activated EMS at 3:43PM. While on the stretcher, the patient complained of chest discomfort and numbness to the right extremity. The Clinical Lead continued to monitor the client?s vital signs until EMS arrived.   When EMS arrived, at approximately 4PM, they took the client?s vital signs and performed an EKG. They informed the client?s mother that he required further medical evaluation. EMS departed with the client and his mother at approximately 4:15PM to a local Medical Center.

All_symptoms: Blister rupture Discomfort Herpes zoster Pain Rash
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient complained of mild pain at first. Then over the course of a few days, he reported increasing pain and discomfort. Additionally, he presented as guarding the arm. The arm then subsequently was found to have a rash associated with it after a few days. The rash originally was localized to the shoulder area, however, over the course of an additional 48 hours spread down the entire arm to the wrist. The rash was red, raised in patched, and blistering. The overall appearance was that of a shingles rash. The patient reported severe pain, itching and general discomfort in the rash and pain in moving the arm.  The patient was first evaluated by a doctor on 1/9/21 at an urgent care. At this time the patient was given Triamcinolone Acetonide and advised to follow-up the next day with primary peds. The patient then was seen again on 1/10/21 by their primary pediatrician. The patient was then given Acyclovir oral.  The patient continues to have a unilateral rash on the arm, however, the blisters have broken and no new ones have developed.
LAB_DATA: none

All_symptoms: Feeling abnormal Pallor Tension
SYMPTOM_TEXT: I administered the vaccine to patient. She seemed calm.  I directed her and her mom to the waiting area to keep an eye on her.  A few minutes later her mom brought her back to me and said she (her daughter ) felt weird.  She presented completely tensed up and pale.  I immediately had one of the techs call EMS.  Myself and her mother were able to get her in a seated position until the paramedics arrived.  They took her in to make sure she was ok.  She was alert, drinking water and had a lollipop.   The mom decided to take her to the hospital to ensure her daughter was ok.

All_symptoms: Back pain Contraception Heavy menstrual bleeding Menstruation irregular
SYMPTOM_TEXT: My daughter was given the Pfizer vaccine on May 17, 2021 and started her period early on May 21, 2021. Her period came on super heavy on the 21st, bleeding through everything to the point where I went to the store to get her DEPENDS to wear at night because she was bleeding through everything. We ended up at the urgent care on Sunday May 23, 2021 and she saw her own primary care doctor who thought it might just be her body trying to regulate her cycles so she put her on birth control pills. She started  them immediately. She told us the pill would help lighten up her bleeding. It DID NOT!  She continued to bleed heavily all week. A week later we were back on a call with a different doctor on Sunday, May 30, 2021. She just told us the same thing that it's probably her body just regulating her cycle. The concern I have is that both doctor's use of the word ""PROBABLY"". It has not set well with myself or my husband. When all was said and done, the doctor upped her a regime of 3 birth control pills a day with a gradual move to 2 a day and then a hope to going back to 1 a day. THIS DID NOT WORK EITHER!!  My daughter bled a total of 50 DAYS  from May 21, 2021 - July 16, 2021, with a few days here and there when the bleeding stopped and then came back with a vengeance.
LAB_DATA: Thyroid test...Neg.   -   lot's of blood tests to check for bleeding disorder, no bleeding disorder found...Low Iron was detected

SYMPTOM_TEXT: The patient received the vaccine and I directed her and her mother to be seated for 15 minutes for observation. Shortly after that the mother approached me and asked if it was normal for a child to be dizzy and weak after the vaccine. She also said that her daughter passed out. I checked her BP and it was 74/53. Ten minutes later I checked it again and it was 84/56. Ten minutes after that it was 81/63. I recommended that we call 911 to be sure she was ok and the mother agreed. I called 911 and the fire department and then the ambulance came and took over.

All_symptoms: Activated partial thromboplastin time normal Acute kidney injury Alanine aminotransferase normal Anion gap Antinuclear antibody negative
SYMPTOM_TEXT: The patient received his vaccination on 1/13/2022 at 4pm.  During the early morning of 1/14/2022 he developed severe muscle pain especially in the bilateral costovertebral angles, fever, and severe headache.  Upon arising later that morning  he had dysuria and gross hematuria without clots along with the aforementioned symptoms.  Seen in the emergency department at Medical Center on January 14th.  Noted to have acute kidney injury with creatinine of 1.1 mg/dl, gross hematuria, normal C3 & C4, normal CBC including normal platelet count. Normal INR and APTT.  Urine grossly reddish brown in appearance with >100 RBC/HPF.  Urine protein/creatinine ratio is 0.882.   BP was134/72 mmHg.  Urine culture was sterile from that day.   Re-evaluated on 1/17/2022.  BP was within normal range for age at 110/78 mmHg.  Clinically free of edema.  Still with backpain that is remarkably tender and dysuria.  Compliant of severe headache.   His laboratory studies show a creatinine of 1.2 mg/dl.  Urinalysis with RBC and coarse granular casts.   Urine protein/creatinine ratio improved to 0.352

All_symptoms: Myocardial infarction
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Suddenly died from a heart attack; This spontaneous case was reported by a consumer and describes the occurrence of MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION (Suddenly died from a heart attack) in a 13-year-old male patient who received mRNA-1273 (Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine) for COVID-19 vaccination.     No Medical History information was reported.   On 06-Jun-2021, the patient received second dose of mRNA-1273 (Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine) (unknown route) dosage was changed to 1 dosage form. On an unknown date, the patient received first dose of mRNA-1273 (Moderna COVID-19 Vaccine) (unknown route) 1 dosage form. On 04-Jan-2022, the patient experienced MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION (Suddenly died from a heart attack) (seriousness criteria death and medically significant). The patient died on 04-Jan-2022. The reported cause of death was suddenly died from a heart attack. It is unknown if an autopsy was performed.            No concomitant medication details was provided. The patient was  died from unexplained experimental mRNA technology which was seen result in massive wave  of youth illness and death. No treatment medication details was provided. Company comment:This case concerns 13-years-old, male patient with no reported medical history, who experienced the unexpected Fatal AESI event of Myocardial infarction event (seriousness criteria death and medically significant). The event occurred approximately 7 months after the second dose of mRNA-1273 vaccine. At the time of report, very limited information has been provided about the patient and about the event leading to the fatal outcome. It is also unknown if an autopsy was performed. The benefit-risk relationship of the mRNA-1273 vaccine is not affected by this report.; Sender's Comments: This case concerns 13-years-old, male patient with no reported medical history, who experienced the unexpected Fatal AESI event of Myocardial infarction event (seriousness criteria death and medically significant). The event occurred approximately 7 months after the second dose of mRNA-1273 vaccine. All_symptoms: Clostridium difficile infection Gastrointestinal haemorrhage Inflammatory marker test Rectal haemorrhage
SYMPTOM_TEXT: diagnosed with CDiff; rectal bleeding; she was experiencing recurring GI bleeding; This is a spontaneous report received from a contactable reporter (Other HCP). The reporter is the parent.  A 13-year-old female patient (not pregnant) received bnt162b2 (PFIZER COVID-19 VACCINE), intramuscular, administered in arm left, administration date 06Jun2021 (Lot number: EW0187) at the age of 12 years as dose 2, single for covid-19 immunisation. Relevant medical history included: ""Known allergies: sensitivity to milk"" (unspecified if ongoing). No covid prior vaccination. It was unknown if covid tested post vaccination. Concomitant medications included: PROBIOTICS NOS (possibly); VITAMINS NOS. The patient did not receive other vaccine in four weeks of vaccination. Vaccination history included: Bnt162b2 (Lot number: EW0170, Administration route: Intramuscular, Vaccine location: Left arm), administration date: 16May2021, when the patient was 12 years old, for Covid-19 immunization. The following information was reported: CLOSTRIDIUM DIFFICILE INFECTION (medically significant) with onset 2021, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""diagnosed with CDiff""; RECTAL HAEMORRHAGE (medically significant) with onset 2021, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""rectal bleeding""; GASTROINTESTINAL HAEMORRHAGE (medically significant) with onset 2021, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""she was experiencing recurring GI bleeding"". The events ""diagnosed with cdiff"", ""rectal bleeding"" and ""she was experiencing recurring gi bleeding"" were evaluated at the physician office visit and emergency room visit. The patient underwent the following laboratory tests and procedures: GI inflammatory markers: high. Therapeutic measures were taken as a result of clostridium difficile infection, rectal haemorrhage, gastrointestinal haemorrhage and included treatment with vancomycin antibiotic. Clinical course: Reporter's daughter started experiencing rectal bleeding over the summer. Her GI inflammatory markers were high and she was diagnosed with CDiff despite not being on recent antibiotics or being in a hospital or nursing home. Because this happened over 2 months after the vaccine administration, it did not occur to reporter that this was a potential adverse event. However, given that she was experiencing recurring GI bleeding and a friend just texted about her mom dying with heart and lung inflammation (separate record report), reporter was wondering if she was having a long term inflammatory reaction due to the vaccine.; Sender's Comments: As there is limited information in the case provided, the causal association between the event clostridium difficile infection, rectal haemorrhage, gastrointestinal haemorrhage and the suspect vaccine COMIRNATY cannot be excluded. The impact of this report on the benefit/risk profile of the Pfizer product is evaluated as part of Pfizer procedures for safety evaluation, including the review and analysis of aggregate data for adverse events. Any safety concern identified as part of this review, as well as any appropriate action in response, will be promptly notified to regulatory authorities, Ethics Committees, and Investigators, as appropriate.
LAB_DATA: Test Name: GI inflammatory markers; Result Unstructured Data: Test Result:high

All_symptoms: Blood test normal Chest X-ray normal Chest pain Headache Heart rate increased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Thurs (1/13/2022) afternoon, my son received a booster shot.   Friday, he complained of headache and muscle soreness from his shoulder to his knee.  On Friday night, he started having chest pains, high heart rate, sweats.  Saturday morning, he told us, his parents, about the chest pains and that it hurt badly enough to keep him awake all night.  I took his bp, temp and heart rate.  bp was high, temp was 99.3, heart rate was 120.  We contacted his pediatrician who recommended we go to an ER with imaging.  We went.   My son's father has a clotting disorder, that was disclosed at the ER.
LAB_DATA: Blood tests, chest xray.  1/15/2022.  All within normal ranges.   Myocarditis was ruled out and we were sent home.  Symptoms were gone by Sunday  (1/16/2022) afternoon.    This was a very expensive vaccination for us as ER visits are expensive and we really needed to have him seen for this, being chest pains.

All_symptoms: Chapped lips Ear pain Fatigue Feeling abnormal Lip pain
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On 01/10/2022- she was feeling ill by 2:30 in the afternoon had a fever at about 6:30pm - 101.5. She had a  sore arm, fatigue, fever that day  and the next day.  01/11/2021, early in the evening before bed she felt her bottom lip on the left side was swelling up. It was swollen,  it was the size of a big grape tomato and painful and she was absolutely miserable.  The next morning it progressed to her left jaw line,  swollen gland on her left side and swollen lymph nodes on her left side and her pain was from the bottom of her neck on left side going from her lip to the left side and she was saying that her left ear hurt. She was all swollen . We started giving her Benadryl and the swelling would go down a little bit, after 5 hrs it would wear off and the swelling would continue. The doctor told us to keep her on Benadryl, and  ibuprofen.  By 4 in the afternoon, she was in a lot of pain. I was getting worried. The APRN told us to take her to the ER, that she need to be seen in the emergency Hospital.  01/12/2021- We took her to the ER. They gave her Benadryl and ibuprofen and we waited an 1 1/2 before she was seen . The doctor gave her one dose or oral steroids, dexamethasone.  Originally the APRN, thought it was possibly and allergy, This doctor felt it was an overly strong immune response. Her lip was so swollen, that it actually cracked. She was miserable. The steroids really worked, It helped the swelling go down.  She was a lot more comfortable on the way home and she did not have a fever.  On Thursday and Friday, she was completely exhausted. She was complaining about her lip hurting . She finally left the house on Saturday.  She felt fine to go back to school today, 01/18/2022. She did get considerably better after the steroid.
LAB_DATA: 01/13/2022- COVID 19 test- negative

All_symptoms: Brain natriuretic peptide normal C-reactive protein increased Chest pain Echocardiogram normal Electrocardiogram ST segment elevation
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient received first Pfizer vaccine on 9/1/21 and second vaccine on 9/22/21. She presented on 1/3/22 with one week URI symptoms and one day of acute onset chest pain. Vitals were stable on admission. Mild ST elevation noted on all leads on EKG. Troponin was elevated (peak at 1.59ng/ml, normal <0.03) concerning for myopericarditis. Echo showed normal function and did not show any pericardial effusion. She was treated with high dose Ibuprofen with improvement in symptoms. Viral panel obtained was negative. Patient was discharged to home on  1/5/22 and was at baseline on discharge.
LAB_DATA: Troponin peak on 1/4/22 - 1.59ng/ml, normal <0.03. Level decreased to 0.42ng/ml prior to discharge on 1/5/22.  BNP normal at 32 pg/ml (normal <100); Respiratory viral panel negative. COVID-19 PCR negative; CRP -57mg/L (normal <7.5); ESR -54 mm/hr (normal <20); wbc 11.8, no bands; Echocardiogram 1/4/22 - normal function, normal coronaries, no pericardial effusion.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Day after booster- Soreness, minor rashes, nausea, tight throat, headache , pain in chest, rapid heart, swelling in face and lymph nodes. Wheezing and heartbeat sent us to ER. Given Prednisone, Cephalexine, Ondansetron 2nd day- repeat of same symptoms by evening, return to ER. 3rd day- fatigue, minor swelling in face, headache, tight throat. Visit to allergist for bloodwork. 4th day- exhaustion, dizzy, headache behind eyes, tight throat.

HISTORY: Possible diagnosis of mast cell syndrome as yet unsubstantiated by allergist.

All_symptoms: Blood pressure increased Chills Echocardiogram Electrocardiogram Energy increased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On January 16, 2022, Patient woke up at 8:30 am and had an 11:20 am appointment at Pharmacy for the 2nd dose of Pfizer pediatric. After waiting, she ended up getting up around 12:00 pm.   At 5:30 pm, she told me that she felt tired which sounded like a normal side effect of the vaccine. Around 6 pm, she mentioned it again.   At 9:00 pm, I noticed that she was more active than usual.   By 10:30 pm, I was still waiting for the ?common? side effects of the vaccine but instead, she was more active than before. She had a weird excess of energy and was breathing faster (like a person does after a breathing treatment). She also looked like she was ?under drugs? because she was way too happy and funny/silly.  At 10:22 pm, she was very cold, shivering, her teeth were chattering even though her forehead temperature was 97.1.  However, at 12:25 am (Monday, January 17), I switched her pajama because her body felt hotter (97.5).   At 2:43 am, I gave her Tylenol because her body (especially her hands, belly, and back of her neck) felt hotter (98), and she looked tired. However, she was still unable to sleep. Her comment was ?I want to sleep but my body doesn?t let me.? She was moving constantly.  At 3:58 am, she was still completely awake, very hyper, and with a temperature of 98.2.  At 6:18 am, still not sleepy and with a lot of energy. And, at 7:01 am her hands and back of her neck were still a little hot.   At 9:00 am, she went to urgent care. The nurse took her blood pressure and pulse three times because the numbers were high. An EKG was also performed. She was also referred for a second EKG and an echo to make sure her heart wasn?t affected.  At 1:00 pm, after 28 hours with 30 minutes, she was finally able to sleep. She slept for 2 hours. During the afternoon, she still had the energy to play around. She wasn?t hyper as she was before but, she wasn?t acting like someone who have barely slept. She was not sleepy.  9:00 pm - Went to bed and was able to sleep peacefully. At this time, she slept for 13 hours and 33 minutes (until 10:33 am).
LAB_DATA: Monday, January 17, 2022 - Facility took her vitals as usual, and both her blood pressure and pulse were high. The third time showed better results. Then, they performed an EKG at the office. It showed normal results, but they still didn't feel completely comfortable due to her vitals and the fact that happened after getting the vaccine.  She was diagnosed with other: ? Insomnia ? Adverse effect of other vaccines and biological substances, initial encounter ? Tachycardia, unspecified  She was also referred to get another EKG and an echo to determine if the reaction to the vaccine caused any damage to her heart.  (This is still pending/ongoing)

All_symptoms: Cardiac disorder Electrocardiogram normal Headache Hypertension Palpitations
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Spoke to patient's mom, Patience, to provide a routine follow-up consultation for patient's Humira, but mom was very frustrated and began inquiring why a prescription would be given to her son that would cause him to have high blood pressure.  Mom noted that her son was perfectly normal before and never had any blood pressure issues, but now his blood pressure is very high, his heart is racing, and he has occasional headaches.  Patient began taking Humira 1/29/21 and did well on the first few doses, but later in May 2021, mom noticed that patient?s heart was racing when he came to her bed to give her a hug after school one day.  Mom checked his pulse the next day and again noted it was racing, so she checked his blood pressure, which was 175/80.  Mom continued to take multiple readings daily and continued to get high and similar readings.  Mom took patient to MD, who noted that EKG looked okay and referred her to take her son to a Cardiologist.  Mom is distraught wondering if there is another medication that GI doctor can give patient since he never had high blood pressure before and it?s ?not okay? for this to be happening to her son and does not understand what has caused him to now have high blood pressure and heart problems.  After further questioning about medical history, mom noted that patient received the COVID-19 vaccinations at school and began having the heart and high blood pressure symptoms about two weeks following the first dose.
LAB_DATA: EKG

SYMPTOM_TEXT: lost consciousness; incoherent; dizzy; Right Atrial Enlargement; fever; nausea; headache; Booster; This is a spontaneous report received from contactable reporter(s) (Consumer or other non HCP). The reporter is the patient. A 14-year-old male patient received BNT162B2 (PFIZER-BIONTECH COVID-19 MRNA VACCINE) administered in arm right, administration date 09Jan2022 13:30 (Lot number: 33025BD) at the age of 14 years as dose 3 (booster), single for covid-19 immunisation. The facility where the most recent COVID-19 vaccine was administered was Pharmacy or Drug Store. Relevant medical history included: ""Asthma"" (unspecified if ongoing); ""Allergies"" (unspecified if ongoing); ""Known allergies: Latex"" (unspecified if ongoing). Concomitant medications included: levocetirizine dihydrochloride (XYZAL); fluoxetine hydrochloride (PROZAC) 20 mg; VITAMIN D NOS. The patient did not receive any other vaccine within 4 weeks prior to the vaccine. Vaccination history included: Bnt162b2 (Dose Number: 2, Batch/Lot No: EW0196, Location of injection: Arm Right), administration date: 12Jun2021, when the patient was 13 years old, for COVID-19 Immunization; Bnt162b2 (Dose Number: 1, Batch/Lot No: EW0187, Location of injection: Arm Right), administration date: 22May2021, when the patient was 13 years old, for COVID-19 Immunization. The following information was reported: IMMUNISATION (medically significant) with onset 09Jan2022 13:30, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""Booster""; LOSS OF CONSCIOUSNESS (medically significant) with onset 10Jan2022 09:00, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""lost consciousness""; INCOHERENT (medically significant) with onset 10Jan2022 09:00, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""incoherent""; DIZZINESS (medically significant) with onset 10Jan2022 09:00, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""dizzy""; RIGHT ATRIAL ENLARGEMENT (medically significant) with onset 10Jan2022 09:00, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""Right Atrial Enlargement""; PYREXIA (non-serious) with onset 10Jan2022 09:00, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""fever""; NAUSEA (non-serious) with onset 10Jan2022 09:00, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""nausea""; HEADACHE (non-serious) with onset 10Jan2022 09:00, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""headache"".  The events ""lost consciousness"", ""incoherent"", ""dizzy"", ""right atrial enlargement"", ""fever"", ""nausea"" and ""headache"" were evaluated at the emergency room visit.  The patient underwent the following laboratory tests and procedures: electrocardiogram (EKG): (10Jan2022) was indicative of right atrial enlargement; COVID Nasal Swab: (10Jan2022) negative. Therapeutic measures were not taken as a result of loss of consciousness, incoherent, dizziness, right atrial enlargement, fever, nausea and headache. Prior to the vaccination, the patient was not diagnosed with COVID-19.  It was also reported that since the vaccination, the patient had been tested for COVID-19. Clinical course: Patient was at school and lost consciousness, was incoherent, dizzy and needed to be wheeled to the nurse for dismissal. Urgent Care diagnosis from EKG was indicative of Right Atrial Enlargement. Scheduled a Cardiology Appointment for this Thursday at 3PM. Has accompanying fever, dizziness, and nausea and headache as well

Received EPI pen at home, and came to ED just in case.  VS normal, normal O2 sat.  No abnormal findings on exam. Treated with duoneb and albuterol nebs and prednisone. Patient discharged home.

All_symptoms: Blood calcium decreased Blood parathyroid hormone increased COVID-19 Calcium ionised decreased Cerebral calcification
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Day after vaccination, 10PM  developed episode of seizure like activity (generalized tonic-clonic like movements of upper and lower bilateral extremities, eyes rolling back and drooling), brought to ED, CT head showed b/l symmetric calcification within basal ganglia and along cortical medullary junction of both anterior loves and parietotemporal lobes. Ionized calcium 0.58, PTH 630, total Calcium 4.5, EKG with QTc 545, also found to be COVID positive. Symptoms resolved with 1gm calcium gluconate. Suspected to have pseudohypoparathyroidism. Admitted to the PICU.

HISTORY: None known at time of vaccination, dx with pseudohypoparathyroidism 1/22/2022

All_symptoms: Blood test Communication disorder Emotional disorder Feeling abnormal Neurological decompensation
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient received the first covid 19 vaccine shot on 11/25.  Three days after the shot she started asking a lot of questions and seemed very confused about the most basic questions.  We thought this was a phase at the time.  She received the 2nd shot on 12/15 and within 5 days had completely deteriorated neurologically.  She developed acute severe OCD, significant age regression, and was unable to function.  She lost the ability to communicate, just pointing and grunting for things that she wanted.  She became completely emotionally disconnected (unable to say I love you or sorry or anything with emotion).  Almost overnight she turned into a 4 year old with autism and ocd.
LAB_DATA: Initial blood work was completed at the hospital on 12/29 and additional blood work was completed at Dr. office on 1/12.

All_symptoms: Dizziness Fatigue Heart rate irregular Malaise Nausea
SYMPTOM_TEXT: At 4:05pm vaccine was administered to patient. While we were waiting for the 15 minutes to elapse, patient looked visibly ill by 4:12pm. I asked him what was wrong and he replied that he felt sick and really tired. I told him to take a seat near me. When he sat next to me he said he was really tired and wanted to go to sleep and proceeded to close his eyes. I told him to stay awake. I then called one of the nurses and i helped them put patient in an observation room. They proceeded to take his vitals for the next 30 minutes. Patient was laying down feeling very fatigued with the feeling of nausea as well. During the course of 30 minutes, his heartbeat fluctuated between 70bpm and 100bpm. After 30 min, nurses recommended an ambulance be called since symptoms were not getting better. Once EMT?s arrived, they determined that patient was stable and that we (his parents) should take him to the ER for further observation. Upon checking in to the ER, he was given medication for nausea. His vital signs were stable and we stayed at the ER for approx 2 hours for observation. At Approx 8:15pm, symptoms improved and we checked out of the hospital. The following morning, patient stated he was feeling dizziness and nauseated when standing up. We decided it would be best for him to stay home from school & we were able to setup an appt with his PCM. His doctor was not sure why he had this reaction to the vaccine and was given nausea medication.
LAB_DATA: No tests administered

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Date of Admission:  12/29/2021   Date of Discharge:  1/1/2022   Attending Physician:   (M.D.)   Admitting Diagnosis: CORONAVIRUS COVID-19 LOWER RESPIRATORY INFECTION   Principal Diagnosis(Discharge Diagnosis): CORONAVIRUS COVID-19 LOWER RESPIRATORY INFECTION   Secondary Diagnoses:  Active Hospital Problems   Diagnosis   ? (Principal) CORONAVIRUS COVID-19 LOWER RESPIRATORY INFECTION   ? ASTHMA, UNSPECIFIED W ACUTE EXACERBATION     Resolved Hospital Problems No resolved problems to display.   Primary Procedures: None   Secondary Procedures: High Flow Nasal Cannula   Issues to be Addressed at Follow-up: - Patient with severe COVID-19, tested postiive on 12/29/21. Isolation for 20 days from first day of symptoms (untill 1/18/22).  - Second dose of covid vaccine after isolation completed  7yr old boy with PMHx of Moderate Persistent Asthma and OSA with recent hospitalization 3 weeks ago for asthma and walking PNA (discharged on Azithromycin) who presented with difficulty breathing. He was found to have wheezing, s/p Magnesium, Terb, Methylprednisolone, and Albuterol 15mg/h in the ED with improvement in symptoms after these interventions. He later tested positive for COVID-19 on 12/29/2021 and was admitted for hypoxemic respiratory failue secondary to COVID-19 PNA and acute asthma exacerbation. He required HFNC up to 15L/60%. Patient was treated with Albuterol per RT driven protocol and steroids per asthma dosing x 2 days (15 mg Dexamethasone daily x 2 doses). He was transitioned to Dexamethasone 6 mg daily per COVID-19 pneumonia dosing. He was also started on Remdesivir with a loading dose followed by 100 mg daily. Patient improved clinically and was weaned to room air by time of discharge.

All_symptoms: Confusional state Dreamy state Fatigue Fear Feeling abnormal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Booster shot received Sunday, 4pm. Child was fine until around 1am Monday and developed normal fever, fatigue and swollen lymph nodes in arm. Tuesday woke up with no fever but headache and feeling off. Attended virtual school so he could be monitored. Tuesday around 3 the child became unaware of what was happening. Described walking in a dream state and was terrified. Hallucinating and confusion lasted around 20 to 30 minutes. Went to the er as instructed by telephone call. They assumed it was a vaccine reaction, was told it had to pass and to come back for follow up. Child woke up Wednesday with a migrane and threw up breakfast. Thursday had no further dillusions or issues but severe fatigue. Child was taken back to the Dr today (Friday) and checked again. Vitals seemed fine. Was told to return Monday for bloodwork if the fatigue does not subside.

All_symptoms: Chest pain Crying Dyspnoea Fatigue Insomnia
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On January 19, 2022 at 7pm, Patient complained that she was having trouble breathing and she was tired.  She was seen at Hospital on 1/19/22 at 7:30 PM and a COVID test was done.  While there patient began to cry because the chest pain was increasing and she could not take deep breaths.  When we returned home she was still in pain and could not take deep breaths because her chest hurt her.  She was saying she thought she was going to die.  She could not lay down fully and her head and chest was elevated to allow her to take short shallow breaths.   She finally fell asleep and woke up the next morning with chest pain but able to breath easier.  She said her chest was sore from the night before, but she could breath better.
LAB_DATA: COVID 19 test on 1.19.22 was negative

All_symptoms: AST/ALT ratio Adenovirus test Alanine aminotransferase normal Anion gap Aspartate aminotransferase normal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: PATIENT SUMMARY:  Reason for Hospitalization: Myocarditis  Admission HPI: The patient is a 14 yo with no significant PMH who presented with chest pain x 2 days and diffuse ST segment elevation x 1 day, 4 days after receiving his booster COVID-19 vaccine.     Family reports that the patient had previously received 2 doses of the Pfizer vaccine without complication. Following his booster, he initially had headaches and chills, and then on Wednesday he started to develop chest pain localized to the center of the chest with numbness and worsening with exertion.  He went to his primary care doctor on Wednesday 1/19/2022 and given that the pain was mostly exertional in nature, was sent home with return precautions. Then in the middle of the night on Wednesday night into Thursday 1/20/2022, patient had an episode of chest pain that woke him from sleep with 5/10 pain.  He took a dose of ibuprofen, and was eventually able to go back to sleep.  He continued to have chest pain this morning, particularly walking at school, and his parents called PCP office back regarding persistent pain.  He then presented to the PCPs office , where he received a EKG, chest x-ray, and blood work including a troponin.  Parent subsequently received a call from the PCP regarding abnormal EKG findings, and he was referred to the emergency department.   Hospital Course:   In the ED, patient was reporting 1-2/10 chest pain worse with mild exertion such as walking. He also endorses lightheadedness particularly with standing up. He denies any shortness of breath. VSS, no tachycardia, well appearing. Cardiac exam normal. No lower extremity edema. EKG reviewed there. Troponin from PCP resulted at 2.09, repeat labs in process and thus far include: normal chem, no leukocytosis, Hgb 14.2, Plt 174 (borderline low), d-dimer wnl, CRP 3.8. Troponin rising to 2.63. AST/ALT with transaminitis. Repeat CXR unremarkable. COVID PCR today is negative. A point of care ultrasound was obtained with two cardiac views which visualized the pericardial space   He was admitted to cardiac service: During his stay we trended his Troponin that was downtrending. He had no chest pain. On 1/22/2022 had a run of Ventricular tachycardia, and was started on Nodalol. Received a IVIG and started the 5 day course of Steroids. On the day of discharge, Troponin down to 0.1, no arrhythmias over the past 48 hours. patient was in no apparent distress, afebrile. Patient was tolerating PO intake well with no vomiting or diarrhea. Family was given written and verbal discharge instructions including follow up and when to seek urgent care. Parents agreed with plan for discharge.  Reasons for new, changed, and discontinued medications:  -Nodalol 40 mg OD  -Prednisone 40 mg twice daily for 6 more doses. ( received 4 doses of 30 mg Methylprednisolone IV during his admission will continue on 1:1 steroid conversion at home)  Reasons for new, changed, and discontinued equipment: NA   Relevant Diagnostic Images/Studies:  Echo done during his stay: ? LAB_DATA: Phosphatidylserine/Prothrombin Antibodies (PHOSPHATIDYLSERINE/PROTHROMBIN ANTIBODIES) - Final result (01/20/2022 10:53 AM PST) Phosphatidylserine/Prothrombin Antibodies (PHOSPHATIDYLSERINE/PROTHROMBIN ANTIBODIES) - Final result (01/20/2022 10:53 AM PST) Component Value Ref Range Performed At Pathologist Signature aPS/PT, IgG 144.1 <=30.0 G units LABORATORY   aPS/PT, IgM >150.0 <=30.0 M units  LABORATORY   Phosphatidylserine/Prothrombin Antibodies (PHOSPHATIDYLSERINE/PROTHROMBIN ANTIBODIES) - Final result (01/20/2022 10:53 AM PST) Specimen Blood - Blood specimen (specimen) Phosphatidylserine/Prothrombin Antibodies (PHOSPHATIDYLSERINE/PROTHROMBIN ANTIBODIES) - Final result (01/20/2022 10:53 AM PST) Narrative  LABORATORY - 01/21/2022 10:09 AM PST  1. A positive result (based on 99th percentile cutoff) indicates the presence of PS/PT (phosphatidylserine/prothrombin complex) IgG or IgM antibodies and suggests the possibility of certain autoimmune disease thrombotic disorders, such as APS or those secondary to systemic lupus erythematosus or other lupus-like thrombotic diseases.  A negative result indicates no PS/PT IgG or IgM antibodies or levels below the detection limit of the assay cutoff.  2. It is to be expected that some samples can be anticardiolipin positive and/or anti-B2 GPI positive yet PS/PT IgG or IgM negative. The anti-B2 GPI test is a specific marker of thrombotic risk. The anticardiolipin test can produce false positive results due to cross-reactivity with dsDNA or certain infectious disease antibodies. Similarly, patients with APS can be PS/PT positive yet lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin or anti-B2 negative. SYMPTOM_TEXT: Felt achy/ aches; Tired; Injection site hurting; He had a fever above 102F by 24 hours post injection; Chills; His lymph nodes under the arm on the injection side were very raised and swollen.; This is a spontaneous report from a contactable reporter (consumer or other non HCP).  A 12-year-old male patient received bnt162b2 (BNT162B2), intramuscular, administered in right arm, administration date 19Jan2022 at 19:45 (Lot number: FJ5682) at the age of 12 years as dose 3 (booster), single for COVID-19 immunisation. Relevant medical history included: ""Asthma"" (unspecified if ongoing) and ""Eczema"" (unspecified if ongoing), notes: ezcema. There were no concomitant medications. Past drug history included: Cephalexin, reaction: ""Drug allergy"", notes: Known allergies: cephalexin. Vaccination history included: Bnt162b2 (DOSE 1, SINGLE; Lot Number: FA7484; Route of Administration: Intramuscular), administration date: 26Jul2021, when the patient was 12 years old, for COVID-19 immunisation and Bnt162b2 (DOSE 2, SINGLE; Lot Number: FA7485; Route of Administration: Intramuscular), administration date: 16Aug2021, when the patient was 12 years old, for COVID-19 immunisation. The following information was reported: PAIN (non-serious) with onset 20Jan2022, outcome ""recovered"" (20Jan2022), described as ""Felt achy/ aches""; FATIGUE (non-serious) with onset 20Jan2022, outcome ""recovered"" (20Jan2022), described as ""Tired""; VACCINATION SITE PAIN (non-serious) with onset 20Jan2022, outcome ""recovered"" (20Jan2022), described as ""Injection site hurting""; PYREXIA (non-serious) with onset 20Jan2022, outcome ""recovered"" (20Jan2022), described as ""He had a fever above 102F by 24 hours post injection""; CHILLS (non-serious) with onset 20Jan2022, outcome ""recovered"" (20Jan2022), described as ""Chills""; LYMPHADENOPATHY (non-serious) with onset 20Jan2022, outcome ""recovered"" (20Jan2022), described as ""His lymph nodes under the arm on the injection side were very raised and swollen"". The events ""Felt achy/ aches"", ""Tired"", ""Injection site hurting"", ""He had a fever above 102F by 24 hours post injection"", ""Chills"" and ""His lymph nodes under the arm on the injection side were very raised and swollen."" were evaluated at the physician office visit and emergency room visit. Relevant laboratory tests and procedures are available in the appropriate section. Therapeutic measures were not taken as a result of pain, fatigue, vaccination site pain, pyrexia, chills and lymphadenopathy.  Additional information: The patient did not receive any other vaccines within four weeks prior to the COVID vaccine. Prior to vaccination, the patient was not diagnosed with COVID-19. Since the vaccination, the patient had been tested for COVID-19. It was reported that although the reporter was aware of the adverse event, it had been waited to report until received a negative PCR Covid test, as the patient's soccer teammates had recently tested positive for Covid. The doctor stated his symptoms were consistent with Covid and she was not certain if there was an adverse event reaction.

All_symptoms: Dyspnoea Erythema Headache Lip swelling Pruritus
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient awoke at 6:20 a.m. with labored breathing, pruritis, red face, facial pain and swelling of lips.  Mother states she also had headache and described a blotchy skin rash on both arms.  The mother gave her acetaminophen and brought her to the emergency department.  Patient states that symptoms improved significantly after acetaminophen although she still had a mild headache and itching.  In the emergency department no facial swelling or rash was observed.  The oropharynx was clear without erythema or exudate.  There was no stridor or trismus.  She was given a dose of diphenhydramine.  The mother was told to give diphenhydramine, acetaminophen and ibuprofen as needed and the patient was dischanged.
LAB_DATA: None

All_symptoms: Aortic disorder C-reactive protein normal Chest X-ray abnormal Chest pain Echocardiogram normal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Chief Complaint  Post vaccine myocarditis.  History of Present Illness     Pt. is a 13 yo young man who was admitted for post vaccine myocarditis, occurring 3 days after receiving the Pfizer COVID booster. His d/c summary is noted below. He received a dose of ibuprophen in our ED and was observed overnight. He had a repeat troponin as an outpatient on 1/18/2022 which was 0.03. Since his discharge home, Pt. has been afebrile and he has not had any chest pain. No palpitations, no dizziness or syncope. ROS includes a peanut and tree nut allergy for which he has an Epipen, otherwise, no significant medical hx. Pt. is in the 8th grade. He was on a swim team (through March). He does jiu jitsu inthe spring and plays soccer three times a week but has been restricted from sports since his discharge.  Cardiology Summary Narrative   Discharge Summary 1/15-1/16/22: Pt. is a 13yo previously healthy who initially presented with complaints of chest pain 3 days after the COVID booster (booster date 1/12/2022). He reports that he woke up on 1/15/2022with an aching chest pain that was localized primarily to the substernal area and a little bit to the left but otherwise did not radiate. He does not know of any exacerbating symptoms, but the pain was relieved after about an hour and taking 2 advil. He said throughout the day it has come back a little bit, currently reporting 1/10, but nothing similar to the intensity that he felt this morning. He had his COVID Pfizer booster on Wednesday and reports only having vague fatigue with the initial 2 dose series. He has not previous experienced these symptoms nor has he been ill or in contact with anyone ill recently. He has not previously had COVID.  At hospital, they did a thorough work-up that included normal CBC, Chemistry, inflammatory markers (CRP 10, nml < 15), NT-BNP (76, nml < 450), and ECG. However, he did have serial elevation of troponins (highly sensitive, nml <14) with 94 -- > 124, so he was sent to BCH given concern of post-vaccine myocarditis.  Recent Testing:  CXR (1/15/22)  There is visceral situs solitus and a left-sided aortic arch. The heart is normal in size and shape. The pulmonary blood flow is normal and the lungs are clear.  Hospital Course:  Pt. was admitted with post vaccine booster myocarditis. He reported significant chest pain the morning of 1/15 which has since resolved. During his admission he complained of at most 1/10 chest and most recently none at all. He had two EKGS during his admission that were all normal. His labs did show a mildly elevated troponin, last 0.23 prior to d/c. An ECHO showed a structurally normal heart with no dysfunction or coronary abnormalities. Given his resolved symptoms and normal EKG and ECHO Pt. is being discharged home with plan to repeat a troponin as an outpatient on Tuesday 1/18 and follow-up with cardiology in 1-2 wks.    1/20/22 Cardiology visit: Physical Exam  Vitals & Measurements  T: 37.1  °C  (Temporal Artery)  HR: 67 (Monitored)  BP: 112/62  SpO2: 99%   Weight: 50.1 kg (58%ile)*; Height: 167.0 cm (82%ile)*; Body Mass Index: 18 kg/m2 (37%ile)*  *CDC chart used to calculate percentile value.   There was no cyanosis or clubbing, and no rash.  Neck veins were flat in the sitting position.  There were no carotid bruits.  Chest was clear to auscultation.  Cardiac exam revealed a normal cardiac impulse without thrill.  S1 was single.  S2 was physiologically split.  There were no murmurs, gallops, or clicks.  Abdomen was soft and nontender, without hepatosplenomegaly.  Pulses were full throughout, and there was no radial-femoral delay.  Extremities were warm and well perfused, and there was no pretibial edema.  Cardiology Diagnostics  EKG: HR 67 bpm. WNL   Group Detail Date Value w/Units Flags Normal Range Normal Reference Text Comment Ind  Chemistry Troponin T 01/20/2022 16:02:22 EST <0.01 ng/mL  Chemistry C-Reactive Protein 01/20/2022 16:02:22 EST 0.08 mg/dL           Assessment/Plan   In summary, Pt. is a 13 yo with recent hospitalization for post vaccine associated myocarditis, treated with ibuprofen. His presentation included chest pain and elevated troponins (normalized). He had a normal echo, normal EKG. His troponin and CRP are pending and will be added once they are resulted.  He has not had any further chest pain. The family is very medically knowledgeable (mom is a neurologist and dad is a scientist). At this time, they have decided not to pursue a cardiac MRI but will have one in March 2022. We discussed what we know about post vaccine myocarditis and, in this setting, we follow similar guidelines as those with myocarditis in order to give the myocardium time to heal. Dr discussed our recommendations for activity restrictions. Pt. should be restricted from competitive/vigorous sports for the next 2-3 months and will return for a cardiac MRI for LGE in March, 2022.
LAB_DATA: As per #18

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Chief Complaint  Neurologic problem (Complaint of)  Arrival Date/Time: 01/21/2022 13:05:00 History of Present Illness    5 yo M with hx of autism (non-verbal) presenting with unresponsive episode. Pt was in usual state of health last night when he received his 2nd COVID-19 vaccine. He awoke today with fatigue and malaise that seemed to improve so pt went to school where he was sent home for malaise and fever (temp unknown). After arriving home, father went to change his pull up and while laying down pt was unresponsive and drooling and did not appear to be breathing. His eyes were open and rolled backwards. He appeared limp. No rhythmic jerking but family did say he seemed shaky earlier today. He turned blue during the episode so family called EMS and when police showed up, cyanosis resolved and pt had rapid, shallow breathing. He was sleepy afterwards but slowly improving.  POC glucose 185 en route. PIV placed. No meds or interventions performed. Tachy en route 140-150's.  He was given tylenol earlier today.  PMHx: Autism (non-verbal)  Home meds: None.  NKDA FMHx: NO hx of seizure or febrile seizure. Social Hx: Lives with family.  Attends school. Review of Systems    General: +fever, +decerased appetite today Neuro: no headache  or focal weakness. Skin: no rashes, bruising. HEENT: no vision changes, nasal congestion, sore throat. Cardiac: no chest pain. Respiratory: no cough, difficulty breathing, shortness of breath. GI: no recent nausea, vomiting, diarrhea. GU: no dysuria, hematuria. MSK: no joint pain or swelling.   10 ROS reviewed and otherwise negative   Physical Exam  Vitals & Measurements      T  HR  RR  BP  Sp02   First Set  37.4 DegC (01/21/22 13:15:25) 140 bpm (01/21/22 13:25:13) 28 br/min (01/21/22 13:25:13) 121/63 mmHg (01/21/22 13:25:13) 100 % (01/21/22 13:25:13)    VS as above.  GEN: sleepy, non-verbal, intermittently follows commands. No acute distress. HEENT: PERRL, clear conjunctiva, oropharynx clear, moist mucous membranes. NECK: supple, full neck ROM. No LAD. CV: RRR, no murmurs. RESP: CTAB. ABD: soft, nontender, non-distended.  EXT: warm, well perfused. NEURO: Moves all extremities equally. He is unable to cooperate with strength exam but full strength in lower extremities noted when touching his feet.  Normal gait but slow. Normal balance. No tremors.   Medical Decision Making     5 yo M with autism (non-verbal) presenting with unresponsive episode with cyanosis in the setting of malaise and fever post-COVID vaccine last night. DDx: febrile seizure, epileptic seizure, syncope, arrhythmia, myocarditis (post-vaccine), acute COVID-19 infection.  Plan: chemistry, troponin, EKG, ibuprofen, COVID PCR, observe   Reexamination/Reevaluation   15:45 - Pt is still sleeping. Feels warm to touch. HR downtrending. Labs significant for mild hyponatremia (Na 134), neg trop, neg rapid COVID/FLU/RSV PCRs. EKG normal. Will continue to observe to re-assess after waking.  16:57 - Pt is awake, alert and at baseline. Eating a banana. Care instructions and return precautions given to family. Family will follow-up with his primary Neurologist. Given this was a simple febrile seizure, he does not require Neuro consultation in ED or urgent EEG/imaging.   Final Diagnosis   1. SYMPTOM_TEXT: Chief Complaint  Facial droop (Complaint of)  Arrival Date/Time: 12/15/2021 13:18:00  History of Present Illness   11 yo girl presents with facial droop. Pt was in usual state of health and received second dose of covid vaccine yesterday. This morning woke up with generalized HA, 7/10, took ibuprofen before going to school and HA resolved. During PE at school, around 9:30am, after she was shuffling her feet for some time, she felt numbness on R side of her face, had difficulty speaking, she was drooling from R side of her mouth and noted to have R facial droop. Symptoms resolved after 2 minutes by the time she arrived in the nurse's office and she was noted to have normal exam by the school nurse. Pt denies any Pt denies any weakness of arms and legs, she was able to walk normally and denies any HA at the time. She also complained of feeling SOB and felt like she was going to faint. Denies CP, palpitation, fever, cough, vomiting, diarrhea.  She feels at her baseline currently.  No hx of migraine  Family History: Mom hx of migraine an von Willebrand. No fam hx of seizure Social History: Lives with family Immunizations: Up to date Review of Systems  Pertinent positives and negatives noted above in HPI. All other systems of a 10 system review are negative.    Physical Exam  Vitals & Measurements    T  HR  RR  BP  Sp02   First Set  36.4 DegC (12/15/21 13:33:11) 92 bpm (12/15/21 13:33:11) 20 br/min (12/15/21 13:33:11) 119/60 mmHg (12/15/21 13:33:11) 100 % (12/15/21 13:33:11)    General: alert, no acute distress, well-appearing, pleasant Skin: no rash, warm, dry Head: atraumatic, normocephalic Eye: normal conjunctiva, sclera clear, no discharge, pupils equal, round, reactive, extraocular movements intact ENT: RTM normal, LTM normal, pharynx: normal, normal tonsils, mouth: moist mucus membranes, no lesions Neck: supple Cardiovascular: regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, normal peripheral perfusion Respiratory: lungs CTA, respirations non labored Gastrointestinal: soft, nontender, nondistended, no organomegaly Musculoskeletal: no deformity, no tenderness, normal range of motion Neurological: appropriate LOC for age, CN II-XII intact, motor strength equal & normal bilaterally, speech normal, normal finger to nose exam, normal negative Romberg   Medical Decision Making  11 yo girl presents with transient episode of R sided facial numbness, difficulty speaking, R sided facial droop which resolved after 2 minutes. Pt had HA earlier in the day which resolved after taking ibuprofen before onset of these symptoms. Pt is back to baseline prior to coming to ED. She received second dose of covid vaccine yesterday. No fever, cough, vomiting, CP, palpitation, but reports feeling sob and felt like she was doing to faint during the episode. On exam, VSS, well-appearing, intact neuro exam with no facial droop, no motor weakness and normal speech. DDx TIA, atypical migraine, focal seizure. Consulted neurology, recommended MRI brain without contrast and MRA. 12-lead EKG also performed and normal, QTc 439  Reexamination/Reevaluation  12/15/2021 16:32 Temperature Temporal Artery: 36.4 DegC (12/15/21 13:33:00)  Systolic Blood Pressure: 119 mmHg (12/15/21 13:33:00)  Diastolic Blood Pressure: 60 mmHg (12/15/21 13:33:00)  Heart Rate: 92 bpm (12/15/21 13:33:00)  Respiratory Rate: 20 br/min (12/15/21 13:33:00)  Oxygen Saturation (SPO2): 100 % (12/15/21 13:33:00) In brief, Pt. is a 11 year old female with no significant medical history who presented with transient episode of R sided facial numbness, difficulty speaking, R sided facial droop which resolved after 2 minutes, i/s/o COVID vaccine. No fevers or infectious sxs. DDx TIA, atypical migraine, focal seizure. Consulted neurology, recommended MRI brain without contrast and MRA, which is pending. EKG w/ NSR; of note, patient complaining of feeling faint/mildly SOB when EKG was done. No CP or palpitations.   Events during my shift:  - Normal MRI, MRA and MRV of the brain; no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or infarction or differential perfusion  - Per Neurology, patient is safe for discharge home; plan outpatient neurology follow-up   Family updated on test results and plan of care. Patient is safe for discharge home with neurology follow-up. Return precautions and anticipatory guidance provided. Written discharge instructions provided and reviewed. All questions answered.  Final Diagnosis  1. Facial droop R29.810 2. Neurological symptom R29.90 3. Headache R51.9 Assessment/Plan  Condition: stable  Disposition: discharged home  Patient and family counseled regarding diagnosis, results, and treatment plan. Questions answered. Patient and family understood.  Briefly, this is an 11-year-old female with unremarkable past medical history who presents with concern for TIA after second dose of Covid vaccine yesterday.  This morning she had acute onset headache and then around 9:30 AM in PE class, she developed right-sided numbness, drooling, difficulty speaking, and facial droop that lasted about 2 minutes.  By the time she was seen by the school nurse she had a normal exam.  No fever.  Agree with history and physical exam as above - no neurologic deficits.  MR/MRA/MRV without any acute findings.  Neurology consulted with plan for discharge home with outpatient neurology follow-up.   Patient safe for discharge home.  Discharged home in stable condition.  Patient to follow-up with neurology and PCP in 1-2 days to ensure continued improvement.  Caregiver in agreement with plan and all questions answered.  Anticipatory guidance and reasons to return to the ED discussed - new neurologic symptoms, fever, any other concerns.  12/15/21 16:22:52  IMPRESSION:  Normal MRI, MRA and MRV of the brain No evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or infarction or differential perfusion.

Patient was transferred to an available room at the site and was laid supine. patient reported feeling better and repeat BP was 106/78 pulse 83bpm, on further questioning patient admitted to skipping breakfast today. At about 10:30am. patient reported feeling better, EMS arrived on site and patient was taken to the hospital.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Acute immune thrombocytopenia. Presented with diffuse ecchymotic and petechial lesions and recent history of epistaxis, with exam on admission notable for slight mucosal bleeding. Found to be profoundly thrombocytopenic (plt count 0 on 1/22/22) with all other cell counts appropriate on CBC, presentation most likely consistent with ITP. No recent h/o viral infection, but could be secondary to covid vaccine on 1/14. Due to presence of mucosal bleeding, patient received 1x dose of IVIG on 1/22. Subsequently showed good response in Platelets uptrending from 0 -- > 6 (1/23) -- > 17 (1/24) prior to discharge. Bleeding symptoms and signs on exam improved. Discharged in stable condition on 1/24/2022 after reviewing need for activity restrictions until Plt count improves > 50-100. Will have outpatient Hematology f/up in next 2-3 weeks and will repeat Plt count at that time.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Heart palpitations after several days of second Pfizer vaccine. It happened with the first dose too, but went away after a few days. This time, it seems to be sticking around and not getting any better. We took Pt to the ER on 1/27/2022 in the middle of the night because his heart rate was up to 135. They did an EKG and blood work. All came back normal. He is looking lethargic, not sleeping well. Having some bad dreams and nigh sweats. We are monitoring his heart with an oximeter and it is fluctuation constantly. While it mostly is staying with in the range of ""normal for his age"", it doesn't stay stable and then goes into a higher heart beat when lying down.
LAB_DATA: EKG, thyroid, electrolytes count, blood count, heart rhythm, blood sugar diabetes. All came back normal on 1/27/2022.

All_symptoms: Activated partial thromboplastin time normal Acute respiratory failure COVID-19 COVID-19 pneumonia International normalised ratio normal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Hospitalized (1.23.22-1.27.22); COVID-19 positive (1.23.22); Fully Vaccinated Patient is a 10 y.o. old male admitted for COVID-19 infection. Admission Date: 1/23/2022  Discharge Date: 1/27/2022 DETAILS OF HOSPITAL STAY: Severe sepsis [A41.9, R65.20] Acute respiratory failure with hypoxia [J96.01] COVID-19 [U07.1] HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient is a 10 y.o. male with congenital glycosylation mutation, global developmental delay with GT dependency, epilepsy on antiepileptics, moderate persistent asthma, CKD, OSA, and neutropenia/lymphopenia with viral infections who is admitted with COVID-19 pneumonia complicated by neutropenia, lymphopenia, and transaminitis. Patient did not require increased oxygen support from his baseline (2L when sleeping), however, given his history of neutropenia and concerning picture for bacterial pneumonia he was started on IV Cefepime.  Given his transaminitis, neutropenia, and risk for thrombosis with his genetic condition and COVID pneumonia and non ambulatory state, Heme/Onc was consulted. They recommended no anticoagulation given his PT/PTT/INR were high normal. Zarxio was started on 1/25 given his neutrophils trending down (calculated on Mandiff 600). His ANC improved >1000 after one day for which his cefepime was discontinued. ID consulted and stated he is not a candidate for IV Remdesivir or decadron given his respiratory stability.
HISTORY: Gastroesophageal reflux disease without esophagitis Undescended testicle Enlarged kidney Hypoglycemia, neonatal Cerebellar hypoplasia  Hypoalbuminemia Bilateral cryptorchidism Congenital disorder of glycosylation associated with mutation in PMM2 gene Thyroxine binding globulin (TBG) deficiency Hypotonia Global developmental delay Torticollis Retching Multidirectional nystagmus Iron deficiency Hypertension Hydronephrosis Renal dysplasia Failed hearing screening Dysphagia, oropharyngeal Excessive weight gain, now stabilized Chronic diarrhea, responding to pectin Symptomatic localization-related epilepsy  Abnormal LFTs Chronic kidney disease G tube feedings  Ineffective airway clearance Hypoxia Cortical visual impairment Hypoglycemia Scoliosis Febrile neutropenia  Thrombocytopenia  Epileptic seizure  Hyponatremia Neutropenia  Other neutropenia  Adult respiratory distress syndrome  Edema Diarrhea in pediatric patient Elevation of level of transaminase or lactic acid dehydrogenase (LDH) Obstructive sleep apnea syndrome Asthma, moderate persistent Viral pneumonia Rhinovirus Upper respiratory infection Carnitine deficiency  Cerebrovascular accident  Congenital disorder of glycosylation (CDG)  Disorder of metabolism Encephalopathy Hearing loss Hemiparesis, right  Splenomegaly Leg length inequality Lung cyst MRSA carrier Protein losing enteropathy S/P Nissen fundoplication (with gastrostomy tube placement)  Seasonal allergic rhinitis

All_symptoms: Acute respiratory failure Acute sinusitis Breath odour C-reactive protein increased COVID-19
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Hospitalized (1.23.22 - 1.29.22);  COVID-19 positive (1.18.22); Fully vaccinated  Admission Date: 1/23/2022  Discharge Date: 01/29/2022 DETAILS OF HOSPITAL STAY: Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure due to COVID-19  [U07.1, J96.01] COVID-19 [U07.1] Pneumonia due to COVID-19 virus [U07.1, J12.82] Acute respiratory failure due to COVID-19 [U07.1, J96.00]   HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient is a 10 y.o. male with PMHx complex partial epilepsy, GDD, Dysphagia, Spastic CP, G-tube dependence who was admitted for admitted for acute hypoxic respiratory failure secondary to COVID Pneumonia.  Patient presented to ED on 1/23 following a 3-day history of worsening cough. Patient had been unwell since 1/15 when he developed terrible nasal congestion. He was seen by his PCP on 1/18 who diagnosed him with acute bacterial rhinosinusitis and started him on a 10-day course of Omnicef and Culturelle. He also tested positive for COVID-19 at that time. 2-3days prior to admission, he then developed a productive cough for which his PCP started him on Albuterol. Patient did not seem to improve with albuterol. Additionally, mom also noted that he had low SpO2 on home pulse ox and so he was brought in to the ED for further evaluation. In the ED, patient was hypothermic and hypoxic (SpO2 87%). He was placed in a heating blanket and started on 4L NC. Labs notable for CRP 15, ESR 19, Procal 0.08. CBC, UA wnl. CXR notable for perihilar opacities. He received 2x NS boluses and 1x albuterol and was then admitted to the inpatient service.  While admitted to the floor, the patient was started on Decadron for his COVID pna, with Pepcid for GI prophylaxis. He had an AWARE called overnight due to increased WOB for which he was started on HFNC and then transferred to the PICU. While in the PICU, his respiratory support was escalated to NIPPV. He also had Albuterol, HTS and Chest physiotherapy added to his pulmonary regimen. He completed his Omnicef course on 1/26. He was eventually weaned off NIPPV to CPAP on 1/27, and then weaned to NC later that day. Patient was then transferred back to the floors on room air. For the rest of his admission, patient remained clinically stable and was on room air. His pulmonary medication regimen was simplified to Albuterol 2.5mg with chest percussion q6h. Shared decision making was made between family and treatment team who agreed that the patient can be discharged home with albuterol and manual CPT q6-8hrs for the next 2-3days. Patient discharged home in stable condition.
HISTORY: Seasonal allergic rhinitis Complex partial epilepsy  ROP (retinopathy of prematurity) Developmental delay Encephalomalacia Global developmental delay Dysphagia Spastic cerebral palsy  Infantile spasms  Gross motor delay Speech delay S/P VP shunt Low muscle tone History of neurological testing - DO NOT EDIT Constipation, chronic Modifiend Hypsarrhythmia Acquired coxa valga of both hips Uses feeding tube Chronic lung disease Environmental allergies Bowel and bladder incontinence Dependence on wheelchair Nocturnal oxygen desaturation Nonintractable epileptic spasms without status epilepticus  Other chronic respiratory diseases originating in the perinatal period Localization-related (focal) (partial) symptomatic epilepsy and epileptic syndromes with complex partial seizures, not intractable, with status epilepticus  Shock  Gastrostomy tube dependent

All_symptoms: Dizziness Pallor
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 14 year old female received Booster dose of Pfizer RTU at 3:18pm. While waiting the 15 minutes after vaccination patient's mom came to the Pharmacy because her daughter was feeling dizzy and was pale. I proceeded to give her an ammonia tablet to sniff and proceeded to check her BP (71/44) Pulse: 50. This was at 3:23pm. 9-1-1 was called and we proceeded to move the patient to the immunization room to lie down on the floor and put her legs up on a chair. She started to gain color again and started to feel better. She drank 2 or 3 sips of water with a little salt that her brother brought. Dizziness started to go away and she wanted o sit on the chair. I took her BP again (98/65). Suddenly, she had the urge to go to the bathroom. While she was at the bathroom, emergency responders arrived at the pharmacy. When her mother brought her back, she was dizzy again and paramedics put her on the stretcher and moved her to the ambulance. Patient's mother told us that her daughter tried to vomit in the bathroom, but she couldn't. They all left to the hospital.
LAB_DATA: N/A

All_symptoms: Anion gap normal Blood culture negative Body fluid analysis Chest X-ray Chills
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On January 14, 2022 patient  came home from school with symptom of shortness of breath only. She was seen at an urgent care that day and tested negative for COVID. The physician there was concerned for refiux so she was given a medicine to treat this. She developed fever on 1/15 up to 105. That same day she was seen by the PCP as she also developed chill, body aches and had continued SOB. She was admitted to hospital.  During the course of her admission, she was found to have elevated inflammatory markers. Given the concern for her new murmur, an echo was obtained. It demonstrated a large, circumferential pericardial effusion with concern for possible tamponade physiology. Cardiology, rheumatology, and infectious disease were brought on board. While there was some initial concern for MIS-C, the clinical history, only mildly elevated inflammatory markers, and single organ involvement did not fit MIS-C and the decision was made to begin treating patient for pericarditis.
LAB_DATA: Chest Xray, CT, EKG, Echocardiogram, Labs and Cultures, and Pericardiocentesis.  All cultures are preliminarily negative and other resulted labs have been negative including IGRA. EBV Ab, Histo blood/urine Ag, flow cytometry, and body fluid path neg for P, Jirovecii/AFB, Pending labs include Karius test, Parvovirus PCR, CMV PCR, EBV PCR, Adenovirus PCR, Echovirus Abs, and Histo Ab

All_symptoms: Arthropod bite Fatigue Foreign travel Headache Muscular weakness
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 11 y/o female with no significant past medical history who presents to the ED with throat pain, neck tenderness, vomiting and fevers. Of note, patient recently traveled overseas from 1/10/22 - 1/30/22. Last Thursday (1/27), while there, patient started to complain of a sore throat and right-sided neck pain. She reports pain with swallowing and talking which eventually progressed to pain with solid foods. She has been able to drink liquids with minimal pain. She rates the pain an 8/10 and reports that it has been worsening since onset. She also states that she has had intermittent headaches since then as well but denies headache at this time. Denies any blurry or double vision or photophobia when headache is present. Patient returned home on 1/30 and started feeling ""feverish"" at home. Tmax at home was 102F. She also started having emesis that day. She reports 4-5 episodes of NBNB emesis. She has been unable to any food down since but has been tolerating liquids. She reports some fatigue, lower extremity weakness, urinary frequency and clear rhinorrhea. Patient denies night sweats, chills, diarrhea, neck stiffness, muscle pain, numbness/tingling, dysuria, rash, abdominal pain, cough, SOB, chest pain or known sick contacts. None of her family or family she travelled with have similar symptoms. Patient states there was a cat in the house she was staying at but denies any scratches or touching the cat. She reports that a mosquito bit her on her left thigh a week after arriving but no bug bite is seen at this time. Of note, patient was prescribed Atovaquone 3 days prior to travelling and has been taking it while traveling however has intermittently missed doses for a total of 4-5 missed doses. Patient has not taken any doses since arriving back home.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Case-patient had first Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine on 11/22/21, acute covid infection on 12/1/21, second Pfizer vaccine on 12/22/21, and developed MIS-C on 12/31/21 (illness onset).  Case-patient met case definition for MIS-C, with evidence of clinically severe illness requiring hospitalization, with multisystem organ involvement (cardiac, hematologic, gastrointestinal, and dermatologic). Case-patient was treated with aspirin, steroids, and IVIG and survived after a 5 day hospitalization.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: ICC visit 1/8/22  patient has been sick since yesterday, with  vomiting,diarrhoea , chills ( no fever )  headache, sore throat.ea ache  bodyaches, clear runny nose, dry cough, SOB,  has asthma Mom  states she is exposed to COVID-19 and patient wants to get tested for COVID -19    1/14/22  ED note:Presented due to tender nodules on bilateral arms. Patient developed COVID symptoms 1/7 and tested positive the next day. She received sotrovimav 1/9 with improvement in symptoms two days later; however, two days ago, she developed a sharp pain in the right AC and realized there was a nodule there. She also developed nausea, vomiting, decreased PO intake, abdominal pain, and orange urine. She has been treating with zofran, tylenol, and motrin at home. She then developed a second nodule on her L forearm yesterday and a third nodule on her L AC this AM. ID and pharmacy were contacted yesterday but have not heard of nodules occurring with sotrovimav infusions. Of note, IV for infusion was in the right hand. No hx of blood clots but patient on birth control.   On exam, nodules are tender to palpation (clinical photography in chart). She complains of right sided abdominal pain but abdomen soft. No lymphadenopathy. No fever since initial COVID symptoms began prior to infusion.
