RM AFTER U      1/17/22-dischaHospital Course (by problem): Thrombophlebitis On admission, she had a exquisitely tender nodules without overlying erythema or rash in the superior aspect of the right antecubital fossa, left antecubital fossa, and anterior aspect of left forearm. The left forearm nodule had a hyperpigmented streak starting at the nodule and extending toward the hand. Her differential included nodular lymphangitis felt less likely due to lack of exposures and BL findings, new viral infection such as EBV, CMV, complications of the COVID itself or a reaction to her Sotrovimab. A Hepatitis panel was negative and EBV and CMV titers were sent and serial CMPs were ordered. She was initially just admitted on motrin prn with her home medications, PO ad lib and MIVFs. Infectious Disease and Heme Onc were consulted. By the next morning, her physical exam was notable for an ""L"" shaped hyperpigmented, painful lesion on the left forearm and this and her other lesions seemed more hard and cord like more so than mobile nodules or lymph nodes. Given this and the fact that she had multiple risk factors for increase risk of clotting (lupus anticoagulant, obesity, birth control, acute COVID-19 infection, and venous stasis), physical exam findings were felt to be most consistent with superficial thrombophlebitis. Pediatric ID and Heme/Onc agreed. A hypercoagulable work-up was initiated and she was started on Lovenox 40mg BID (prophylactic dose) for at least 2 weeks, stopping her estrogen-containing birth control during this time. She did develop some posterior calf and BL foot pain with a cord over her R foot and BL foot hyperpigmented streaking but these rapidly resolved and her UE lesions greatly improved. She'd also remained afebrile in house and repeat BL LE doppler was also again negative. By the day of discharge she had only some improving L forearm pain with improved TTP and discoloration and only mild BL AC TTP with minimal remaining masses with superficial changes.  Heme Onc thus did not feel she needed increased to therapeutic dosing or Anti-Xa levels. Her mother, pharmacy, ID and Heme Onc were all okay with discharge to home. Her mother, already familiar with giving her sister injections for eczema, was easily able to take over her Lovenox injection in house and voiced comfort with doing so at home. She was then sent home in good condition. Her d-dimer was only mildly elevated at 612 and her homocyteine and ATIII had resulted as nml with Prothrombin, Factor V Leiden, Lipoprotein A, Pro C and Pro S as well as her EBV and CMV titers all still pending at the time of discharge.  She will be followed up in 2 weeks at Hematology and ID. The length of her Lovenox and hold on OCPs will be readdressed at that time.   Transaminitis with hyperbili and mild hypoalbuminemia on RUQ Pain, N/V, poor PO On admission, Hepatitis panel was normal and EBV/CMV testing were still in process at the time of discharge. Transaminitis was felt to be secondary to viral infection versus regular tylenol use during her COVID-19 infection versus COVID-19 itself. Throughout admission, CMP were trended. Her bili normlized, her alb dipped to 3.3 but was back up to 3.7 and AST and ALT downtrended to 82 and 526 respectively. Her RUQ tenderness improved some and then stabilized, her N/V resolved and her oral intake improved. She will continue to avoid tylenol (and motrin given her Lovenox) and needs another repeat CMP on 1/19/22 to continue to follow.   Mild Hyperchloremic Acidosis on Dehydration Her Cl- bumped to 115 likely from her IVFs with a likely related mild acidosis to 19. Ketosis and her dehydration may have played roles as well. Her UOP normalized and her PO intake improved as above. She was off IVFs by HD#2. Her Cl and HCO3 improved to stable at 110 and 18 on last checks.    Abnormal urine Her nurse noted some possible urine sediment on the night prior to d/c. Her UA was abnormal with moderate LE, 4 WBCs and trace bacteria but as she was not having any symptoms of a UTI this was not cultured. Repeat UA by her PMD is recommended. Of note her urobili was negative and her orange urine color change had resolved however as expect as her her hyperbili resolved and with hydration. All_symptoms: Abdominal pain Appendicolith Brain natriuretic peptide normal C-reactive protein increased Chromaturia
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient is a 9 yo boy history of premature birth, otherwise previously well, now admitted with febrile illness associated with abdominal pain, vomiting and diarrhea, and with elevated inflammatory markers, suspected MIS-C.  On 12/16 he developed headache.  He was otherwise well, though the following day he again had headache, and developed abdominal pain and body aches.  Symptoms worsened on 12/18 and he developed fever.  12/19 he was seen by PMD with worsening symptoms.  Rapid strep, COVID, and flu all negative.  The following day he developed higher fever, worse abdominal pain and body aches, and developed profuse watery diarrhea and persistent emesis with any PO intake.  Returned to PMD on 12/21 (yesterday). Repeat rapid strep positive, COVID negative.  Referred to ER for evaluation.  He has not been able to tolerate PO intake since start of emesis on 12/20.  He has had a dramatic decrease in activity and remains very listless.  He has not had significant cough or congestion.  He is noted to have swollen eyes with conjunctival injection today.  He has been complaining of a sensation of fullness in his throat described as ""lumps"".  No noted adenopathy.  Although he is achy all over, the pain is most intense left side of neck.  His urine looks darker today.  A few weeks ago he did have a single dry patch of skin on one leg.  That has since resolved with a moisturizer.  No other rash.  No extremity swelling.  He has not had a recent febrile illness.  He does say his taste is off during the current illness, though no prior loss of taste or smell.  He has had intermittent URI symptoms over the past few months, though nothing out of the ordinary.  All systems negative other than as noted.  His parents had COVID early in the pandemic in February and March of 2020.  His sister who lives with the family had COVID in 9/2021.  Patient was negative at the time.  His parents do note that they receive notice from the school regularly that there have been COVID cases.  Patient is in-person school.   In the ER yesterday he was febrile and tachycardic.  Labs with left shift on WBC, lymphopenia, borderline low platelets, markedly elevated CRP.  Urinalysis had mild pyuria and hematuria, negative LE and nitrite.  COVID antibody was positive, PCR negative.  CTA showed appendicolith but no acute abnormality.  Admitted inpatient on ceftriaxone.  Ferritin and D-dimer added today markedly elevated.  BNP and troponin normal.   PMH - Born at 27 weeks gestation.  He was followed by cardiology and ophthalmology for the first year of his life, but has since been cleared by both services.  Otherwise previously well. Allergies - NKDA Immunizations UTD including dose 1 of COVID on 12/3.

All_symptoms: Adrenal insufficiency Adrenocortical insufficiency acute Blood bicarbonate decreased Blood culture negative Blood glucose decreased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On 1/28 developed sore throat and headache.  Saturday during the day slept throughout and has been fatigued.  On 1/29 spiked a fever of 102 and did not want to move due to head feeling heavy.  As mom was waking him up he was going back to sleep.  He had 2 episodes of watery diarrhea as well as of vomiting.  He was drinking 20 ounces of water over the course of the day but had decreased p.o. intake.  In the ED on 1/30 glucose was found to be 18 with a CRP of 7.2, CBC showed a WBC of 14.42.  CMP remarkable for glucose of 10, hyponatremia and bicarb of 14.  Normal kidney and liver function.  Covid flu RSV negative.  He was given IV bolus and was started on D5 NS after which glucose had normalized.  He was admitted to main campus for further work-up.  Due to concern for sepsis blood culture was obtained which he received IV vancomycin and ceftriaxone and given blood culture negative antibiotics were stopped.  Have not been having any fevers, vomiting or diarrhea while at the hospital. Lab work evident for CRP of 7.2 on admission, proBNP of 510.  Since then his CRP is now 1.9 but proBNP had increased to 2979. Cardiac echo obtained and normal.  Diagnosis is adrenal insufficiency/crisis that may have been precipitated by viral gastroenteritis.  Since admission, he has not had any fevers and has improved with respect to diarrhea and vomiting.  Activity is almost back to baseline.  Given initial concern for MISC upon admission with mildly elevated inflammatory markers with CRP of 7.2, and proBNP of 510.  Cardiac echo was obtained and was normal.  Currently CRP is downtrending and is now 1.7 but proBNP increased to 2 2979 and D-dimers are 2200 and IL-6 was found to be 84.3.

He was referred to hematology at local Hospital where he had additional blood work including ANA, Anti-platelet antibody, and a comprehensive workup. They determined there was no other cause of the low platelets and told parents it is likely related to the vaccine. As of 2/1/22, platelet count has not recovered.

All_symptoms: Confusional state Fall Generalised tonic-clonic seizure Head injury Lethargy
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Post-immunization, within a few minutes of administration, client fell forward out of chair, hit head, and had a tonic-clonic seizure lasting approximately 5 seconds. He resumed consciousness, and remained in confused, lethargic postictal state, with stable vital signs, until EMS arrived and transported him to the emergency room. Mother called later that afternoon to report that client was discharged from the ER, remained lethargic, but had not had any subsequent seizure activity at the time of the phone call.

All_symptoms: Feeling hot Nausea Seizure Syncope
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient fainted shortly after his brother but he clenched up and told his mom and she was able to catch him so he did not hit his head on the floor. His parents were able to lay him on the floor where we used an ice pack and wet towels to cool him down since he felt very hot. He drank a bottle of water and his brother got him a sprite. He was not interested in crackers. Shortly after he got up from the floor to the chair, he stared straight ahead and started to have a seizure briefly with his parents holding on to him. He was finally able to speak a few seconds later and we laid him on the floor on his side in case a second seizure happened to prevent any aspiration. EMS was contacted and they arrived to assess his vitals and he began feeling nauseas. He was taken by stretcher to the hospital to be assessed there.
LAB_DATA: Hospital performed tests to monitor his vitals and heart function on 2/4

All_symptoms: Concussion Echocardiogram Electrocardiogram ambulatory Head injury Heart rate
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Passed out cold; Hit her head; Concussion/ concussion symptoms of headache and dizziness; Irregular heart beat rate, some irregularities; This is a spontaneous report received from contactable reporter (a nurse, although she is not currently working as a nurse). The reporter is the parent (patient's mother).  A 15 year-old female patient received BNT162b2, administered in arm left, administration date 21Aug2021 (Lot number: FC3182) at the age of 14 years as dose 2, single and administered in arm left, administration date 31Jul2021 (Lot number: FA7484) as dose 1, single for COVID-19 immunisation. The patient had no relevant medical history. The patient had no family medical history relevant to adverse events. There were no concomitant medications. No additional vaccines was administered on same date of the pfizer suspect. No other vaccinations were used within four weeks prior to the first administration date of the suspect vaccines. Adverse events following prior vaccinations was none. The following information was reported: LOSS OF CONSCIOUSNESS (medically significant) with onset 14Nov2021, outcome ""recovered with sequelae"" (15Nov2021), described as ""Passed out cold""; HEAD INJURY (medically significant) with onset 14Nov2021, outcome ""recovered"" (Nov2021), described as ""Hit her head""; CONCUSSION (medically significant) with onset 14Nov2021, outcome ""recovered"" (Nov2021), described as ""Concussion/ concussion symptoms of headache and dizziness""; HEART RATE IRREGULAR (medically significant) with onset 14Nov2021, outcome ""recovered"" (15Nov2021), described as ""Irregular heart beat rate, some irregularities"". The events ""passed out cold"", ""hit her head"", ""concussion/ concussion symptoms of headache and dizziness"" and ""irregular heart beat rate, some irregularities"" were evaluated at the physician office visit and emergency room visit. The patient underwent the following laboratory tests and procedures: echocardiogram: (18Nov2021) normal, notes: Patient does not have congenital thing. Everything was fine with her valves; electrocardiogram ambulatory: (18Nov2021) normal, notes: For 48 hours starting 18Nov2021 through 20Nov2021. Patient's rhythm was back to normal sinus rhythm; heart rate: (14Nov2021) irregular. Clinical course: The patient passed out, completely passed out cold for about 2 minutes and hit her head. She had a concussion, irregular heart beat rate, some irregularities. At the time the patient passed out cold mother was talking to the patient. They were down in the basement, had just gone down there because she needed more drawer space; so mother was clearing out a dresser and handed the patient some stuff. While patient was standing there with mother in the basement patient quit talking, and mother looked at the patient and thought ""oh my God""; the patient's eyes were wide open and then the patient went down hard, complete loss of consciousness for about 2 minutes; when patient passed out cold patient hit her head on a wooden crate. Patient has never done that before, has never had any health issues. She had eaten, she was doing fine, she was healthy, she was a wrestler before COVID and all this stuff, events just happened out of the blue. Patient was seen in the emergency room on 14Nov2021 related to these events. She was not admitted to the hospital, was under observation; patient didn't even get a room, they had her in the triage room. The emergency room staff did not tell them that day that the patient had an irregular heart beat rate, some irregularities; when they went to the primary doctor's office for follow-up after these events that is when they were told that she had irregular heart beat rate, some irregularities, did not have a normal sinus rhythm on 14Nov2021; Because of that they wanted to make sure everything was fine with her valves so they performed an echocardiogram on 18Nov2021 and had patient wear a holter monitor for 48 hours starting 18Nov2021 through 20Nov2021. The echocardiogram was done just to rule out if she had a congenital thing which she does not; and the holter monitor just to make sure her rhythm was back to normal sinus rhythm which it was. Echocardiogram and holter monitor results were normal, she had normal sinus rhythm and everything was fine with her valves. By 15Nov2021 patient was fine although she still had a headache and dizziness; Headache was still ongoing on 17Nov2021; but mother reported patient recovered completely from the events of hit her head, concussion and concussion symptoms of headache and dizziness within a week or so of onset. She has not had any further events, after these. The case was serious. Causality of all events mother reported as unknown, there's a possibility but she is not sure. Mother reported that she does not know if these events are related to BNT162b2, but events have never happened before; and events did not occur right after she got BNT162b2 doses. During the patient's follow-up appointment at the primary doctor's office the patient saw the Physician Assistant and he did not think events were related to BNT162b2. The Physician Assistant said everything looked normal with the testing they did for patient.; Sender's Comments: Based on the current available information and the plausible drug-event temporal association, a possible contributory role of the suspect product BNT162B2 to the development of events LOSS OF CONSCIOUSNESS, HEAD INJURY, CONCUSSION, HEART RATE IRREGULAR cannot be excluded  The impact of this report on the benefit/risk profile of the Pfizer product is evaluated as part of Pfizer procedures for safety evaluation, including the review and analysis of aggregate data for adverse events. Any safety concern identified as part of this review, as well as any appropriate action in response, will be promptly notified to regulatory authorities, Ethics Committees, and Investigators, as appropriate

At that point, she became clammy and started to vomit. She also stated her head was hurting and felt tired. I grabbed a cool damp cloth and applied it to her forehead. I got water for her to sip. All_symptoms: COVID-19 Chest X-ray abnormal Cough Decreased appetite Human metapneumovirus test positive
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Hospitalized (1.29.22 - 2.1.22); COVID-19 positive (1.28.22); ED visit (1.28.22); fully vaccinated Admission Date: 1/29/2022  Discharge Date: 02/01/2022  DETAILS OF HOSPITAL STAY: Pneumonia [J18.9] HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient is a 5 y.o. female with no significant PMHx who was admitted for hypoxia secondary to pneumonia.  Patient presented to ED on 1/29 following a 4-day history of fever, cough and poor appetite. She was initially evaluated in the ED on 1/28 due to fever (T104F) but she was deemed stable for discharge. On 1/29, she was brought back to the ED for worsening symptoms. In the ED, patient noted to be hypoxic and started on 2L NC. CXR obtained in ED notable for bilateral perihilar and bibasilar patchy consolidations (R>L). COVID-19 PCR negative. 1x dose given for possible CAP. Patient admitted to the floors for further management.  While admitted to the floors, patient did continue to intermittently require supplemental O2 especially when asleep. She was switched from Ampicillin to Amoxicillin once PO intake had improved. A film array was obtained 1/31 from her previous nasal swab due to concerns for Mycoplasma. FA positive for COVID-19 and Metapneumovirus. Discussed with ID about positive result on similar swab that initially tested negative, and they recommended treating the result as a true positive. Patient received 1x dose of Decadron given need for supplemental O2 and COVID-19 illness. At time of discharge, patient was clinically stable and breathing comfortably on room air. Discussed with mom that she may continue to be intermittently tachypneic at home but we do not expect her to have increased work of breathing. She will need to take 3 more doses of Amoxicillin to complete a 5-day course of abx for her superimposed bacterial pneumonia. She will not need to continue on steroids. Return to care precautions provided to family. Patient discharged home in stable condition.

All_symptoms: Haematochezia Laboratory test normal Rectal haemorrhage Stool analysis normal

LAB_DATA: 01/29/22: Saw MD. MD took stool sample and performed unknown lab tests which ""turned out negative."" MD advised that patient take miralax and water. Bloody stools continued. 02/02/2022: Patient taken to Hospital ER by mother. Stool sample and rectal exam performed. Hemorrhoids ruled out as cause. GI Doc saw patient 02/08/2022, opted to not perform colonoscopy at this time. GI doctor had no further recommendations as bleeding had stopped at this time. At this point, unknown etiology to rectal bleeding.

All_symptoms: Autopsy Cardio-respiratory arrest Cyanosis Death Gastrointestinal disorder
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 8yo previously healthy boy. Mom had COVID around 1/5/22. As far as we know the boy did not have symptomatic covid during or after her illness. He was not seen in the clinic for covid, nor was his 12 yo brother. There was no communication with them about this other than mom called to reschedule their appt for the 2nd COVID vaccine on 1/5 b/c she herself had covid. (Both of the kids got the first dose of the vaccine on 12/17/22)  Both of the boys got the 2nd dose of Pfizer Covid vaccine at our clinic on 2/3/22.  Mom called in on 2/9 with what sounded like a gastroenteritis over the phone and Zofran was called in. Our nurse  documented well his GI bug history and that his UOP was good and to call back PRN any problems. The nurse  remembers talking to this mom and that she did not seem worried at all?.just needed an antiemetic called in for nausea and vomiting. Patient was not having fever or abdominal pain. That call was at 8:53 on Wednesday AM. We did not hear from them again about this.  The details now get incredibly hazy due to the trauma of the whole event. Sometime during the night on Thursday night 2/10/2022 (40 hours or so after their phone call) one of the parents found him blue and lifeless in his bed. (Do not know details of what made them go check on him). Was taken to the Hospital with a full code in process. They were able to get a pulse back a few times for a brief time, but then lost him in the ICU.   This family goes to church at the same church that one of our doctors  attends,. This doctor  got a notification on the  morning of 2/11/2022 that a member in the church had died. The word that she received was that the boy had died of MIS-C (we do not know what exactly they were basing that on or who made that determination/speculation). My partner  called me 2/11/2022 AM about it since the boy is my patient. I looked through the chart and talked with my nurse  who specifically remembered the call and how completely unworried and normal  the mother seemed about the boys illness?.not in an unusual way but in a normal ?my kid has a GI bug, can you call in some zofran? kind of way. I called mom to reach out to her, but had to leave a voice mail (not surprisingly under the circumstances).  There are obviously lots of details about the history/presentation/treatment that I don?t  know. They may have sought medical care somewhere else other than our clinic before he became so significantly ill. I just don?t know since the family is in crisis mode and not returning calls or text messages. At present we don?t even know burial arrangements.
LAB_DATA: None by me, but plenty at ER/ICU?..I know they are doing an autopsy.

All_symptoms: Aphonia Cognitive disorder Conversion disorder Dyskinesia Fine motor skill dysfunction
SYMPTOM_TEXT: He collapsed and was hyperventilating. When he came around, he had all over paralysis. When his voice and upper body returned, his legs remained paralyzed. He was released from ER
LAB_DATA: He was at hospital initially. After all tests, there was nothing significant. After Neuro evaluated him, they thought he may have FND (Functional Neurological Disorder). He did rehab. He is now enrolled in Pain Clinic. He has some function in the right leg but the left leg continues to have paralysis. He has been removed from school because he is experiencing memory and cognitive issues. As well as other FND related things such as fine motor skill issues and uncontrolled movement of the fingers and eyelids.

All_symptoms: Fatigue Headache Hypoaesthesia Malaise Migraine
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 1st event- he came home at about noon from school the day following his vaccination with a terrible headache and very pale and feeling nauseous. Once he got home he started vomiting and I gave him some Zofran. I had also stocked up on Gatorade and saltines just in case, but he was unable to eat or drink those. He threw up until 8-9PM until he fell asleep. Threw up about 30 times and had an absolute awful headache the entire time. When he woke up in the morning on 01/29/2022, he felt tired but fine. 2nd event- took place on 02/09/2022. The school called at about noon and said that he had a terrible headache and wasn't feeling well so I went and picked him up. When I got him home, it was the same thing, terrible headache, pale and feeling nauseous. He threw up pretty much nonstop until 5PM. He had some vision issues, numbness in his left hand. I called the doctor earlier in the day and asked if it would be okay to give him Zofran again and they said it should be okay. I also called hospital later and asked what I should be doing, and they said I should bring him in. At that point, his vision was okay but he was on the ground in pain because of the headache and I couldn't get him to stop vomiting even with the Zofran. So that's when I took him to hospital. Once we got there, they said he needed to go to the ER and quickly start an IV for fluids, head pain and nausea. We were there until 10PM administering that and he missed school the following day as well with a relatively mild headache and exhaustion.
LAB_DATA: Hospital indicated that it appeared to be a migraine.

All_symptoms: Aphasia Blood test Breath holding Chest discomfort Condition aggravated
SYMPTOM_TEXT: The patient has asthma. Thursday September 9 she thought she was having an asthma attack because she couldn't breathe and her chest was tight. She had no response to the rescue inhaler and she was taken to the hospital via ambulance to get steroids and was sent home. 24 hours later she fell to the floor and grabbed her chest and said she was having a heart attack. Her jaw was locked open and she couldn't speak. She was taken to the hospital via ambulance. Admitted to the hospital via ER. She was severely tachycardic and above 170. After 24 hours of having heart/breathing attacks in the hospital, she was transported to another hospital via ambulance due to her congenital heart defect. Upon arriving her attackes continued every 27-30 minutes. Her symptoms then attacked her limbs. Her right leg shot up in the air in a 90 degree angle and convulsed uncontrollably for 40 minutes. That happened for 24 hours. Her foot and hands would lock up in spasms. Throughout these five days in the hospital, she would become unconscience from 2 to 60 minutes.
LAB_DATA: EKG, Brain MRI, Blood work.
HISTORY: Congenital Heart Defect, anomolous right coronary artery

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Mother of patient called and stated that her son received the Pfizer booster at our pharmacy on 1/8/22 (over a month ago). She stated that after out 12 hours after the vaccine, he experience 100.4 fever and started having high pulse rate of 200 (taken with home oximeter). She then took him to the ER, where they assessed him and gave him IBU and Tylenol which brought his fever down and then his pulse went down. Dr's told mother that the reaction to the vaccine his normal and he is ok. They did run labs and saw elevated liver enzymes level and when they did an ultrasound found that his liver was enlarged, but told mother that can happen with an immune response. She has consulted with a cardiologist and an allergist whom both said that he is ok.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: On 1/10/22 Patient had axillary lymphadenopathy and was evaluated by Dr.  Her chest pain started around this timse as well. Around Jan 26 she had redness and swelling of her hands that lasted several days and then resolved for about a week and then recurred again on 2/5/22 -~ 2/14/22.  Her chest pain worsened and she was evaluated on 2.9/22 and found to have ventricular bigeminy.  She was admitted to hospital.  She was on telemetry which showed persistent ventricular bigeminy. She is scheduled for an outpt holter.

All_symptoms: Acute respiratory failure Angiogram pulmonary normal Anticoagulant therapy Aspiration Blood culture positive
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Brief HPI: Patient is a 13-year-old girl with complex PMH significant for kabuki syndrome, moderate/severe mitral valve stenosis, C VID on home IgG infusions, s/p liver transplant in 2017 and immunosuppressed, ESRD on MWF HD, steroid-induced diabetes, HTN, and ILD with home oxygen requirement of 0.5 L who presented in the setting of tachycardia and increased home oxygen requirements and with known COVID-19 infection.    She presented on 1/26 after 1 week of symptoms of myalgias and cough and having already tested positive for COVID-19 on 1/24/2022.  She has home oxygen needs 0.5 L by nasal cannula but had increased needs up to 1 L by nasal cannula.  At her dialysis prior to admission she was tachycardic and increased respiratory support she will pursue further evaluation in the ED.  She was initially fluid resuscitated but given her mitral stenosis this was stopped given concern for worsening interstitial fluid on chest x-ray.  She was started on maintenance fluids.  Empirically started on meropenem with concern for sepsis.  Laboratory studies showed leukopenia of 3.3, pro-Cal 1.9 and CRP at 19.8.  She was initially admitted to C4 for further management.   She fired sepsis alert on the floor.  At 0430 on 1/27 she had an aspiration event related to trying to drink while coughing.  She desaturated to the 60s with this episode.  She was noted to have increased work of breathing and higher oxygen needs and the decision was made to admit her to the PICU for high flow nasal cannula support.   Brief PICU course:   Respiratory: She was admitted to the PICU on HFNC 25 L at 60% FiO2.  Initially, she was tachypneic in the high 40s-low 50s with accessory muscle use and bilateral coarse rhonchorous breath sounds bilaterally with occasional expiratory wheezing.  She was maintained on her pulmonary sick plan  and received treatment for COVID-19 pneumonia with remdesivir and dexamethasone.  She continued on empiric meropenem until blood cultures were negative >48 hours. We were able to wean from HFNC to NC on 1/29/22. On 2/1 she had acute and profound decompensation of her respiratory status with desaturations to 60%, minimally responsive to CPAP. Given level of respiratory distress, decision was made to intubate to allow for optimal lung recovery given severity of Covid pneumonia. Over the coming weeks she had progressively worsening compliance and progression of her respiratory failure, which acutely worsened on the evening of 2/13 into 2/14.  She developed subcutaneous air and pneumothoraces.  She had a right sided chest tube placed without improvement in ventilation.  Also attempted iNO without improvement in cardiac output or arterial saturations.  She was transitioned to the oscillator without success and she developed a new left sided pneumothorax.  The family had previously gave patient an altered code status after discussion with Dr.  Despite attempt to decompress her left pneumothorax, patient had progressive desaturation leading to bradycardia and hypotension. At that point we asked her family to be with her.  At 1158 on 2/14 she was pronounced deceased.     CV: Initially on arrival to PICU was maintaining reasonable indices of perfusion however did require inotropic support throughout course. Inotropic support was escalated with worsening compliance as high ventilatory pressures impeded output. On 2/7, patient had an acute event with worsening tachycardia and worsening mixed venous saturation. Sedation was increased and neuromuscular blockade performed with associated drops in NIRs. Bedside ECHO performed and notable for findings of new right sided atrial and ventricular dilation as well as decreased right sided function concerning for new pulmonary hypertension. Patient initially anticoagulated with heparin drip until stable for CTA which was ultimately negative for PE. A trial of iNO was also done without clinical improvement. During acute worsening on 2/14 and repeat ECHO was obtained and notable for similar findings, but not acutely worse.    FEN/GI: She was maintained on home feeding regimen upon arrival to PICU but required transition to NG feeds after intubation but enteral feeds were not tolerated well. Thus patient started TPN/IL to meet nutritional requirements while intubated. From a transplant perspective, patient's sirolimus levels were closely monitored while inpatient and necessary dose adjustments were made per hepatology recommendations. She continued on bowel regimen and scheduled zofran.    Renal: Patient was transitioned from hemodialysis to CRRT. She overall did well with this. Some concern that event on 2/7/22 was related to citrate lock, but patient tolerated transition back to citrate without further incidence.    ID: She received dexamethasone and remdesivir for Covid. Blood, urine and ETT cultures initially no growth to date. She was initially on meropenem for 48 hours for rule out of superimposed bacterial pneumonia and was discontinued with clinical improvement. However, upon intubation and respiratory support escalation, she was re-started on meropenem for suspected superimposed bacterial pneumonia. She was switched to Avycaz per ID and completed a 10 day course. Blood cultures were obtained during her acute worsening on 2/7/22 and ultimately grew enterococcus faecium. She was started on vancomycin. ETT also cultured at that time with polymicrobial growth. Decision made to not treat this growth unless clinically worsening. Patient was given a therapeutic dose of fluconazole on 2/14 due to worsening of respiratory status. She continued on her dapsone, valgancyclovir and fluconazole for her baseline infection prophylaxis.     Endocrine: She was aintained on stress dose steroids, hydrocortisone 50 mg 3 times daily.  Her home dose of prednisone 5 mg twice daily was held while on stress dose steroids. Also received dexamethasone 3.5 mg daily in the setting of her Covid pneumonia. She was transitioned to her home dose steroids on 2/11/22 with wean of hydrocortisone complete on 2/13/22. She also received one dose of stress dose steroids on the morning of 2/14 due to acute decompensation. She required an insulin drip while on stress dose steroids due to poor glycemic control.
HISTORY: Kabuki syndrmome s/p liver transplant End stage renal disease Intersitial lung disease with chronic cough Mitral valve stenosis

All_symptoms: Blood test normal Dizziness Dyspnoea Electrocardiogram normal Eye movement disorder
SYMPTOM_TEXT: She reacted to the first and 2nd vaccine the same. Bad headache, lightheaded. I gave her some Advil, she had a slight fever. Next morning she went to school but she called me to pick her up that she was really dizzy. She had a fever, headache, and dizzy spells that were stagnant and getting worse for the next couple of days. She began to projectile vomit and it was so strong I have never seen any of my kids vomit that way. She could not even breathe because it would not stop. Her eyes were rolling back, and it was just coming out. I took her to the ER room, and they took her right in. They claimed it was related to the vaccine. They gave her medication ondansetron, commonly known as Zofran. They were trying to get her to eat and she did not want to. Another doctor came in and did an EKG on her, they gave her an IV. They discharged her with Zofran and to remain on fluids.
LAB_DATA: EKG and blood work, nothing came out of it. Pregnancy test done that was negative.

All_symptoms: Alanine aminotransferase normal Aspartate aminotransferase normal Asthenia Blood creatine phosphokinase decreased Blood creatinine normal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Almost immediately after the vaccine on  1/23/2021, the patient started having what she described as little ""flutters"" on her L side (patient states she usually she gets them in her chest) this time on the  left side, almost like a ""strike"" = per patient like a painful electric shock down her side. Worsened and on 1/9/2022 taken to the ED. Exam there showed tenderness at mid sternum. XR was normal and an EKG was normal. In the ED, the patient reported the episodes stopped. Thought likely some component of costochondritis. Told to f/u with cardiology.   Seen by Cardiology;  on exam had reproduced left lower sternal border pain with palpation, no murmurs. EKG normal.  CXR was clear. Tested for COVID twice and negative, also flu negative.  Then after about a week she felt better and was cleared for physical activity. However, on 1/29/2022  during the second half of a field hockey game she began to ""not play right"", walking rather than running, experiencing vague dizziness and chest discomfort, and feeling as though her heart was beating kind of funny.  Over the next 20 minutes, these symptoms progressed. When she was taken out of the game to rest, she walked over to the shade because she was feeling weak and ""really hot"".  She was ""not walking right"", fell to the ground, but did not experience actual LOC, bodily injury, tongue biting or urinary incontinence.  She was picked up and placed on the nearby training table, where she remained awake but showed some delay in responding to questions.  Her mother noticed that she had perioral pallor at that time.  She was ultimately put in to an ambulance, and taken to the ED, where extensive testing was performed: negative thyroid function screen, D-dimer, sed rate, CRP, BNP, procalcitonin, CBC, BMP, total CK, and viral tests (Covid, flu, RSV). In addition, she had a negative chest x-ray and normal echocardiogram.  Initial serum troponin I was 0.09 ng/mL (upper limit of normal in that facility was 0.05 ng/mL) - trending showed drop in troponin to 0.03 and then <0.03 by the next morning.  She was observed in the ICU, and had a benign exam and ECG tracings.  It was recommended that she follow-up with cardiology after discharge. Afterwards she still continues to have symptoms of ""fluttering"" in her chest (longstanding), but to date no other symptoms.  A followup troponin and CRP on 2/14/2022 were normal.  Cardiology thoughts: Numerous published reports re: mild transient serum troponin elevation in exercising individuals, seems to reflect normal physiological response rather than pathological process. Considering evaluation for rare congenital coronary artery anomalies with chest CT angio.
LAB_DATA: 1/20/2022: CBC: WBC 8.7, hemoglobin 14.1, platelets 255, ANC 4600, ALC 3390 EBV antibody panel: Naïve (all antibodies less than 0.2) Covid?19 IgG spike protein antibody positive (recall history of both natural infection and vaccination) CMP: Creatinine 0.54, AST/ALT 20/13.    1/28/2022 ED during acute episode:  BNP: 19 (normal) ESR 2 (normal) Pro calcitonin less than 0.05 CRP less 1 CK 187 (normal) CBC: WBC 10.8 (slightly elevated), hemoglobin 12.7, platelets 314, ANC slightly elevated 6.7, ALC 3.4 BMP: Normal D-dimer: 241 normal   Troponin at 16:18: 0.09 (slightly elevated, facility test range for normal was 0?0 0.05) Troponin repeat at 22: 41: 0.03 normal   SARS?Covid 2/flu/RSV PCR not detected TSH 1.82 normal T4, free: 0.88 normal T3 free: 3.4 normal   1/29/2022:  Troponin 11:08: <0.03 normal  2/14/2022:  Troponin <0.010 (ref 0.000-0.034) CRP <0.1 (ref <0.5)
HISTORY: Patient has had chest symptoms beginning in 2018, including a sensation of her heart ""spinning"" or ""fluttering"" accompanied by chest discomfort and pressure. These lasted typically 5-7 seconds, terminating when she would bear down and hold her breath.  Patient is otherwise active and healthy female who participates in multiple sports (field hockey, basketball and lacrosse). She is followed by Cardiology; cardiac auscultation, EKG, stress test and echo have been normal. Multiple exams notable for reproducible left lower sternal border pain with palpation.

All_symptoms: Dizziness Eye inflammation Eye pain Fall Head injury
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Per the patient's mother, the patient became dizzy and must have blacked out, fell off the bench and hit the right side of her head on the ground. A loud ""thump"" was heard. The mother immediately picked up her child and witnesses stated the patient started to seize in her mother's arms. This occurred about 8 minutes after being vaccinated. As soon as I ran out, the patient had appeared to have stopped seizing. We laid her on the bench in a supine position. Patient stated her head was sore. No bleeding or inflammation of the area was present at the time. The vaccine was given around 12:32pm. A cold compress was applied to the right side of her head around 12:42pm. At this point, patient stated her head wasn't sore anymore so the compress was removed. Around 5 minutes later, patient stated her right eye was sore and it appeared to be turning red with a little inflammation forming so the cold compress was placed on her right eye. Patient stated the cold compress made it feel better. Management and EMS were alerted when the event had occurred. EMS had arrived approximately around 12:50pm and transported the patient to the hospital. Spoke with the mother an hour later and she stated patient is doing okay and is waiting to get released from the hospital.
LAB_DATA: None

All_symptoms: Dizziness Fall Head injury Headache Loss of consciousness
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient came in for pfizer covid booster with mother and sisters. Patient was vaccinated in right arm. After vaccination, patient was standing outside the booth with mother and sisters, while they were being counseled on possible side effects from vaccination. During the counseling (within 2-3 minutes) patient appeared woozy and passed out. Mother was able to help break her fall, but the patient did hit her head on the ground. Patient appeared un-responsive for less than a minute and came to. EMS was immediately called and patient remained on the ground until EMS arrived and evaluated her. Patient was given oxygen, complained her head was a little sore. Mother declined ambulance transport opted to take her to local hospital in her own vehicle for further evaluation.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient developed fever (101F), acute chest pain and was brought to care at the local ED.  He was found to have symptoms and labs consistent with myocarditis.  CXR/AXR WNL.  His peak troponin was 2.01 (occurring approximately 3d after the vaccine).  He had a normal echocardiogram and EKG.  Additional labs included a WBC count of 9, normal BNP, mildly elevated CRP at 2.5, and positive COVID-19 RNA.  Symptoms improved with ibuprofen provided orally.  Hospitalized overnight at a HCF for ongoing monitoring.  Discharged ~24h later with down-trending troponin of 0.68.
LAB_DATA: See above.

The nurse was new to giving vaccines in the first place; Some vaccine did not enter her arm/ Told my sister in law that my niece prob got 90% of the vaccine if she had to guess; When the nurse administered the vaccine to my 5yo niece, she jerked away, the needle bent and scratched my niece's arm; This is a spontaneous report from a contactable reporter (Consumer or other non HCP).   A 5-year-old female patient (not pregnant) received bnt162b2 (BNT162B2), intramuscular, administered in right arm, administration date 11Feb2022 at 16:00 (Lot number: unknown) at the age of 5 years as dose 1, single for COVID-19 immunisation. The patient's relevant medical history was not reported. There were no concomitant medications. The following information was reported: PRODUCT ADMINISTRATION ERROR (non-serious) with onset 11Feb2022 at 16:00, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""When the nurse administered the vaccine to my 5yo niece, she jerked away, the needle bent and scratched my niece's arm and some vaccine did not enter her arm. The nurse was new to giving vaccines in the first place""; INCORRECT DOSE ADMINISTERED (non-serious) with onset 11Feb2022 at 16:00, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""Some vaccine did not enter her arm/ Told my sister in law that my niece prob got 90% of the vaccine if she had to guess""; SCRATCH (non-serious) with onset 11Feb2022 at 16:00, outcome ""recovered"" (an unknown date in Feb2022), described as ""When the nurse administered the vaccine to my 5yo niece, she jerked away, the needle bent and scratched my niece's arm"". The event ""When the nurse administered the vaccine to my 5yo niece, she jerked away, the needle bent and scratched my niece's arm"" was evaluated at the emergency room visit. Therapeutic measures were not taken as a result of scratch.  Additional Information: The patient did not receive any other vaccines within four weeks prior to the COVID vaccine. Prior to vaccination, the patient was not diagnosed with COVID-19. It was reported that when the reporters sister in law asked if the patient needed to get another dose, the nurse did not know the answer and did not administer another one or refer her to anyone for the answer. Since the vaccination, it was unknown whether the patient had been tested for COVID-19.   The lot number for BNT162b2 was not provided and will be requested during follow up.

All_symptoms: Allergy test positive Erythema Hypersensitivity Oral discomfort Swelling
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 4 days after 1st Pfizer vaccine, was on vacation. Had hiked earlier that day at national park and had seen the sunset on that evening. While sitting at the table playing cards, had an allergic reaction of unknown origin. Child reported that her lips started to feel funny, then she began to develop hives on her face. Gave a Benadryl tablet and took immediately to ER (hospital was thankfully about 2 minutes away from our vacation rental). Epinephrine administered and then monitored at ER and an additional dose of Epinephrine then given. Hives, swelling and redness were throughout her whole body. About 4 hours after first dose of Epinephrine, many hives went away however some were still present so given additional dose by ER doctor. Initially was told vaccine reactions will only occur within 24 hours of vaccine and the only possible trigger they could think of was a brown tailed moth hair which apparently is in the vacation location. Now we have to carry around an EpiPen for her. No allergic reaction after 2nd Pfizer vaccine. Since, has become allergic to neosporin and today allergy testing showed she is now allergic to Polymyxin.
LAB_DATA: ER visit Epinephrine x2.
HISTORY: Glucose Transporter Type 1 Deficiency Syndrome, Scoliosis.

All_symptoms: COVID-19 Cardiomegaly Chest X-ray abnormal Conjunctivitis Cough
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Alerting VAERS of MIS-C occurring after post-COVID-19 vaccination. 11/22/21 - First COVID-19 vaccine; 11/25/21 - First COVID-19 positive antigen test; 12/1/21 - Second COVID-19 positive antigen test; 12/13/21 - Second COVID-19 vaccine; 12/31/21 - Symptoms of MIS-C began; 1/7/22 - Hospitalization for MIS-C; 1/7 - SARS-COV-2 nucleocapsid antibody IgG: positive. Upon admission, patient was fatigued with a mild cough and conjunctivitis. Initial evaluations were notable for elevated troponin and initial EKG and echocardiogram negative for cardiac dysfunction. For treatment of MIS-C, patient received IVIG, low-dose steroids, and aspirin therapy (following improvement of an initial thrombocytopenia). His IVIG infusion was complicated by development diffuse urticarial rash, fever, and supplemental oxygen requirement, consistent with an infusion reaction, with only a small portion of the dose remaining; he was treated with Benadryl and pulse steroids with improvement of symptoms. A chest x-ray the following day revealed an enlarged cardiac silhouette and increased pleural effusions, potentially due to MIS-c vs transfusion reaction. Patient received Lasix with subsequent improvement in his respiratory status. Patient's troponin levels continued to downtrend and patient completed three days of high-dose IV pulse steroids followed by repeat echocardiogram (most recent results detailed below) prior to discharge. He was discharge home with significant improvement in his clinical status with a steroid taper plan and cardiology follow-up.
LAB_DATA: 11/22/21 - First COVID vaccine; 11/25/21 - First COVID positive antigen test; 12/1/21 - Second COVID positive antigen test; 12/13/21 - Second COVID vaccine; 12/31/21 - Symptoms of MIS-C began; 1/7/22 - Hospitalization for MIS-C; 1/7 - SARS-COV-2 nucleocapsid antibody IgG: positive.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Chest pain, worsening over 2 - 3 days after his booster dose. Presented to ED, found to have elevated troponins. Admitted to the cardiology service.  Troponin peaked on 2/21/22. IVIG given on 2/21/22, and troponins have fallen since. Chest pain resolving. Hemodynamically stable with normal cardiac function by echo and cardiac MRI throughout observation in hospital.
LAB_DATA: 2/19/22: initial troponin 13.7 ng/mL, echocardiogram with normal biventricular function, no pericardial effusion, EKGs with ST segment elevation, anterior and lateral leads 2/20/22: max troponin 33.78 ng/mL, more diffuse ST segment elevation 2/21/22: peak troponin 43.27 ng/mL, repeat echo with normal function, no coronary artery dilation, received IVIG 2/22/22: troponin down-trending to 11.8 ng/mL 2/23/22: cardiac MRI with evidence of myocarditis, 25 - 50% of myocardium affected 2/24/22: troponin 1.85 ng/mL

All_symptoms: Chest pain Troponin increased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient is a 14 year old previously healthy male accompanied by his mother. He has a history of autism characterized by sensitivity to loud noises and largely non-verbal communication (can communicate verbally but often uses alternative modes of communication). No prior medical conditions. He received his second COVID vaccine 2 days ago on 2/22 (pfizer, second dose). He was in his baseline state of health until today at school when he started pointing to his chest. Due to chest pain, mother took him to the local emergency department. He was found to have an elevated troponin at 1.24 so was transferred to another HFC for further evaluation and management. Vitals remained stable on room air. Other than the chest pain, he has had no other symptoms. No fevers, shortness of breath, vomiting, diarrhea, rash, dizziness, syncope, cough, or URI symptoms. No recent ill contacts. No history of known COVID infection per database.
LAB_DATA: Elevated troponin (1.24)

All_symptoms: Lip swelling Periorbital swelling
SYMPTOM_TEXT: About one hour after the injection, child began to experience increasing periorbital swelling, followed by increasing swelling of her lips.  No rashes. No trouble breathing.  No wheezing on exam.  No fever.  No emesis.  No mental status changes.  Seen in the Emergency Department that same evening (Feb 23 PM), within hours of reaction onset,  treated with diphenhydramine, dexamethasone, and famotidine, then discharged home with Epi-Pen.  Telephone follow-up care by me the next day (Feb 24 PM), when mother reported less swelling around the eyes, no breathing concerns, and almost complete resolution of lip swelling.  Advised to continue anti-histamine treatment (with OTC non-sedating, long-acting loratadine or cetirizine at 10mg daily) until complete resolution of swelling.
LAB_DATA: None.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Day 1 (Friday 1/14/22) after shot #1 of Moderna  she had 4 bloody noses throughout the day and a swollen lip.  Day 2 (Sat 1/15/22)   after shot #1 of Moderna she had swelling and rash at injection site, which cleared up after 2 doses of Benadryl after consulting with on call physician.    4 days  later (Wed 1/19/22) after shot #1 Moderna she passed out at a team softball practice and was seen in the Emergency Room.   She received her 2nd  COVID vaccine on 2/26/22 and was advised by staff to get the age appropriate PHIZER vaccine as Moderna is not recommended for under 18 yrs of age.   She has had no adverse side effects to the PHIZER vaccine at the time of this report.
LAB_DATA: On 1/19/22 while at Emergency room, they ran blood tests and checked her urine and heart, all tests were normal providing us with no explanation of the 'fainting episode' at her team practice.

All_symptoms: Blood glucose normal Electrocardiogram normal Eye movement disorder Fall Full blood count
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 2 minutes after receiving her COVID vaccine, per Dad, patient screamed, said her arm really hurt, fell back onto the exam table where she had been sitting with eyes rolled upwards and peed herself. MA and I were in the room within 30 seconds. Patient was unresponsive and staring straight up at the ceiling. SpO2 99%, HR 110s. After 10 seconds of tactile stimulation and talking to her, patient became responsive. Was very slow to respond but said her name. Was unable to state her age, where she was, or who her Dad was. BP 90s/60s. POC glucose 80. After 5 minutes, was able to respond more with the names of her siblings and who she lived with at home but still not back to baseline.   Sent to ED, labs done and pediatric neurology consulted. Thought to be most likely vasovagal syncope. Was back to baseline.
LAB_DATA: 2/24/22: CBC, BMP, EKG normal

All_symptoms: Acute pulmonary oedema Cardiac dysfunction Cardiac imaging procedure abnormal Cardio-respiratory arrest Catheterisation cardiac abnormal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient had symptoms of COVID January 14th but was never tested. He received his 2nd dose of vaccine on January 29th. Patient had no issued until 2/9 when he collapsed in gym class while running and was brought to the emergency room. He went into flash pulmonary edema and then coded with low cardiac function seen on bedside ECHO. He was placed on ECMO and started on epinephrine and milrinone drips. He remained on ECMO for 7 days when he was decannulated. He went to a cardiac catheter procedure which showed left main coronary artery narrowing and cardiac MRI showed possible transmural infarct .  He was transferred to another hospital and is still inpatient pending possible LVAD or heart transplant.
LAB_DATA: EBV IgG (+) - 2/9 CMV IgG (+) - 2/9 Rapid COVID test (-) 2/9 COVID nucleocapsid IG (+) 2/10

All_symptoms: Arrhythmia Cardiac arrest Chest pain Cytogenetic analysis Fatigue
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Initial first injection muscle soreness. Within a week post 2nd injection, my son complained of jaw pain and sinus pressure. We took him to the doctor, he was treated for sinus infection and took sudafed OTC meds. He has taken these before for years with sinus pressure. Some chest pain and fatigue developed. He thought the chest pain was due to working out. On July 19, he suffered major cardiac arrest while at a friends home. CPR was started until EMT arrived. He had to be revived 3x and was transported via helicopter to hospital where he remained for 10 days. No Myocarditis or Pericarditis but he was ruled to have an arrythmia. On July 29, he had a defibrillator installed - he is 14 years old. No prior signs of ANY heart issues and all genetic tests to date have come back with NO trace of what he suffered being present in a gene abnormality. We are still awaiting 2nd set of genes to return, but told not likely anything will be present. He was initially treated by Dr. at hospital. He is now with a new Dr. for any ongoing care. I have written to Pfizer and also CDC - I received a response 8 months ago, provided medical records and never heard back with 4 follow ups sent since. We just would like to know what happened to our son and truly believe in our hearts that this could be a reaction to the vaccine.
LAB_DATA: I can provide all medical records as requested. It's pages of input.

All_symptoms: Abdominal pain Blood fibrinogen increased Brain natriuretic peptide increased C-reactive protein increased Chest X-ray normal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Case-patient had first Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine on 12/7/21, developed MIS-C symptoms on 1/5/2022, and received second Pfizer vaccine on 1/7/22.  Case reported having an undiagnosed upper respiratory infection in late December/early January (specific date unknown).  Case-patient met case definition for MIS-C, with evidence of clinically severe illness requiring hospitalization, fever, multisystem organ involvement (cardiac, hematologic, and GI).  The case-patient experienced tachycardia, headaches, abdominal pain, vomiting, and various elevated inflammatory markers (see box 19 below).  Case-patient was treated with IVIG, ASA, and steroids and survived after a 2 day hospitalization.
LAB_DATA: COVID-19 Ab Nucleocapsid positive (1/29/22), elevated inflammatory markers (1/28-1/30/22): Fibrinogen - 471 mg/dL, CRP - 5 mg/dL, Troponin - 26 pg/mL, BNP - 271 pg/mL, see cont. page D-dimer: 0.68 mg/L FEU.  Chest X-ray and echocardiogram were unremarkable.

All_symptoms: Back pain Chest discomfort Chest pain Costochondritis Echocardiogram
SYMPTOM_TEXT: About 15 minutes after 2nd Pfizer dose was injected into my daughter's left arm (upper), she experienced sharp pain near her sternum and ribs near her sternum. She's never experienced this before.  - The nurse at the doctors office administered a max ibuprofen dose.  - Pain radiated around ribs to her back.  - Dr  performed an examination at 4:45 pm and found sore areas in the ribs, but heart rate seemed normal. -Pain in ribs near her sternum was sporadic and she felt ""tiredness"" at the front of her chest walking to school the next morning.  - Per advice from doctors office where she received the injection,  - I took her to the emergency room Hospital. - Pain occurred with and without physical activity (activity limited to walking with some stairs)
LAB_DATA: At Hospital ER - Rapid strep test (Strep A - my daughter had sore throat 36 hours before 2nd dose, nurse was notified) - EKG was normal - ER doctor also noted sore areas in the connective tissue in the ribs around the sternum - Costochronditis suspected - Root cause analysis unknown - Time proximity to vaccine a factor 8 day followup at cardiologiest: - normal EKG - normal ultradound of heart - Still residual soreness around ribs, noted by Cardiologist

All_symptoms: Arterial dolichoectasia COVID-19 Chest X-ray abnormal Computerised tomogram thorax abnormal Dyspnoea
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient tested positive for COVID on 1/22/2022. She developed fever, headache, sore throat, red eyes and rash on 02/04/2022. She was seen by primary MD and ultimately hospitalized from 02/09/2022 through 02/14/2022 at medical Center. She was diagnosed with MIS-C. She had abnormal echocardiogram on 02/10/2022 (small pericardial effusion, mild TR and MR, slight right coronary artery ectasia, SF 32.8). She was treated with IVIg, IV steroid and aspirin with good response. Patient develop shortness of breath and oxygen requirement on 02/12/2022. CXR and CT of chest done showing bilateral pleural effusions. Repeat echocardiogram done on 12/12/2022. Repeat echocardiogram on 02/12/2022 was stable compared to 12/10/2022. Patient transferred to pediatric ICU on 02/12/2022 where she was treated with hi-flo oxygen and Lasix with improvement. Transferred back to general pediatric unit on 02/13/2022 and discharged home on 02/14/2022 on oral steroid taper and aspirin, in good condition. Repeat echocardiogram done on 02/14/2022 showed some improvement. She was to follow up with pediatric rhematologist, PMD and pediatric cardiologist as outpatient.

A 12-year-old female patient (not pregnant) received bnt162b2 (BNT162B2), intramuscular, administered in arm left, administration date 07Nov2021 17:30 (Lot number: 3230BD) at the age of 12 years as dose 1, single for covid-19 immunisation. The patient had no relevant medical history. The patient's concomitant medications were not reported. The following information was reported: HEART RATE INCREASED (non-serious), PALPITATIONS (non-serious) all with onset 28Nov2021 19:00, outcome ""not recovered"" and all described as ""Rapid beating and pounding of the heart""; CHILLS (non-serious) with onset 28Nov2021 19:00, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""chills""; DYSPNOEA (non-serious) with onset 28Nov2021 19:00, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""loss of breath/difficulty to breath""; PANIC ATTACK (non-serious) with onset 06Dec2021, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""Panic attacks""; ANXIETY (non-serious) with onset 06Dec2021, outcome ""not recovered"", described as ""anxiety attacks""; CHEST DISCOMFORT (non-serious), outcome ""unknown"", described as ""tight chest"". The events ""rapid beating and pounding of the heart"", ""rapid beating and pounding of the heart"", ""panic attacks"" and ""anxiety attacks"" were evaluated at the physician office visit and emergency room visit. Relevant laboratory tests and procedures are available in the appropriate section. Therapeutic measures were not taken as a result of heart rate increased, palpitations, chills, dyspnoea, panic attack.  Additional information: The patient did not receive any other vaccines within 4 weeks prior to the COVID vaccine. The patient was not tested since the vaccination. The patient was not diagnosed with COVID-19 prior to vaccination. On 06Dec2021, the patient had the first panic attack. She complained of a rapid heartbeat, tight chest, difficulty to breath. The following 2 days she had two more panic attacks between 6pm and 7pm which resulted in a visit to the emergency room on 08Dec2021. They did an EKG and XR chest single view test. That day they diagnosed that what had given her was an anxiety and panic attack and they recommended seeking therapy at a family center. The patient was a healthy girl and she had never suffered from any depression or seizures before. We think as a family that the vaccine affected her nervous system to the point of causing these panic attacks. We now have a huge hospital bill that we cannot pay and my daughter has anxiety attacks at least once a week.

All_symptoms: Blister Blood urine present Computerised tomogram Cytomegalovirus test negative Depressed mood
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 15 year old child presented very sick with high fever and red painful eyes. Fever was 103 for three days. No lowering. Condition worsened with headache, fever of 103.8, fatigue, and rash in vagina, thought to be from maxi pads.  Saw urgent care after virtual dr. appointment. Urgent care said it was viral or covid. I asked for urine test for UTI. Came back blood in urine, but not UTI. Refused Covid test as I had done three already that were negative. Sent home and said was viral. SHe got much worse so I called and asked for antibiotics. They called in and said if not improve call. I called after 2 days of no improvement and getting worse. The on call dr. suggested we go to hospital. After day6 of fever of 1 103.8 the er was very concerned. They suggested herpes or another STI. we were nortified. CHild was not sexually active and they said it did not matter. They tested for EBV, CMV and many others. so they called specialist OB GYN. She came and said it was Lipschutz Disease. They needed to wait for tests. She was in extreme pain and could not move. We were admitted and continued for 5 days. SHe was in extreme pain. They took pictures to document her recovery. She was sad and embarrassed. SHe mentally was struggling. COuldn't drink or eat out of fear of using the restroom. She was very ill and feared dying. She had blisters covering the inside and out. She had many doctors looking daily at her progress. She tested negative for all viruses that could have caused this including COVID-19. No antibodies. No EBV, CMV or Mono, or many others they tested. No flu. Her liver enzymes were high and her blood showed her body had inflamation. My child is still in extreme pain and suffering and can barely walk. Is afraid to use the bathroom and is struggling in school now.
LAB_DATA: CBC, Covid Antibodies, Covid, Flu, CMV, pneumonia, Complete panel, EBV, Herpes, HSV, CT Scan, STI

All_symptoms: Abdominal discomfort Bandaemia C-reactive protein increased Constipation Culture urine negative
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 10 y.o. female with PMHx of mild intermittent asthma and chronic constipation, presenting with vaginal ulcers accompanied by dysuria x1 day PTA, lower abdominal discomfort most likely secondary to chronic constipation, and fever and bandemia that have resolved since admission. Cause of vaginal ulcers and pain are continuing to be worked up with wide differential, with consults from gynecology and dermatology. Genecology workup was urgent priority to determine possibility of abuse, and have so far resulted negative for syphilis, HIV, HSV1/2 and VZV. GC/Chlamydia is still pending. Wound and urine cutlers are NGTD. RVP of swabbed ulcers is negative. Currently, there is lower suspicion of infectious origin due to negative results to date. Social work and child protection also following patient.  Of note, this patient received her COVID-19 vaccine shortly prior to presentation of fever and vaginal ulcers. A case report shown Lipschütz ulcer development in a 12 year old girl following COVID-19 vaccination, with more reports of patients developing Lipschütz ulcers following COVID-19 infection. Patient is COVID-negative as of 2/5/22.   Other potential causes of patient's current symptoms include vaginal foreign body, Crohn's, EBV- related Lipschütz ulcer, Behcet syndrome, and contact irritation from change in laundry detergent. There was concern for vaginal foreign body due to vaginal discharge and patient endorsing pain in the vagina, but internal pain is more likely secondary to chronic constipation x7 days. Patient will receive enema today and continue bowel regimen, will observe for symptom resolution. Internal vaginal exam deferred for now due to need for general anesthesia, gynecology will follow up. Foreign body is lower on differential as this would not explain vaginal ulcers. Crohn's can be associated with constipations, abdominal discomfort, and vaginal ulcers, so fecal calprotectin was sent. Awaiting EBV results as well.
LAB_DATA: crp elevated. fecal calprotectin

All_symptoms: C-reactive protein increased Chest discomfort Chest pain Echocardiogram normal Electrocardiogram ST segment elevation
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient had myalgias around 24 hours after vaccine, took some Tylenol that day.  On the second day after the vaccine, he had chest pressure (low grade).  He did not take anything for it, but woke up with worsening chest pain the following morning (3 days post vaccine).  He was taken via EMS to the ER at the Hospital and was found to have elevated inflammatory markers, elevated troponins, and ST changes on EKG (consistent with myocarditis/pericarditis).  He had an ECHO with normal function.  We followed his troponins until they declined (around 7 days post vaccine) and his chest pain resolved.  He was given scheduled ibuprofen during his stay here.  He had no hemodynamic instability or arrhythmias.

All_symptoms: Abdominal pain Abdominal tenderness Chills Decreased appetite Fatigue
SYMPTOM_TEXT: ""Patient is a 5 y.o. male who presents to the ED with abdominal pain. The patient received his COVID19 vaccine on Friday afternoon. Saturday morning, the patient developed fatigue, fevers, chills, aches, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and decreased appetite. The patient's max temperature was 102 measured at home by mom. Per mom, the patient has said he is hungry throughout yesterday and today, but will barely eat the food put out for him. He has well-controlled constipation at baseline and last had a BM earlier today. He has not had diarrhea. There is no one else sick in the household. He had no symptoms prior to the COVID vaccination.""  ""Patient was admitted to the Surgery service with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting in the setting of recently receiving the COVID19 vaccine. Given his symptoms, he was worked up for possible appendicitis; his appendiceal US was equivocal for appendicitis and his abdominal exam was benign. He was admitted for observation and serial abdominal exams. He did well with resolution of his abdominal pain and he was advanced to a general diet which he tolerated.    Overall, he did well and followed the expected course including resumption of a diet appropriate for age, return of bowel function and baseline activity.  His vital signs and temperature curve are within normal limits for age. Patient has met all criteria for discharge including tolerating a diet appropriate for age and ambulating with good pain control on oral pain medications.""

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis flare; Gastritis; stomach bug; COVID-19; COVID-19; This is a solicited report received from contactable reporter(s) (Consumer or other non HCP) for a sponsored program. Other Case identifier(s): 22K-163-4279910-00 (Agency).  A 8 year-old female patient received bnt162b2 (BNT162B2, Solution for injection), intramuscular, administration date 19Dec2021 (Batch/Lot number: unknown) at the age of 8 years as dose 2 (tris), single and intramuscular, administration date 2021 (Batch/Lot number: unknown) as dose 1 (tris), single for covid-19 immunisation; adalimumab (HUMIRA, Solution for injection in pre-filled pen), first regimen subcutaneous (Batch/Lot number: unknown) till Dec2021 and second regimen subcutaneous from 10Feb2022 (Batch/Lot number: unknown) to 10Feb2022 for juvenile idiopathic arthritis. The patient's relevant medical history and concomitant medications were not reported. The following information was reported: DRUG INEFFECTIVE (medically significant), COVID-19 (medically significant) all with onset 22Dec2021, outcome ""recovered"" and all described as ""COVID-19""; JUVENILE IDIOPATHIC ARTHRITIS (hospitalization, medically significant) with onset 2022, outcome ""unknown"", described as ""Juvenile idiopathic arthritis flare""; GASTRITIS (non-serious) with onset 2022, outcome ""recovered"" (2022), described as ""Gastritis""; GASTRIC INFECTION (non-serious) with onset 2022, outcome ""recovered"" (2022), described as ""stomach bug"". The events ""gastritis"" and ""stomach bug"" were evaluated at the emergency room visit. The patient underwent the following laboratory tests and procedures: laboratory test: (unspecified date) stomach bug; sars-cov-2 test: (22Dec2021) positive. The action taken for adalimumab was dosage permanently withdrawn on 10Feb2022.  The reporter considered ""covid-19"", ""juvenile idiopathic arthritis flare"", ""gastritis"" and ""stomach bug"" related to bnt162b2.  Clinical course: The patient reported she had her second Covid-19 shot on 19Dec2021, first Covid-19 shot on an unknown date in 2021. However, on 22Dec2021 she was tested and results came back positive for Covid-19 felt and parents decided to skip Humira dose until she got better. She ended up receiving her Humira dose on 10Feb2022 after having Covid-19 and being hospitalized over the weekend from a flare up. She was taken to the emergency room and was there for a weekend due to severe diarrhea, gastritis, and unable to keep anything in. After several test it ended up being a stomach bug. It was unknown if patient was enrolled in a Covid-19 Vaccine Trial. Causality for Humira (Adalimumab): The reporter's causality for the events of Gastritis, stomach bug and polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis flare was not provided; for the events of Covid-19 was no reasonable possibility. Agency's opinion is that there is no reasonable possibility that the events of gastritis, polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis flare and Covid-19. Agency's opinion is that there is a reasonable possibility that the event of stomach bug is related to Humira (Adalimumab). Causality for BNT162B2: The reporter's causality for the events of Gastritis, Gastric infection, Juvenile idiopathic arthritis flare, Covid-19 was Possible.  The lot number for bnt162b2 was not provided and will be requested during follow up.; Sender's Comments: As there is limited information in the case provided, the causal association between the reported events with the suspect drug BNT162B2 cannot be excluded. Note: The same reaction occurred when taking second dose of Pfizer COVID vaccine 6/28/21 and the third dose (booster) of Pfizer COVID vaccine 3/6/2022.   On  the second dose  6/28/21 the fire department\paramedics responded to Pharmacy and waited until she recovered her vision\sight\paleness\ability to stand and did not recommend that she needed to go to the hospital as she was recovering.      After a few months after the second dose she had 4 months of harsh stomach issues, headaches, nausea, vomiting.   Where ultra sounds, mri, endoscopy, blood tests were done and it was not conclusive what is causing this.
LAB_DATA: Tests not done since same occured on the second dose.  All the tests conducted then did not yield an answer. We need assistance from the CDC for similar cases and any added info.

All_symptoms: Asthenia Dizziness Hyperhidrosis Pallor
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient was accompanied by her mother to receive her covid booster vaccine.  Shortly after she received her vaccination (about 3 to 4 mins).  she started feeling dizzy and lightheaded.  She was sitting down when she felt weak and dizzy. Her skin turned to pale color. we immediately assist her to a laying down position and elevate her legs.  We call 911 right away and continue to monitor her pulse and breathing.  She was sweating a lot and she is alert.  We keep making conversation to her to make sure she did not lose consciousness. EMT arrived and took her vital sign outside and brought her to emergency room. Per patient's mother they stayed in emergency room for about an hour and got discharged. Patient was feeling better after returning to home.

All_symptoms: Cerebral disorder Computerised tomogram head normal Fatigue Gait disturbance Generalised tonic-clonic seizure
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Previously healthy 9 year old female with no history of seizures received the first dose of the COVID19 Pfizzer-Biontech vaccine on 1/19/2022. On 2/13/2022, she had a major tonic-clonic seizure at home while watching TV. She was admitted with status epilepticus to the Hospital and Medical Center on 2/13/2022. Although the seizure resolved, she continued to have paralysis and pain of her right lower extremity at discharge which was tentatively attributed to Todd's paralysis. On evaluation by rheumatology on 3/7/2022, she had persistent paresis and pain of her right lower extremity which interfered with ambulation.
LAB_DATA: She had a normal head CT at a local ED facility prior to transfer to hospital. Brain MRI with/without contrast on 2/14/2022 revealed abnormal signal in the left hippocampus with diffusion restriction. Repeat brain MRI with/without contrast on 3/11/2022 documented persistent of the T2 hyperintensity of the left hippocampus with resolution of diffusion restriction; no qualitative volume loss of the left hippocampus was identified, though these findings can precede the development of mesial temporal sclerosis.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: 9 yo girl developed MIS-C with fairly classic symptoms following dose #1 of COVID vaccine.  Had had COVID but 10+ weeks prior to onset of symptoms. All_symptoms: Adenovirus test Alanine aminotransferase normal Aspartate aminotransferase normal Basophil count normal Basophil percentage decreased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: ""Patient recently immunized with adult dose COVID booster on 3/8 and developed fever and chest 1 day after receiving vaccine. His T max was 101 over the past 48 hours. This AM, around 0300, patient woke with chest pain and feeling like something was stuck in his throat. He felt he could breathe normally (though ED note notes some difficulty with breathing when walking or doing stairs) and denied dizziness or other neurologic sensations. Due to persistence of chest and throat pressure, family called nursing line for his PCP who recommended ED evaluation. Mother notes she feels patient has been breathing faster.   No family history of bleeding/clotting disorder. Patient denied leg pain or calf swelling. Notes he has had a headache since his COVID booster and has otherwise been relatively active.   ED Course: Due to fever and chest pain after receiving COVID booster vaccine there was concern for post vaccine myocarditis. Troponin and NT pro BNP were elevated at 0.888 and 979. An EKG was performed and showed ST segment elevation and PR depression consistent with acute pericarditis. CXR without cardiomegaly. Cardiac ECHO showed Mild-moderately reduced LV function with LV dilation, trivial MR.  No effusion. Patient was given a dose of toradol and transferred to the hospital for further care. ""

All_symptoms: COVID-19 Cerebral mass effect Cerebral ventricle dilatation Computerised tomogram head abnormal Febrile convulsion
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 1/24/22: 14 days after dose 1 of Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine (1/10/22) child had first (one-time) seizure (unresponsive, shaking for 1 minute) followed by lethargy/postictal period of 12 hours.  Question if febrile in nature in ED as temperature not taken at home.  Non-febrile in ED with NBNB emesis x1.  CT  had 3 mm lef-to-right mid line shift (non-specific, given no mass/bleed/edema) and asymmetric enlargement of the left ventricle.  If preparing for CT, patient tested positive for COVID-19 on 1/24/22.  Father also tested positive for COVID-19 to transfer patient as did remainder of family over the next few days.  Patient tested negative (required by local law) on 2/4/22.  Ultimate diagnosis by primary physician was  febrile seizure.  2 week follow up was unremakable neurologically.  Plan to re-image in 3-6 months, unless second seizure occurs.
LAB_DATA: CT head without contrast.  COVID (positive), Flu A/B/RSV (negative).

All_symptoms: Anticoagulant therapy Blood culture positive Blood test Brain abscess Cerebral thrombosis
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Nine days after receiving the second dose of the Covid Vaccine, Patient developed severe headaches that were not relieved with any over the counter medication such as Tylenol, Ibuprofen, or Excedrin. He developed a fever a day later that would not stay down. The head ache became un bearable for him. After 3 trips to the ER, Dr office and another ER they finally ran blood cultures that diagnosed bacterial meningitis leading to a MRI which revealed a blood clot in the forehead area and a abscess in the right frontal lobe.  He was transported to the Hospital for surgery.  He was on Multiple IV antibiotics. He was also started on IV Heparin.  Eight days after the first procedure and IV antibiotic therapy the abscess had continued to  expand into the brain requiring a craniotomy.  He was then on IV antibiotics and blood thinners for an additional 7 weeks
LAB_DATA: Blood tests, Blood cultures, CT scans,  mult MRI between Oct 17, 2021 thru 12/17 2021 at multi health care facilities
