All_symptoms: Abdominal discomfort Blood test abnormal Cardiac disorder Chest X-ray normal Confusional state
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On 3/1/22 patient had stomach discomfort and muscle soreness/stiffness. On 3/2/22 muscle stiffness continued, especially in neck.  Began feeling fatigued around midday, took a 2 hour nap and awoke with fever.  On 3/3/22 symptoms continued and fever rose to 104.  Took him to walk-in urgent care where he tested negative for flu and covid and was sent home.  Vomited later that afternoon.  Also woke around 1:00 am with vomit/diarrhea.  Went back to sleep but when he awoke the morning of 3/4/22, rash was present on legs, buttocks, arms, and fever spiked to 106.  Returned to the same clinic and they admitted him to the ER side where they gave him fluids and performed more tests, all of which were negative.  Dr. decided to treat for strep and gave him antibiotics intravenously. Also prescribed antibiotics to continue at home (he was able to take 1 dose at home but wasn't able to keep subsequent dose down). He started feeling better that afternoon and was able to eat/drink a little, but had vomit/diarrhea again at bedtime. Woke around midnight with vomit/diarrhea and again on the morning of 3/5/22, so we took him to the ER at Hospital. Very dehydrated. Bloodwork showed high inflammation throughout entire body. High heart rate with low blood pressure. Chest x-ray and Echo looked normal. Doctor conversed throughout the day with the Infectious Disease Specialist at the Hospital, and they both felt like symptoms pointed to MIS-C.  They helicoptered him that night to the PICU in where doctors ran tests to rule out infection from meningitis, tick-related illness, etc. By 3/6/22 another Echo showed trouble with heart.  By that afternoon he was starting to show occasional mental confusion and mild hallucinations. Infection was ruled out, diagnosis of MIS-C confirmed, and they started IVIG treatment by 3/7/22 at which time symptoms began to slowly dissipate.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient developed Henoch-Schoenlein Purpura (HSP) on 1/27/22, beginning with myalgia/arthralgias 16 days after receiving his first COVID-19 vaccine. Family denies any recent/previous viral illnesses prior to onset HSP. Pt had appx 5-6 'waves' of HSP (typical course) with no sig renal involvement. Hospitalized overnight once for emesis/dehydration, experienced typical petechiae/purpura, arthralgias, abd pains but otherwise well.
LAB_DATA: Pt getting weekly UA/BP checks to monitor renal function during convalescence.

All_symptoms: Arthritis Back pain Blood test Computerised tomogram abdomen abnormal Echocardiogram
SYMPTOM_TEXT: My child developed MISC after receiving her first does of the Pfizer Covid vaccine. She was hospitalized for a week with severe symptoms. She received IVIG and steroid treatment at the hospital and is on daily aspirin for risk of blood clotting. Many of her organs were impacted and we have a long road to recovery.   Patient was admitted on 3/1/2022 with a high fever and abdominal inflammation evidenced by ultrasound and CT scans of her abdomen. She had tachycardia for days, had bloodshot eyes and a full body rash. She had severe back and neck pain and was unable to walk. She was weak in her extremities from joint and tendon inflammation. She was in a lot of pain as her body was trying to regulate the reaction to the Covid vaccine.
LAB_DATA: Ultrasound, CT scan, bloodwork, echocardiogram, ekg, urine and stool samples from 3/1/2022-3/6/2022

All_symptoms: C-reactive protein increased Dizziness Dyspnoea Fatigue Feeding disorder
SYMPTOM_TEXT: She came down with a virus on August 30, 2021 (27 days after Pfizer dose #1) which presented with fever, congestion, fatigue, sore throat and swollen glands through September 3rd. September 4-5 she seemed to be better, but then developed severe Urticaria on her feet, legs, torso and hands on September 6, 2021. Her feet, fingers and hands swelled and her fever returned. She developed dizziness and  shortness of breath so I took her to the ED on September 7, 2021. They sent us home with instructions for Benadryl, Ibuprofen and Oatmeal Baths which we'd already been doing, but this did nothing and she got progressively worse. She was unable to walk, eat or sleep. I took her back to the ED on September 8, 2021. This time they gave her prednisone and a stronger antihistamine and she was finally able to sleep. She was on a 6 day course of prednisone and her immune system finally calmed down and cleared the Urticaria, swelling and fever. We were told that it was a response to the virus she had, but she has never had anything like this happen before. The only variable was the Pfizer vaccine less than a month prior. Her immune system acted very differently and couldn't clear the histamines. She has never been that sick.
LAB_DATA: 9/7/21: Mono - negative 9/7/21: Covid - negative 9/7/21:  Neutrophils High / Lymphocytes Low 9/7/21:  CRP slightly elevated

All_symptoms: Abdominal distension Atelectasis Bladder catheterisation Blood pressure increased COVID-19
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient is 6 y.o. female with developmental delay, epilepsy (on ketogenic diet and multiple AEDs), neurogenic bladder with suprapubic catheter in place who is admitted to the PICU due to presumed septic shock and altered mental status.    Patient developed URI symptoms on day prior to presentation with subsequent development of fever and emesis today. Mother was concerned for subclinical seizures given that patient was not as active as she normally is, so administered rescue dose of ativan. Due to persistent fever and lethargy, was brought to ED for evaluation.    In the ED she was febrile and tachycardic. Labs obtained and significant for film array positive for human metapneumovirus. Procal elevated to 0.54 and UA with large LE and 46 WBCs, although this is baseline compared to previous urinalyses. Blood pressure trended down over the course of the ED stay, requiring 3 NS boluses without significant improvement. Admitted to the PICU for further monitoring.    Evaluated upon arrival to PICU. Responds appropriately to stimuli, then falls back asleep. Pupils reactive. Extremities warm and well perfused, cap refill 2-3 seconds. Abdomen soft; suprapubic catheter in place; Contractures of extremities present.     Requires admission to the PICU due to hemodynamic instability from presumed shock and possible subclinical seizure activity.    Plan as follows:    Neuro:   - NCC consulted  - Will place EEG  - Ativan bridge while NPO     CV:  - MAP goal > 55   RS: - 2L NC     FEN/GI:  - ketogenic diet  - NS IVFs  - NPO  - monitor glucoses    ID:  - blood and urine cultures pending  - Ceftazidime  Patient is a 6 y.o. 4 m.o. female with complex PMHx including of recurrent epileptic spasms and perinatal interventricular hemorrhage (requring ketogenic diet and multiple antiepileptic medications), intrauterine drug exposure, global developmental delay, G-tube dependence, and suprapubic catheter with recurrent urinary tract infection who presents today with increased lethargy, fever, vomiting x1 day. Per mother, pt was irritable at school, not tolerating feeds, felt warm. Tmax PTA 101, given tylenol/motrin and rescue ativan with single episode emesis shortly thereafter. Pt has been tired and lethargic all day, normally interactive at baseline. Recent increase in Banzel a few weeks ago. Mother denies diarrhea, rash, sick contacts. Pt had covid 5-6 weeks prior, no monoclonal antibody therapy.   In the ED, pt's blood pressure remained low with systolic pressures in the 70s despite 40cc/kg bolus. Film array positive for metaneumovirus; CBC, CXR unremarkable. Procalcitonin 0.54. Neurology consulted, recommending continuous EEG. Admitted to PICU for further management given continued soft blood pressures.   Admitted from: ED   History was provided by the parent and mother.

Technician called the pharmacist and Pharmacist attended the patient right away. Asked pt to lie his head down between the knees for better blood flow ( Looked like vasovagal response) Patient was breathing normal , was conscious in split seconds and talking .Pharmacist sat with the pt for 5-10 minutes and went back to the pharmacy after pt felt better. Technician stayed with the patient. Pt fainted again while technician was with him . Pharmacist attended the pt right away again and asked technician to call management and 911. Paramedics came to the scene checked blood pressure and heart rate. It was normal. pt was talking and responsive even before paramedics came in. Parent requested patient to be taken to hospital

SYMPTOM_TEXT: This is an instance of breakthrough COVID-19 after which death occurred. The individual was vaccinated with the Pfizer product on 07/30/2021 and 08/20/2021. The individual presented to emergency department on 01/15/2022 with primary complaints of severe abdominal pain. They were admitted to hospital same day and tested positive for COVID-19  on 01/16/2022. Due to the complexity of the situation (the individual had several underlying medical conditions), they were transferred to a different hospital on 01/16/2022. Their health continued to deteriorate and required ventilation. They died on 01/20/2022. The cause of the abdominal pain was not determined.
LAB_DATA: Positive COVID-19 test on 01/06/2022 despite being vaccinated.

All_symptoms: Anaemia Blood iron decreased Blood test abnormal Erythema Haemoglobin decreased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 24 hours after this vaccine Pt developed a red arm. It was puffy and hot to the touch. It went from his neck to his wrist, the entire arm that received the vaccine was red. After 3 days it went away and we thought it was going to be ok because he had never had a reaction before. Approximately 45 days later Pt began feeling unwell. He went to his nephrologist who ran routine blood tests and was shocked to see that Pt was now extremely anemic. His hemoglobin was 8.8. Pt had routine blood work done in December 2021 and his hemoglobin was 12.5. From December 2021 to March 2022 Pt became severely anemic, and this required hospitalization to try and correct the low iron. Nothing has changed from December when Pt was normal except that he got the COVID shot. The vaccine made him anemic and he now requires IV infusions of iron.
LAB_DATA: December 1, 2021 hemoglobin was 12.5 March 17th, 2022 hemoglobin was 8.8 The vaccine occurred on January 16

Subject was worked for hematuria, complete blood works including Complement (C3 and C4), total protein/creatinine ratio, APTT, PROTIME-INR, renal function panel, urinanalysis, calcium/random urine, urine culture, and kidney ultrasound. No treatment given. Gross hematuria resolved within 3 days and proteinuria persisted for about 3 months before resolving. Same follow done after 2nd booster and proteinuria follow up is still pending.

All_symptoms: Electroencephalogram Intentional self-injury Laboratory test Magnetic resonance imaging Seizure
SYMPTOM_TEXT: New onset seizures, approximately 5 hours after receiving COVID vaccine. (2 seizures)  Family heard a shout and a thump and arrived to find him actively seizing. Family called 911.  He does have a history of hitting his own head with his hands when he is frustrated but no banging on hard surfaces and no increase lately.  No recent hx of trauma, fever, cough, runny nose, diarrhea.  It is also possible that he has had an adolescent onset of epilepsy.  Seizures are more common in children with autism. He may have had a lower seizure threshold and the vaccine inflammation may have exceeded it.  It is unlikely that he has an intracranial event with normal behavior (for him) between seizures and a normal neuro exam.
LAB_DATA: EEG, MRI, labs
HISTORY: Autism, Obesity, Diabetes, Hypertriglyceridemia, Language Devlopment Disorder, Developmental Regress

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient developed symptoms of MISC on 11/7/21; fevers began on 11/9/21 with a Tmax of 41.1 degrees Celsius.  Over the course of illness, symptoms and complications included fevers, AKI, cough, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, rash, headache, neck pain, and myalgias. Abnormal labs included elevated creatinine, elevated bilirubin, elevated transaminases, elevated urine WBC, NT-ProBNP, elevated CRP, and elevated D-dimer. ECHO studies showed trivial tricuspid regurgitation and trivial mitral regurgitation. Patient was admitted to the hospital on 11/9/21 and treated with IVIG and steroids. She was discharged on 11/17/2021.
LAB_DATA: Positive SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid IgG, 11/12/21; negative SARS-CoV-2 PCR, 11/10/21; peak CRP 5.7 mg/dL, 11/13/21; peak NT-ProBNP 3,360.0 pg/mL, 11/12/21; peak creatinine 3.96 mg/dL, 11/13/21; peak bilirubin 3.0 mg/dL, 11/5/21; peak AST 122 U/L, 11/11/21; peak ALT 192 U/L, 11/11/21; peak urine WBC >100 cells/HPF, 11/10/21; peak D-dimer 2,810 ng/mL, 11/9/21; ECHO 11/12/21 showed mildly diminished left ventricular systolic function. ECHO 11/16/21 showed trivial tricuspid regurgitation and trivial mitral regurgitation. Abdominal US 11/9/21 showed increased bilateral renal parenchymal echogenicity with decreased corticomedullary differentiation, splenomegaly, borderline hepatomegaly, and contracted gallbladder despite fasting state. CT abdomen/pelvis 11/12/21 showed enlarged kidneys, contracted gallbladder, small amount of free fluid in the pelvis, small right and trace left pleural effusions.

All_symptoms: Abdominal pain Activated partial thromboplastin time shortened Acute kidney injury Alanine aminotransferase increased Anion gap
SYMPTOM_TEXT: The patient presented to the hospital 11/20/21 with signs and symptoms consistent with MIS-C as detailed next, felt to be triggered by previous COVID-19 infection (SARS-COV-2 nucleocapsid antibody was positive). Symptoms began the same day sh received influenza and COVID-19 vaccinations and in the context of known exposure to siblings with cold-like symptoms 1.5 months prior to admission.    In detail, her symptoms began 11/15/21 with fevers of 102 -103 degF, occurring hours after receiving an influenza vaccine and her first COVID-19 vaccine (Pfizer) at a well child visit earlier in the day. On day 2 of illness, she developed abdominal pain, nausea, loose stools, and her fevers continued. On day 3-4 of illness, she developed a diffuse confluent sunburn-like rash on her abdomen, chest, and face, which spread to her  arms (no involvement of palms/soles). Conjunctival injection developed by day 4 of illness and the rash worsened. She was brought to the ED on day 5 of illness when she felt her vision was a little blurry, where she was found to be hypotensive requiring a fluid bolus and she was admitted to the PICU. She was found to have multisystem inflammation with acute kidney injury, coagulopathy, myocarditis with elevated serum troponins but no compromised function, and vasodilatory shock.  Studies were consistent with MISC with hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, increased echogenicity of the kidneys on ultrasound, acute kidney injury with Cr of 3.6, elevated CRP, pro-calcitonin, ESR, BNP, troponin, D-dimer, and fibrinogen, hypoalbuminemia, thrombocytopenia, as well as lymphopenia (normal WBC and low absolute lymphocyte count of 800 cells/uL). Her echocardiogram showed normal ventricular function, coronary arteries and anatomy. EKG was normal. CXR was normal. Initial differential diagnosis included MISC, shock KD, toxic shock syndrome, sepsis, less likely tick-born illness (no high risk exposures). Lower extremity dopplers were normal. Sepsis/ID workup was negative by blood cultures, respiratory viral multiplex nasopharyngeal PCR panel, COVID-19 nasopharyngeal PCR, ehrlichia and anaplasma serologies and PCRs, rickettsia rickettsii serologies, and a strep A PCR test from outside pediatrics clinic was negative 2 days prior to admission. COVID-19 serologies were positive for SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid antibody (qualitative) and spike antibody (titer of 182 U/mL; normal reference < 0.8 U/mL), indicating a past infection which was felt to be the trigger for her MIS-C.    She was treated for MIS-C with IVIG, steroids, lovenox, and high dose aspirin. Lisinopril was given for elevated blood pressures presumably secondary to steroids. Empirical antibiotics for possible sepsis or toxic shock syndrome (ceftriaxone, clindamycin, vancomycin) were discontinued 48 hours of blood culture negativity and with no evidence of focal infection. She had excellent clinical recovery on MIS-C treatments. Pressors with norepinephrine were weaned off within 12 hours of admission, and her rash and fevers quickly resolved along with her other presenting symptoms. Inflammatory markers eventually were all improving by the day of discharge 11/24/22. She was discharged to home on weaning oral steroids, lovenox, aspirin, lisinopril. Upon hematology and cardiology outpatient follow up over the next two months (visits on 12/1/21 and 1/12/22 with repeat labs 1/3/22), she was doing well without any cardiac symptoms of chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, or syncope. She was noted to have demonstrated full recovery and with no recurrence of symptoms or inflammation on repeat labs (1/3/22) after coming off the steroids (completed 12/27/21). Lovenox was stopped 12/1/21. Aspirin was stopped 1/12/22 after her vW and FVIII levels normalized indicating resolution of vasculitis. She received her second COVID-19 vaccine (Pfizer) on 1/13/22. A cardiac MRI was normal on 1/24/22.
LAB_DATA: Admission labs 11/20/21 showing multisystem inflammation consistent with MIS-C: - WBC 7.3, hgb 12.4, plts 77, ANC 5600, ALC 800 - ESR 30 - Procalcitonin 95.36 ng/mL - CRP 80.2 mg/L - Na 130, K 3.0, chloride 94, CO2 24, BUN 77, Cr 3.65, glucose 110 - Ca 8.2, anion gap 12 - Albumin 2.7 - Bilirubin total 0.4, alk phos 122, ALT 44 (however became abnormal 11/24/21 to 51), AST 45 (however became abnormal to 66 on 11/24/21) - Ferritin 687 - Lactic acid 0.5 - N-terminal Pro BNP 3,116 - Troponin I 0.083 - INR 0.98 - PTT 35 - Fibrinogen 529 - D-dimer 10.53 - Factor 8 assay 176 - Von Willebrand factor activity 332 % - Von Willebrand factor antigen 243%  Negative infectious studies as follows, aside from positive COVID-19 antibodies indicative of previous infection, all drawn 11/20/21: - Negative aerobic blood culture - Unremarkable urinalysis (negative glucose, bili, ketones, normal spec grav, pH, protein 50, normal urobilinogen, negative nitrite, leuk esterase, blood, 4 WBCs, 1 RBC, many bacteria, 10 squamous epi, mucus present) - Negative tick born infection studies 11/20 as mentioned above in section 18 - Negative SARS-CoV-2 PCR, nasopharyngeal - Positive SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid antibody (assay, qualitative) - Positive SARS-CoV-2 spike antibody, titer 182 U/mL (assay) - Negative Respiratory multiplex panel, nasopharyngeal PCR  Inpatient Imaging:  - CXR 11/20 normal - Echocardiogram 11/20 normal Lower extremity dopplers 11/23/21 ""IMPRESSION: No deep vein thrombosis in the right or left lower extremity."" - Complete abdominal ultrasound 11/20/21: IMPRESSION: 1. Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and increased echogenicity of the kidneys (indicating medical renal disease) are all findings that could be seen in MISC. 2. All_symptoms: Hypersensitivity Immunisation reaction Oropharyngeal discomfort Pharyngeal swelling Sensation of foreign body
SYMPTOM_TEXT: presents for evaluation at ED on 4/7/22 after likely allergic reaction from COVID vaccine.  Patient was at his pediatrician's office today getting his prescribed vaccination, and within 20 minutes of the vaccination began feeling as though he was having globus sensation/swelling in his throat.  Per mother, patient was speaking normally and swallowing normally at that time, he was treated with p.o. Benadryl in the office, and evaluated for another 20 to 30 minutes.  After the second observation.  He still felt the swelling in his throat and was noted then to have wheezing, treated with albuterol nebulizer treatment prior to arrival in the emergency department.  Patient still reports ""weird feeling"" in his throat, but denies difficulty breathing. Patient was treated with weight-based dose of p.o. dexamethasone and observed for over an hour with no worsening of symptoms. Given prescription for EpiPen.

All_symptoms: C-reactive protein increased Chest pain Echocardiogram normal Electrocardiogram abnormal Immunisation reaction
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 12-year-old boy with post-COVID-vaccine-associated myocarditis who had presented with chest pain x1 day and recent fever (2 days prior to admission) after dose #2 of Pfizer vaccine. Of note, history of acute COVID infection on 12/29/2021, but negative COVID during admission. COVID-vaccine-induced myocarditis was suspected with low clinical suspicion for MIS-C given time course, no recent fever, and mildly elevated CRP, with no other concerning symptoms.   Troponins peaked at 1.66 and downtrended until 0.21 at time of discharge with recommendation for troponin recheck at 1 week while outpatient. Cardiology were consulted by the team, who recommended echo, which was unremarkable. EKG showed sinus rhythm. For chest pain, ibuprofen PRN was first-line, but patient denied chest pain and specific complaints for most of the hospital course. Patient was discharged in stable condition to home with appointment placed with cardiology and repeat troponin scheduled for 1 week post-discharge. Recommendation was to avoid strenuous activity and competitive sports for 3 months until clearance with treadmill.

Developed tingling and numbness in limbs that quickly progressed to loss of reflexes, difficulty standing and walking, and soon also severe pain.  Hospitalized 11/29/21 to 12/6/21. Sudden/severe drop in blood pressure on one occasion. Treated with IVIG. Months of slowly improving difficulty with walking, balance, strength and pain that interfered greatly with school attendance. Primarily used gabapentin for pain outpatient. Completed physical therapy outpatient in March 2022, fully recovered. Put off second dose of Covid vaccine on medical advice, but now planning to get it after further consultation with treating neurologist.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: On April 2, 2022, she was complaining about a sore throat that Saturday night. The next day on Sunday she had a fever and felt nauseated. She vomited 3 times. She also had a headache and a little bit of congestion. She kept complaining about a sore throat and headache on Monday and Tuesday. I took her to the doctor on April 5th and she was diagnosed with strep throat. The doctor didn't do the strep test swab. He just diagnosed her because of the symptoms she had. She was prescribed Amoxicillin 400mg/5mL Suspension 100mL. She drunk 10mL for 7 days. I never took her to a follow up appointment because they never gave her one as the hospital asked for so I ended up changing doctors. She went back to school on the following Thursday and Friday. She sounds like she has a little bit of allergies still, but she is doing much better after taking the Amoxicillin.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Case-patient had first Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine on 12/18/2021 and illness onset for MIS-C was on the same day. Case had COVID-19 with mild symptoms approximately 4 weeks before MIS-C onset. Case-patient met case definition for MIS-C with evidence of clinically severe illness requiring hospitalization, fever, multisystem organ involvement (cardiac, hematologic, & GI). The case-patient experienced cardiac shock, chest pain, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, conjunctival injection, and various elevated inflammatory markers (see box 19 below). Case-patient was treated with IVIG, ASA, steroids, and epinephrine and survived after a 4 day hospitalization (1 day in PICU).

All_symptoms: Acute kidney injury Acute respiratory distress syndrome Acute respiratory failure Blood bicarbonate decreased Blood creatinine increased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Diagnosis of COVID-19 who presents with dehydration and COVID pneumonia. She developed cough and runny nose a about a week ago. She had several home COVID tests that were negative. On 9/22 she had a test at Pharmacy that came back with results of ""indecisive"" on 9/25. She was taken to a clinic that same day where COVID-19 PCR was positive and CXR reportedly with ""mild pneumonia"". She was seen in our ED yesterday (9/26) for a COVID antibody infusion. Mother reports that patient has previously received a similar infusion when she was sick with coronavirus this past winter. She has had nausea and some vomiting of mucus. She has had decreased appetite. Reports mild sore throat. Denies any headache or abdominal pain. She was taken back to the ED  today due to persistent cough, some shortness of breath, and decreased drinking over the past 2 days. Repeat CXR showed stable findings of mild to moderate b/I opacities. Labs at ED include CMP (HC03 14, BUN 36, Cr 2.43, otherwise wnl), CBC (WBC 10k, H/H 11.5/35, pits 72), LA (20-49 WBC, spec grav 1.020). She received a total of 2L of NS and a dose of ceftriaxone. Patient became critically ill with acute respiratory failure requiring invasive mechanical ventilation secondary to acute COVID pneumonia/ARDS and AKI. Intubated and on mechanical ventilation with improving lung function, however severe critical illness neuromyopathy prevented mechanical ventilation liberation.  On day of death patient developed rapidly (minutes) progressive refractory hypotension and bradycardia. Resuscitative efforts started with chest compressions and meds (CPR form).  Copious amounts of fresh blood noted from ETT unable to be controlled despite continuous suction. This prevented from adequate gas exchange. All resuscitative efforts stopped at 10:34 and patient pronounced dead.
HISTORY: T cell leukemia s/p bone marrow transplant

All_symptoms: Alanine aminotransferase normal Albumin CSF increased Aspartate aminotransferase normal Asthenia Blood creatinine normal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 12/4/21: 2nd dose of Pfizer Covid vaccine 12/23/21: FIrst symptom of LEFT sided ptosis (did not resolve) 1/13/22: Noticable worsening of LEFT ptosis 1/23/22: Limping began  1/24/22: Limping worsened with LEFT leg splinting (knee pointed inwards) 1/26/22: Presented to PCP; labs obtained:  WBC 9.4 (37N, 55L), H&H 14.2/41.9, Plts 274. ESR 2, CRP <1.0. Glu 84, cr 0.38, AST 33, ALT 17. Left lower extremity XR done and showed a ""cortical irregularity of the left femoral head"".  1/29/22: Presented to ED: Pelvis XR showing LEFT femoral head flattening and irregularity, possible AVN vs benign variant. Ortho consulted and felt consistent with LCP.  ***PLEASE SEE PAGE 2 FOR CONTINUED TIMELINE*** 2/3/22: Seen at clinic – was unable to bear weight, had a positive Gower's sign prompting non-con spine MRI which was normal.  2/4/22: Seen by Neuro for LEFT sided headache, LEFT eye ptosis and LEFT leg weakness; referred to ED and admitted.  2/4/22 – 2/11/22: Admitted for progressive LEFT sided weakness. Brain MRI showed diffuse cauda equine nerve root thickening and enhancement (greatest ventrally) and mild leptomeningeal enhancement circumscribing the conus; all suggestive of an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy (AIDP, GBS). Labs showed WBC 6.9, Hct 31.7, Plts 188; ANC 1173; ESR 19, CRP <0.8. Blood cultures from 2/7/22 were negative. LP done on 2/5/22 which showed CSF WBC 2, RBC 1, Prot 263, Glucose 50; Albumin 162.0, Synthesis Rate 32.43, IgG 17.4, IgG/Albumin Ratio 0.11, IgG Index 0.73. CSF Mycoplasma PCR neg. CSF cultures were negative. He received IVIG 2/5/22 – 2/7/22 which was subsequently complicated by symptoms of aseptic meningitis.  2/11/22 – 2/18/22:  Transferred to inpatient rehab, where he showed improvement by the time of discharge.  3/1/22 – 3/5/22 Admitted to hospital again due to gradual decline in LE strength to point of not being able to sit or walk independently. CIDP started to rise higher on the differential. Toto received another round of IVIG 2g/kg over 2 days – had again post-infusion reaction. Upon discharge had improvement in lower extremity muscle function.  4/4/22 – 4/7/22 Re-admitted to hospital due to worsening ascending weakness, and new progress nausea / headache in morning, worsening of his ptosis (which had never completely resolved since first appearing on 12/23/21) and blurry vision. He was found to have increased ICP and papilledema on brain MRI; notably, no evidence of demyelination of brain or brainstem. MRI head venogram was normal. Had an LP confirming increased ICP with opening pressure 26-42; WBC 26 (0% polys, 100% other cell types), RBC 2, Prot 150, Glucose 138.  CSF viral PCR panel negative (CMV, HSV, HHV6, ENV, Parecho, VZV PCRs). Culture negative. Elevated WBCs and Protein thought to be secondary to prior IVIG treatments and high protein supportive of CIDP diagnosis. Received IV Methylpred 30 mg/kg from 4/5-4/7. Started on Acetazolamide.   4/16/22 - Continues to follow with Neurology and Rehab / Therapy
LAB_DATA: Please see above timeline for related work-up including labs / imaging

All_symptoms: Dyspnoea
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient complained of difficulty taking a breath approximately 15 minutes after vaccine administered.   Mother reported that this happened after his first Pfizer dose. At that time symptoms only lasted 10 minutes.  Patient observed. Stated that symptoms seemed like they were improving some. Patient was instructed to take deep breaths and was continually observed. Respiration rate at that time 22. Total observation period approximately 1 hour, symptoms stayed the same. No angioedema, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, chest pain.    Patient did not appear tachypneic.  Patient appeared non-distressed. Able to speak in full sentences. Skin color normal. No audible wheezing. No rashes/hives. Vital signs were taken about 30 minutes after vaccine administered and repeated about 15 minutes later. Vitals: pulse ox 96%, BP 128/73 mmHg, RR 22, Pulse 79, Temp 97.2 degrees F.  Based on patient appearance and vitals, on-site emergency protocols did not need to be deployed.   Patient instructed to call PCP to be evaluated, or go to ED if symptoms worsen.   Patient's mother spoke to PCP on the phone. Patient was instructed by PCP to be evaluated in emergency room. Patient's father came to school. Patient's parents left and took him to emergency room approximately 1.5 hours after vaccine administration.

Two day fever of 38c. In ED the patient was hypotensive to 70s/30s and admitted to PICU. ECHO revealed left  ventricular dysfunction, moderate to severe tricuspid valve regurgitation. ECHO before discharge showed improved cardiac function.

All_symptoms: Abdominal X-ray Abdominal distension Anticoagulant therapy Atelectasis Blood fibrinogen increased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 7 year old male with no significant past medical history who was admitted for tachycardia in the setting of 7 days of fevers, bloody stools (gross blood seen 1/25), NBNB vomiting, and decreased PO intake and urine output. S/p both doses of his COVID vaccine, second dose at end of December 2021. A CAT was called 1/29 due to decreased urine output, low BPs in the 80s systolic and HR persistently 120s-140s despite pain management. He received a total of 4 NS boluses over his first 2 hospital days and CXR was obtained with atelectasis vs L sided PNA. POC US done by PICU fellow showed mild-mod cardiac dysfunction. Labs were notable for increased troponin and markedly increased BNP, leukocytosis with left shift, and persistently elevated inflammatory markers. He was subsequently transferred to the PICU.  On arrival to the PICU, patient was hypotensive with fluid overload clinically (peripheral edema, pulmonary edema on CXR), consistent with cardiogenic shock. Epinephrine was started and milrinone added given ECHO with diminished biventricular function. Epi was discontinued 1/30 and milrinone continued. Nicardipine was added for afterload reduction and lovenox added given poor cardiac function. Lasix gtt was started 1/30 for diuresis, and diuril added 1/31 (though discontinued 2/1 due to adequate diuresis). Given continued hypertension, nicardipine drip was d/c'ed as amlodipine was started.  For treatment of MISC, patient received IVIG on 1/30, pulse dose steroids on 2/1 and 2/2, and continued on BID steroids with wean plan outlined by rheumatology. His inflammatory markers down-trended appropriately and his cardiac function normalized on ECHO 2/2. Given patient age and anxiety with medical therapies, he was intubated 1/30-2/3. Dex and midaz drips were started for sedation and anxiolysis. Patient remained stable on RA. Given fevers and retrocardiac opacity on CXR 1/30, patient completed 5 days of CTX for pneumonia.  Patient  developed worsening abdominal distension and emesis, requiring intermittent pauses in feeds. Abdominal xray showed ileus with significant gaseous distention. Feeds were paused 2/3 for extubation, briefly resumed, then paused again in the setting of multiple episodes of emesis (one heme occult positive emesis likely due to coagulopathy + mallory weiss tear). Distension improved with NPO/sump suctioning, and patient was able to tolerate clear liquids and meds starting 2/4. Bowel regimen was continued with small, non-bloody stool output. Patient had no further episodes of bloody stool or emesis. Hgb and coags were trended and improved. Anti-xa remained within goal while on lovenox. At the time of transfer patient was tolerating a regular diet and off all IV medications. Patient's bowel regimen was held in the setting of loose stools. Patient continued to tolerate PO and was meeting maintenance goals at the time of discharge.   Patient hospitalized from 1/28/22 to 2/8/22 with 7 days spent in ICU.

All_symptoms: Abdominal pain Blast cells present Blood bicarbonate decreased Diarrhoea Full blood count abnormal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 5 days after vaccination developed GI symptoms.  She was seen in  ER on 2/22 for abd pain, vomiting & diarrhea & 2/27 for vomiting. Mom reports approx 3 weeks of ongoing symptoms.  Child started with a few episodes of vomiting in a day then would go a couple of days without vomiting. And the cycle would restart. She also had diarrhea. Last episode of vomiting was 2/24 & last episode of diarrhea was 2/25 am. Denies further abd pain. Since then acting well.  She had labs the second time and white count was elevated at 13,600 but the concerning thing was that there were 62% lymphocytes but also some early appearing cells with at least 1 cell that appeared to be a blast versus a reactive lymphocyte.  Continued below.  Approximately 10% of the lymphocytic cells were what he described as lymphoplasmacytic type cells that are usually seen in older adults but could be a reactive component to an infectious process on the CBC according to pathologist and he sent it out for consult who agreed.  Concern was for early leukemia or malignancy.  We repeated the CBC twice subsequently and the number of lyphoplasmacytic cells declined and WBC normalized and Hemoglobin and platelets were normal.  It is unclear whether this was a reaction to the vaccine or an infectious process but mother strongly believes it was a reaction to the vaccine so I said I would report it.  I checked her today and exam was normal.  We are waiting for the patholigst to review the CBC but it appears normal to me.
LAB_DATA: CBCs abnormal as described in #18.  CMPs showed slightly low bicarbinates at 19.2 and 20.5 then normal, otherwise normal for age.

Worst pain is when looking over right shoulder. - Still eating and attending online classes like normal. - He could not sleep well last night because of the pain. - No fever.  - Walking normally but had to look down a little bit d/t pain.  - When he sits down, he needs to sit forward and can't straighten his back, but mom wondering if that is because he's been sitting for a while for school. - Pt reports he is urinating normally and had a normal BM today - The left hand has a little bit of pain and discomfort and some numbness on his legs but he has been sitting for a long time doing his online school. (pt did not volunteer this information but was provided when mom directly asked about any numbness/tingling.) TREATMENT: - Increase fluids - Get plenty of rest - Alternate Tylenol / Ibuprofen every 3-4 hours as needed for pain - If symptoms drastically worsen or a high fever is present then please be sure to take the child to the ER

All_symptoms: Anticoagulant therapy Blood culture negative Brain natriuretic peptide increased Bundle branch block right C-reactive protein increased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 2/9/22 11 y/o male who had COVID-19 in December, presented to the ER with 8 days of fever, pleuritic chest pain, headache, and malaise. Also 3 to 4 days of periorbital and lip swelling with a macular rash that resolved. Hypotensive 76/43, tachycardia at 126. MIS-C vs Kawasaki. Admitted to ICU. Resp: remained stable on RA. ID: He was given IVIG x1 on 2/10 and started on Methylprednisolone 1mg/kg BID. Blood & urine cultures were negative.  2/9 CXR - small left effusion, EKG w/right bundle branch block. Echo-good contractility, mitral valve insufficiency consistent w/myocarditis.  2/11 Inflammatory markers downtrending, transfer to floor. CV: BP's were stable and he did not require any pressors. He was started on Aspirin 81mg daily and Lovenox. Evidence of mild myocarditis with tachycardia and mildly elevated troponin, which downtrended prior to transfer to regular floor. Repeat Chest Xray on 2/11 showed small left basilar pleural effusion unchanged from previous examination. It also showed subsegmental consolidation left base, suspicious pneumonia, and WBC also increased to 26.52, patient was started on Ampicillin. Ampicillin later changed to PO Amoxicillin as PO tolerance improved and clinical impression improved. Methylprednisolone was also changed to PO Prednisone. Blood and urine cultures showed no growth after 5 and 2 days, respectively.   2/14 Repeat Echo showed trivial-to-small pericardial effusion located posteriorly behind the heart, with excellent biventricular function. Patient remained afebrile while on floor. Inflammatory markers and LFTs continued to downtrend. Electrolyte abnormalities resolved. Discharged 2/15/2022.

CRP 159, Procalcitonin 3.47, Ddimer3,618, Pro-BNP 2,376, PT 14.4. Tachypnic, hypotensive, elevated inflammatory markers, neg COVID and flu PCRs and pos COVID Abs. Urinalysis with +LE, bacteria, WBC. Blood & culture pending. Zosyn, vancomycin administered pending clinical course/culture results.  Increased tachypnea/fatigue 1/26 received IVIG overnight for possible MIS-C, echo with decrease in function, some PVCs noted overnight, concern for patient being at risk for need of escalation in cardiac support, iv linezolid and meropenem, decision to transfer to center with ECMO capabilities. SYMPTOM_TEXT: On 01/08/22, she developed a cough and fever then subsequently tested positive for COVID-19 on 01/10. She started improving and felt better until 01/13 at which time she developed high fevers 102-103F with Tmax 106F, nausea with multiple episodes of vomiting, diffuse myalgias with hand and foot edema, and malaise. Admitted on 01/16/22 for MIS-C, received 1 dose of IVIg on 01/17, and was discharged on Tuesday 01/18 on prednisone 40 mg PO and aspirin 81 mg. Readmitted on after resurgence of fever/102F, nausea, myalgias, and a mild headache. Mother noted she has been very fatigued. Likely secondary to refractory MIS-C, cannot rule out other source of infection. No fever since admission. Labs done on admission reassuring; showed continued downtrend of inflammatory markers. 1/20 Labs: WBC 12.8 (unchanged from 1/19) CK WLN, LD WLN, fibrinogen 618 (down from 782 on 1/18), D-dimer 2.38 WLN (slight increase from 1.69 on 1/16), CRP 30 (down from 56.1 on 1/19). Naproxen 375mg BID AMD Pepcid started on 1/21. Discharged 1/22 on prednisone 40 mg daily and ASA 81 mg ,
LAB_DATA: 1/16 B Type Natriuretic Peptide 144, Procalcitonin 39.04, CRP 229.6, Ferritin 175, Fibrinogen 932, D-dimer 1.69, CXR atypical pneumonia/Covid, Urine negative.

All_symptoms: Abdominal pain Acute respiratory failure Blister Blood culture negative Blood fibrinogen increased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 01/13/2022 10-year-old male without significant past medical or surgical history presenting for evaluation of 6 days of fever, nausea/vomiting and decreased p.o. intake, diffuse abdominal pain, headache, fatigue, and migratory rash. Patient reportedly COVID-positive 12/6/2021, received initial COVID-vaccine in late November. Patient denying any chest pain, cough, or shortness of breath. Constellation of symptoms is concerning for Kawasaki versus MIS-C. Exam notable for diffuse rash with palmar involvement and early bullae/vesicles, straw berry tongue. There is no conjunctival injection, no perineal involvement. No focal neurologic deficits, diffuse abdominal tenderness without focality. Vital signs are stable hough notable for mild hypotension.  Laboratory studies overall consistent with MISC (elevations in ESR/CRP, ferritin, etc. with elevations in troponin and BNP consistent with myocarditis. Electrolyte abnormalities including hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hypocalcemia consistent with inadequate oral intake and diarrhea.  Hospital course: MIS-C associated with COVID-19, S/p CTX x2, negative blood cultures, S/p IVIG 1/14, Solumedrol 1/14-1/15, Transitioned to PO Prednisolone 1/16 Lovenox switched to ASA 1/1  Acute respiratory failure with hypoxia, Required HFNC on arrival to PICU, Stable on RA day of d/c.  Myocarditis,  LVEF 45-50% on 1/14  Discharge: Pt tolerating regular diet well. No N/V. Pt denies any pain. Rash to BLE and bilateral hands/arms improved. Follow up with PMD in one week, Rheumotology in one week, Cardiology in one month
LAB_DATA: 1/13-sed rate 41, Ferritin: 358,  Fibrinogen 469, D dimer: 2.27, B Type Natriuretic Peptide: 1407 1/14-PT 15.8, INR 1.3, D dimer 14.8, Potassium: 2.8, Troponin I: 0.32, EKG

UPON EVAL PT WAS ILL APPEARING, FEBRILE, TACHYCARDIC, HYPOTENSIVE 90/40. CONCERN FOR MIS-C VS. KAWASASKI VS. VIRAL EXANTHEM VS. TICK BORNE ILLNESS. ADMITTED TO UNIT FLOOR. REC'D IV FLUIDS, EMPIRIC CEFTRIAXONE, IVIG AND LOW DOSE ASPIRIN PER MIS-C PROTOCOL. 1/7 ADDED IV STEROIDS & LOVENOX.  Blood and urine cx NG >36 hours and at 5 days. Hospital course:  Blood and urine cx NG >36 hours & at 5 days, - Tick studies negative, Pancytopenia improving -Received 2nd dose of IVIG due to being febrile and symptomatic within 36 hours after 1st infusion -Kept on mIVF for hydration -Appetite improved over time -Developed Abdominal pain; abd XR showed prominent liver, inc LFTS; abd US showed diffuse inflammation in the abdomen involving multiple organs -Abdomen pain and LFTs improved over following days, no N/V, constipation or diarrhea  Discharge:  -Follow up with physician within 48 hours of discharge -follow up with cardiology and rheumatology in the outaptient setting -continue with aspirin once a day, steroids once a day and famotidine for belly protection - rheumatology will help taper the steroids, for now continue taking them once a day.

All_symptoms: Activated partial thromboplastin time shortened Adenovirus test Blood culture Blood fibrinogen increased C-reactive protein increased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 2/9/22 To ED with 3 days of bilious/nonbloody vomiting, fever, and headaches with 1 day onset of watery diarrhea since the morning. Fevers with a T-max of 103.3 F. Patient more sleepy & appetite decreased significantly. Prior to arriving to the ED, mom noticed a faint rash on his torso that had resolved ""for the most part."" Per mom patient tested positive for Covid three weeks ago but remained asymptomatic w/o complications. Fully vaccinated. Admitted for COVID associated MISC. Infectious disease followed. ID following. 2/10 Received 1 dose of IVIG 2g/kg run over 8 hours and methylprednisolone 30 mg/kg. Echo showed normal intracardiac connections and normal biventricular systolic function. Pancytopenia- worsened, 2/10 WBC 4.5  RBC 3.88  Hgb 10.6  Hct 30.5 L   Adenovirus was high on DDx, but RVP since returned negative, making MIS-C the likely diagnosis. Inflammatory markers stable. FU labs tomorrow to trend. Pt now afebrile for at least 16 hours, and otherwise HDS on RA. Discussed with ID re: negative COVID Ab. With known hx of COVID, the negative test does not preclude the diagnosis. There is also the possibility of post-vaccine MISC (not common) but again with his known hx within 4 weeks it fits the diagnosis regardless. 2/12 Patient improving based on lab work and clinical assessment. He is tolerating fluids and small amounts of solid food with mild nausea. He remains afebrile and HDS. Patient is stable for discharge
LAB_DATA: 2/9 WBC 9.2, PT 16.6, PTT 38.9, ESR 15, Fibrinogen 515, Ddimer 1.41, Hgb 12.2, CRP 120.65, Urine culture negative, blood culture pending. EKG was wnl.

All_symptoms: Abdominal pain C-reactive protein increased COVID-19 Echocardiogram normal Encephalitis
SYMPTOM_TEXT: 2/10 ER note, 2nd covid vax on 1/7. Diagnosed with Covid on 1/9 after outbreak at mother's work. Nasal congestion/fatigue, recovered quickly. Began 2/4 with daily fever and fatigue, abdominal pain, reddened eyes and neck pain/tenderness upon palpation. Rash began today, 2/10.  MIS-C vs meningitis/encephalitis. Inflammatory markers significantly elevated, concerning for MIS-C, hemodynamically stable. Admitted. Urine & blood cultures ordered.   Work up confirms diagnosis of MIS-C, initiated treatment. He received IVIG, and IV steroids. Infectious disease was consulted forrecommendations,[SB.3] a[SB.4]nd followed along throughout hospitalization. Pediatric cardiology was also consulted per protocol.    With clinical improvement and improving inflammatory markers, he was transitioned to oral steroids with taper to complete his course for MIS?C treatment. To remain on ASA, prednisone until coronary arteries are reassessed, and he has normalization of platelets. Discharged home with planned cardiology follow-up.
LAB_DATA: 2/10 CRP 146, ProBNP 1284, trop 19, Covid Ab +, Covid PCR neg., Ddimer 2.57, ferritin 2,932, flu & RSV negative. 2/11 Echo is normal.

All_symptoms: Abdominal pain upper Anxiety Axillary pain Blood test normal Chest pain
SYMPTOM_TEXT: She mentioned chest pains and stiffness of the hand immediately. They advised her to keep moving her hand. When she mentioned the chest pains, we went straight to the hospital. This was on Saturday. They did an ekg which was normal. When we came home she said that her stomach was hurting. I kept giving her water but the following morning, she continued to complain of pain in her stomach and under her arm pit on the same side she received her vaccine. I put Neosporin on it because I was advised by a doctor before to use it for this type of pain. I called the nurse line and they said it could be a swollen lymph node. They advised me not to treat it but to wait until the pediatrician examined her. She then told me the chest pain was back. She went to the bathroom and she had a runny stomach. We went to the ER yesterday around 10pm for chest pain and they did an ekg, x-ray, and bloodwork. They said everything looks good and to come back if the chest pains worsen, I am going to set up an appointment with the pediatrician. We are also going to see a cardiologist. The ER indicated that they think this is anxiety related as they had done all preliminary testing and did not see anything. They ruled out myocardial issues. She started having breathing issues when walking into the hospital. Today she is indicating that she is still having the chest pains. At least 3 times today. We have an appointment with a Pediatric cardiologist on Thursday. She still has the pain in her under arm.
LAB_DATA: Ekg, X-Ray, Blood Work

All_symptoms: Dyspnoea
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Shortness of breath and difficulties breathing in the afternoon same day she received the vaccine. Mother called 911, and EMS provided an ""injection"" then monitored her at home for 1 hour. EMS left without taking patient to an ED.
HISTORY: Patient is a 16 y.o. female with  with Morquio A Syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis Type IVA, OMIM # 253000).  Typical manifestations are mostly skeletal abnormalities.  Her active issues include obstructive sleep apnea (with risk for central apnea from cord compression), Restrictive lung disease, Mitral and aortic valve thickening, Odontoid hypoplasia (with risk for atlantoaxial instability), Kyphosis, and multilevel vertebral disc herniation.  Her major functional impairments are a waddling gait and easy fatigue after short walks.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: It started with extreme fatigue, shortness of breath, stabbing pains in his chest. It was severe so he wasn't moving or doing anything and was very lethargic and couldn't do anything or move without severe pain. We went to the ER the first night and they didn't really diagnosis him them said it could be either pericarditis or myocarditis and to come back if it got worse. 2 days later, it got worse and we went back to the ER and the doctor could hear rubbing on the scope so it helped him diagnose pericarditis and to not do activities till it got better and take Tylenol. We followed up with our regular doctor and she said the same thing and did another ekg which looked normal but the pain persisted and just last week (6monts later) he did an echocardiogram and that all looked normal but he still has pain when he does physical active though it's gotten better. Doctor said same thing that it was pericarditis.

At her follow up visit with pediatric rheumatology she continued having symptoms of left ankle pain and was prescribed etanercept under the diagnosis of Chronic Non-bacterial Osteomyelitis (CNO). She has a follow up clinic visit to evaluate for the effectiveness of etanercept therapy on 7/7/2022.
LAB_DATA: Bone biopsy samples from her left ankle revealed osteomyelitis.  MRI of the left ankle revealed osteomyelitis and synovitis. Whole body MRI )STIR) revealed additional foci of signal abnormality on her right humerus, right hip,  and T5 and S1 vertebral bodies. Autoantibody testing was negative. Normal C3 and C4. Slightly elevated serum IL-10.  During hospital admission, she had mildly elevated platelet counts and mildly elevated D-dimers.

All_symptoms: COVID-19 Cough Culture throat negative Epistaxis Feeling abnormal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On Friday, January 14, it was in the evening after he came home from school. About 6PM. I heard him cough a couple times. He will usually have a cough here and there. He told me he wasn't sure and maybe something went down the wrong pipe. It was strange none the less. The next morning, around 4-5AM on Saturday the 15th, he woke up complaining of a sore throat. When he woke up at 8am he still complained about the sore throat. Gave him some hot chocolate and it felt better and it was gone. He didn't have it again until around 5pm the same day. He complained about the throat being sore again. I gave him an at-home test which came back negative. He didn't complain anymore then went to bed. He woke up at 10pm and complained again and he seemed to have a fever. He had a popsicle, and he just couldn't sleep and that his throat was sore. I offered to take him to emergent care, and he said no. he was struggling to sleep well and gave him fever reducing medication. At around 6-7am, he was still complaining, and he said he didn't feel good. And still had a fever. Took him to urgent care. They did a strep test culture and rapid, and the COVID PCR test. The COVID PCR came back positive. On Sunday, the fever was still occurring, he was lethargic. Throat was hurting. Didn't want to drink or eat. His fever broke about 10-11pm on Sunday. He had this fever for about 24 hours. He woke up on Monday and bounced back to being normal. He didn't complain about a sore throat anymore and viewed himself as normal. So, by Wednesday or Thursday, a cough appeared. He did on Sunday have a cough like a fake cough. 2-3 days after when he felt better was when the cough came. The cough was deeper and he never had phlegm and didn't have anything come up. Sounded like an adult deep cough. He had that for 2-2 1/2 weeks. The cough subsided and I would hear him clear this throat constantly. Towards the end of February, I brought him to the pediatrician and she said his nasal passages were swollen, possibly allergies. She recommended putting him on CLARITIN ever since. He doesn't have the throat clearing like he used to, but if I miss a day, he starts to feel weird. Not sure if it's an allergy thing or because of COVID. He was sick a couple weeks ago as well. This last time I took him to the office and they did a rapid test and it came back negative. His symptoms were nearing what COVID was. He had a fever, cough appeared later. He didn't have a confirmed COVID test, but I'm concerned he had it again. There have also been some nose bleeds that may be due to the swollen nasal passages.
LAB_DATA: 01/15/2022 - At Home COVID Test - Negative; 01/16/2022 - Strep Culture - Negative; 01/16/2022 - Strep Rapid - Negative; 01/16/2022 - COVID PCR - Positive

All_symptoms: Abdominal pain upper Arthralgia Blister Condition aggravated Eczema
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient received first COVID Vac on 03/28/2022 and experienced mild eczema flareup shortly after. Received second COVID vaccine on 05/11/2022 and started having symptoms on 05/18/2022 to include headaches, stomach pain, joint pain, fevers, fluid filled bumps on lip that spread to face/arm/hands/inside mouth, weight loss of 4 lbs (significant for a child his age). Bumps resembled herpes. Case reports show that Herpes simplex flare is an uncommon skin reaction to the COVID vaccine. Unfortunately, it appears the  healthcare providers don't seem to want to link it to the vaccine. Although the patient has a history of severe eczema, he has never had an eczema flare-up that resembles herpes. After two visits to ERS, he was finally swabbed and diagnosed with HSV1. He was placed on acyclovir (which he is still taking), keflex oral antibiotics and mupiricin topical antibiotics for infection, tylenol and motrin for fevers that lasted 5 days, and other skin creams. He has scars and is suffering emotionally from embarrassment of how his mouth looks. He is still recoving.
LAB_DATA: HSV1 positive 04/23/2022
HISTORY: severe eczema, seasonal allergies, food allergies, mild asthma

All_symptoms: Abdominal pain upper Balance disorder Blood test normal Computerised tomogram normal Crying
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Initial symptoms were pain at injection site and fatigue.  Fatigue became more significant by 5/27, with patient taking a 3hr nap in the middle of the day after having slept 12-13hrs at night.  That night she had a fever of 101.5.  Gave Ibuprofen (7.5ml).  On 5/28, took a 5hr nap after sleeping through the night.  Complains of full body pain, pain under armpits, both arms and legs.   On 5/29, screaming in pain when touched.  Does not want to walk, when she tried to walk she is wobbly, unsteady gait, off balance.  Have to carry her to use toilet.  Even gentle touch hurts her.  Complains of arms and legs hurting. Sleeping most of the day. On 5/30, extremely lethargic.  Only awakes if loudly spoken to, complains of body pains, especially legs.  Cannot walk or hold self up.  Legs seem extremely weak and balance is off.  Put her in bathtub in hopes it would help muscle aches, but she fell asleep in bathtub.  Decide to take her to Medical Center Emergency Room in.  After an extremely long wait, she gets seen by a provider.  CT scan and blood work were ordered, results were normal.  She is given IV fluids and toradol for pain.  Gait continues to be unsteady, but move improves with pain medication.  Neurology team assesses her and ultimately decides that it is not neuro related.  No clear diagnosis given.  We are discharged home.  On 5/31, Patient is still screaming in pain, less pain in arms but significant pain in legs and now stomach.  Cannot walk without holding onto us or a wall/railing.  Sleeps most of the day.  Have to carry her to bathroom.  6/1 - 6/2:  No longer walking on own, has to hold our hands and is terrified to walk.  Says it really hurts.  Keeps saying she doesn't feel good. Mentions her legs are itchy.  Continue to give ibuprofen for pain.  Sleeping most of the day.  6/3:  Took Patient for follow-up with pediatrician.  Was referred to Infectious Disease Specialist, Neurology, PT/OT and Behavioral Therapy.  BAck log at Medical Center.  Very difficult to secure appointments.  6/4:  Still hesitant to walk.  Screams, cries, yells when we try to get her up to ambulate.  Still complaining of pain in belly and legs.  Still says legs feel itchy .  6/5: Today is better.  Patient woke up in better spirits.  No pain.  Have not given Ibuprofen.  Takes initiative to try walking by herself.  Unsteady, wobbly gait, but can do it on own without holding our hand.    6/6:  Walking on own, still unsteady gait, but no pain.  By end of day, she is is very tired from practicing walking.  Appetite was slightly decreased throughout.  Lost about 5lbs, but mainly due to not wanting to feed self.  We have been feeding her while laying on the couch.   She has missed 7 days of school at this point.  Cannot send her back until gait improves.    My husband and I have also had to pivot with work to provide care for her.   Appointment with Infectious disease specialist on 6/8 and Neurology on 6/10.  Hoping to get some clarity.
LAB_DATA: CT scan 5/31: results were normal Blood Work 5/31: results were normal

SYMPTOM_TEXT: COVID vaccine dose booster (third vaccine) Mom present no questions at present. Epi pen on hand. Multiple allergies. No reported concerns with previous 2 doses. Pfizer 12 yo and older. 30 min. Watch  15 minute of watch;mom came out of room, patient anxious c/o SOB asking for her inhaler. She had spacer with her but no albuterol. Mom had epi pen with her.  This writer (registered nurse) used auto inject through her pants to right thigh. 12:03pm 0.3mg Epi  Initial Pulse ox 100% Ap120  100 % non breathing No audible wheezing +diaphoresis, hunched over,  AP initially 120s at 100% Benadryl1 25 mg PO at 12:21pm Patient calming down, ice to nape of neck 130/76 AP 87  Refocused breathing with 100% non rebreather that was placed early on.   Transporting no more concerns. Lungs with excellent air movement in all fields  To ED for rebound monitoring.  Doctors assisted in evaluation and response. Registered nurse assisted in transport, oral medication Pulse oc, registered nurse. Supervisor registered nurse, certified, on hand. To ED with registered nurse and medical doctor, with O2.

All_symptoms: Erythema Injection site erythema Injection site rash Rash
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Situation: Pt is present for appointment for 1st dose of Pediatric Pfizer Covid vaccination. Background: Dose is administered by MA at 1540 with discharge time of 1555. Pt and mom comes to RN with c/o redness and rashes on antecubital areas bilaterally at 1600.  Assessment: Patient is taken to observation area with mom and is given icepacks to apply bilaterally. Initial vital signs at 1605 are 104 HR, 98/67 BP, 20 RR 99% o2 @ RA. Patient denies SOB, difficulty breathing, or chest pain on assessment and is calm watching tablet with mother at side. Redness remains on antecubital areas bilaterally, is also seen faintly on neck and R orbital area. V/S at 1615 110 HR, 96/65 BP, 20 RR 99% o2 @ RA. Redness remains localized. Pt denies SOB, difficulty breathing and chest pain, remains calm watching tablet with mother. V/S @1637 are 101 HR, 93/63 BP, 20 RR, 100% o2 @ RA. Pt denies SOB, difficulty breathing and chest pain, remains calm watching tablet with mother. Redness remains localized. Mom denies Epinephrine administration when offered, states that Zyrtec might work better. V/S @ 16:55 96 HR, 94/57 BP, 20 RR, 100% o2 @ RA. Pt denies SOB, difficulty breathing and chest pain, remains calm watching tablet with mother. Localized redness and rashes never spread during observation, but do not dissipate and at this time I decide to take patient to urgent care and confirm plan of action with manager MA. Mother complies and approves urgent care visit.    Recommendation: I escort pt and mom to pediatric urgent care. Patient is alert, oriented, and is active running around the hallways. Mom and patient remain calm. I check in at pediatric urgent care desk and report to both desk representatives and give hand off report to RN. Patient and mom present at waiting room and wait to be called in.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Last vaccination was in December of 2021. June 6th he developed a continuous cough and sore throat for about two days then developed runny and stuffy nose. I attributed it to his seasonal allergies. Days two and three developed low grade fever, never higher than 101 but never lower than 99.1. I took him to ER at Hospital on June 9th and was given two albuterol for his breathing and gave him an xray and oxygen. Also gave him two doses of amoxicillin once they found out it was bilateral pneumonia and also gave him a steroid- about 4 mL dexamethasone. They released him the same day and he vomited the entire night. Fever broke the next day, June 10th. Since then he has continued albuterol treatments twice a day and amoxicillin twice a day. Still coughing but less, and no fever.
LAB_DATA: chest x-ray, full panel, covid test, benign flu (something)

All_symptoms: Atrial septal defect Atrial septal defect repair Atrioventricular block first degree Autonomic nervous system imbalance Cardiac operation
SYMPTOM_TEXT: The morning after her second dose of the Pfizer covid vaccine, Patient woke up very dizzy and, on standing, passed out. She fell over, almost losing consciousness, three more times that morning.  From that point on, Patient was ""dizzy"" or lightheaded daily. She had been an avid athlete, playing soccer at least three times per week and teaching swim lessons 4 times a week. She began to have to sit out at soccer practice and to have to leave the field during soccer games. Her dizziness was worse with exertion. She was treated zealously for assumed dehydration, but it did not help. She continued to be more and more dizzy until in January she had to quit her job teaching swim lessons because she would get dizzy in the pool where she was watching young kids. She is home schooled and only attends school twice a week, but she did miss school at least 6 times from dizziness (and more due to heart surgery but I am not counting that). Patient stopped playing soccer completely  in November due to her symptoms.  In the quest to try to find out what was wrong, her pediatrician, (since retired), found a first degree AV block on her EKG. She was referred to cardiology where she was diagnosed with a 17mm atrial septal defect. Her cardiologist, thought this could be causing the dizziness. The ASD was repaired on 3/2/22 with open heart surgery. Patient felt less dizzy for a day or two while in the hospital, but unfortunately after a week it was clear that the symptoms had not gone away. After further testing (blood pressure tests, holter monitor) she was diagnosed by Dr. with POTS/Disautonomia. Dr. said this could have been caused by her COVID vaccine, especially condsidering the timing of onset and never having symptoms before the vaccine. Dr said disautonomia was a possible side effect of the vaccines. At this time, a year after the vaccine, Patient is still suffering with debilitating dizziness and light-headedness not associated with dehydration. She is still unable to play soccer or to work, or can't tolerate heat and humidity well. This has been very difficult for her.  With her concurrent heart condition, we have been to Emergency Room and many doctors trying to tease out what is going on with her.
LAB_DATA: Too many to list!
HISTORY: Atrial Septal Defect (not diagnosed until 11/2021), surgically repaired 3/2022

All_symptoms: Confusional state Conversion disorder Crying Delusion Depersonalisation/derealisation disorder
SYMPTOM_TEXT: During the observation period after receiving the Covid Vaccine, Patient suddenly said to me (her father) that she didn?t feel well and she instantly passed out and collapsed.  She woke up after a few seconds and seized a bit as she was coming to.  Medical professionals onsite at the vaccination clinic monitored her vitals but had no definitive diagnosis after her incident.   She was a little loopy and tired and confused for a long while afterwards.   That evening she wasn?t herself still and she suddenly escalated into full delusions and hallucinations and wild mood swings from laughter to hysterical crying.  We took her to the local ER, and she was given a sedative to calm her and some fluids.  They performed extensive tests with no conclusions.  This reaction and behavior had never occurred in her life up to this point.  Now since then, she has had probably 10 similar episodes since then with about half requiring an ER visit.
LAB_DATA: Various tests at various clinics and hospitals all without definitive diagnosis.

All_symptoms: Biopsy lymph gland Blood test Chest X-ray normal Computerised tomogram abnormal Induration
SYMPTOM_TEXT: So on about the 17th of January I noticed that he had a large swollen lymph node on his jawline on the right side by his ear. I asked him when it started and he said he wasn't sure, maybe a few days before. We held off a few days thinking it would go away. It didn't hurt to touch, it was just swollen and hard, it was about 2 in. We waited another week and it didn't go down and seemed to be growing in size and so we decided to go to pediatrician on the 25th. They didn't know anything about it, weren't sure, and they asked us to go and get an x-ray of it. We got a chest x-ray to make sure there weren't any other swollen lymph nodes on February 11th, showed no other lymph nodes other than the one on his jawline. They basically told us to hold off and wait and monitor it and it might go down. So we waited, and then on March 28th we went to an ENT. At this point it was still growing, it didn't hurt him but it was very visible. We went to the specialist and they told us that it was unusual that it had been 3 months of this and ordered a CT scan and that was done on 3/28 and at that time they couldn't decide if it was actually his parotid gland or a lymph node. They were concerned it could be cancerous so they wanted to have a biopsy done. We went in on 5/5/22 to an urgent care and when they read the sample of the biopsy they saw that it was lymphatic material and were quite certain it was a lymph node. Based off of that we had a spinal visit with Dr. again in May, and they said it was a good chance it was a reaction to the booster shot and reactive ""benign reactive lymph node"" and to keep monitoring it and if it doesn't go down to go back in to have it removed. As of now it has gone down quite a bit, but is still there under the skin. Pediatrician recommended a different brand or dosage for next vaccination.
LAB_DATA: Chest x-ray, blood work, CT Scan, biopsy.

All_symptoms: Arthralgia Asthenia Back pain CSF protein increased Chest pain
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Nine hours after shot he had a slight headache and arm pain. He also had neck pain. We gave him PEPCID and CELEBREX. He had a prescription from flare up sin the past. At 3AM on 6/11 he awoke with severe headache, severe arm pain, coughing, nausea, weakness. He could not walk, he needed assistance. He had a fever of 104 degree, his neck pain increased. We got him back to bed and he slept in when he woke up around 9:30 AM his headache was less severe and his fever was down, his leg weakness and achiness continued. He was not able to walk. This is similar to his post viral episode. He had for about the rest of June a lot of fatigue, he didn't have leg strength and had to sleep in often. The doctors were aware and told us to keep them posted. Then end of Jul/early August he started having headaches and joint pains (elbows, knees, ankles,) He also had pressure headaches. He also had Achilles pain, tailbone, and hip pain. He started school in August, and he had to call out sick because his symptoms were getting worse. He took a Covid test which was negative. The headache continued. He was still taking CELEBREX and PEPCID. He was having issue in PE. Nobody had figured out why he has had the constant headache since July. He has had MRI, Spinal Taps. He also had an episode of gastritis. He had never been on biologics for the joint pains, and he was put on the methotrexate and prednisone, and he had to go to the ER for increased heart rate from the prednisone. He was very very fatigued with everything. They also did a GI scope in December. The methotrexate caused more problems for him and he developed really severe headache and joint and sternal pain. He got very pale, they raised folic acid to counteract the effects of the methotrexate. He had full body weakness and his arms feet like they were stinging at the ends of the bone. He also had some cognitive issues and missed school for 3 weeks. He also developed ulcers probably from switching from CELEBREX to naproxen at the end of Sept. the also switched him to omeprazole. He developed scoliosis as well. His side effects were like chemo levels In January he went to school and got sick he had two COVID-9 test that came back negative and he got sick with coughing, and it threw him into progressive leg weakness and pain. He has to do extensive rehab to learn to walk again. He developed vertigo at times and separately migraines. He did antibiotics. His spinal tap showed high protein 61 and no infection. They are not sure why this is happening. He missed months of school because of the severity of the headaches especially in the mornings. He got sent home with a walker and wheelchair. His headache when away for a few hours after the spinal tap and that was the only time. He had a spinal tap in March and pressure was lower and protein was 55. The gabapentin he did for about a month and made the headaches worse. He started developing loss of conscious and Parkinson like symptoms. He has missed a lot of school and he has to do summer school and possibly repeat a grade level. His cognitive issues have been so severe to the point he had to re learn his address. He is now on EMBREL, it's helping his joints to get better, he has less headaches and is over all making some progress. He has had a genetics workup to see if there is anything.
LAB_DATA: MRI, Spinal Tap, 3 COVID-19 test, negative.
HISTORY: Post-viral Issue; Cardiac Arrhythmia; Elevations in inflammatory labs

We administered Diphenhydramine but we discovered that we do not have any Famotidine or Cimetidine. We ended up calling the ED, administering Epinephrine per their guidance and awaited EMS transport. Was transported to ED.   From ED: Got Pfizer COVID vaccine at today. About 15 minutes afterward developed swelling of right eye and whole body itchiness. Was given benadryl about 30-45 min after vaccine dose for these symptoms. She was then observed. Epi given at about 1753 and she was subsequently brought to ED by EMS for further management. No breathing issues. No swelling of lips, tongue, mouth. No rash noted on body. No vomiting. She is otherwise healthy. Takes no medications. No food allergies or other known allergies. No recent fevers, rhinorrhea, cough, abdominal pain, dysuria, diarrhea. Currently feeling well. Did get lidocaine under arm prior to vaccine injection. Family wondering if she could have touched the lidocaine and then touched her thigh. Had eye redness and itchiness with swelling initially.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient developed symptoms of MISC on 6/13/22; fevers began on 6/13/22 with a Tmax of 38.7 degrees Celsius.  Over the course of illness, symptoms and complications included fevers, sinus tachycardia, cough, vomiting, and mucocutaneous lesions/conjunctivitis. Abnormal labs included elevated fibrinogen, elevated CRP, elevated ferritin, elevated troponin, elevated BNP, elevated NT-ProBNP, elevated D-dimer, elevated AST, and elevated ALT. ECHO studies showed coronary artery dilatation, left ventricular dysfunction, mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, dilated left atrium, and pulmonary valve regurgitation. All_symptoms: Joint range of motion decreased Laboratory test Screaming X-ray normal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: My son (2 years, 8 months) received the Pfizer COVID 19 injection in his left arm on Friday morning at 9am. His behavior was normal after the injection, he did not complain of any pain and was playing and running as normal. He went to bed at 730 without any issues and still no side effects from the injection. On Saturday 6/25/2022 at around 6:45 he woke up screaming because he could not move his head. If he moved, he would scream in agony. His head maintained a position to the right without inducing pain. Motrin and Tylenol were given with no impact. Urgent Care was called and instructed to give Benedryl 5mg and wait 1 hour to see if symptoms improved. At 45 minutes after the benedryl was given, he was still screaming at any movement. He remained laying with his head to the right without any issue but otherwise could not move his neck. Other extremities were fine, no rashes. He was not warm to the touch but temperature was not taken. Since he was still in pain and unable to move, he was taken to the Emergency Room in. They completed additional tests, including temperature to which no fever was recorded. X-rays which showed no injury. However no improvement was being made. He was given additional Ibuprofen. Heating pads were put on his upper neck. Slow movements were made by family and nurses and after 5 hours he was able to sit upright leaning back on the bed. He eventually was able to then stand and walk around. Instructions were to continue Motrin at regular dosing times 24/7 at home. The following day, Sunday 6/26/2022, there are no signs of any pain. He is not complaining of any pain and is active and back to normal self.
LAB_DATA: X-ray was completed on 6/25/22 at the Emergency Room - no injury was shown.

All_symptoms: Activated partial thromboplastin time shortened Angiogram normal Antiphospholipid antibodies negative Antithrombin III Asthenia
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Patient received second dose of COVID-19 vaccine (Pfizer) on 11/30/21. He did not have any notable local or systemic reactions and was in his usual state of health, even participating in his tae kwon do classess until 12/4/21, when he developed new back pain. On 12/5, pain worsened to the point that he had difficulty walking as well as worsening urinary retention, prompting admission to the hospital for further workup. He underwent extensive workup from 12/5-12/12 (summarized in Item 19), all of which was inconclusive. However, his clinical exam improved while inpatient, so he was subsequently discharged with supportive care and outpatient PT.  Repeat MRI 3/7/22 demonstrated a substle T2 hyperintense signal abnormality at the left lateral cord from C6-T1 as well as a tiny C5-C6 annular tear, most suggestive of a spinal cord infarct. Underwent cryptogenic stroke evaluation with repeat head/spine and vessel imaging as well as serum studies, that were not suggestive of other underlying cause of spinal stroke. Leading suspicion is that his presentation was due to a fibrocartilagenous embolism.  He clinically continued to improve over the next several months to the point where he no longer had urinary retention and no weakness was detectable on his neurologic exam as of 03/2022. He does continue to have hyperreflexia.
LAB_DATA: MRI Spine Full (12/5/21): Normal MRI of the C-, T- and L-spine LP results (12/6/21): WBC <1 (Neut 0, Lymph 100, Mono 0) , RBC <1, Protein 20, Glucose 60; Meningo/Encephalitis PCR: negative; CSF Culture negative, OCB negative CRP (12/6/21) <0.1 Vit B12 624, Folate 24.4 (upper limit of normal 24.2), Copper 89, ACE 93, Homocysteine 4.3 MRI Spine Full and MRI Brain w/ and w/o (12/10/22): No intracranial or intraspinal abnormality MRI Spine Full w/o (3/7/22): 1. Subtle T2 hyperintense signal abnormality at left lateral cord from C6 to T1, evolved from 12/10/21, now more prominent and more extensive in cranio-caudal dimension, with slight volume loss. Findings non-specific, may be inflammatory, infectious, demyelinating, ischemic. 2. Tiny C5-C6 disc herniation with tiny annular tear MRI Brain w/ and w/o (3/9/22): no intracranial abnormality MRI/MRA Brain and Neck (4/22/22):no intracranial abnormality and no flow-limiting stenosis, occlusion or aneurysm in the intracranial or neck ateries. MRI Spine Full w/ and w/o (5/17/22): 1.  Unchanged nonspecific small ill-defined signal abnormality in the left aspect of the spinal cord at the C6-C7 level. No associated enhancement. 2.  No new abnormality. All_symptoms: Acne Joint swelling Skin discolouration Skin fissures
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On May 8, 2022, I noticed a recurrent dark patch on his wrist. It started to look swollen, raised, and skin cracking. I advised my son to go and wash his hands and put NEOSPORIN on the patch. After the NEOSPORIN we tried the steroid ointment that we had and that was not working; so we made a doctors appointment. The first doctor's appointment was on that very same week of May 9th, 2022. They prescribe antibiotic ointment mupirocin. A few days later, I called my son's doctor and they prescribed, KEFLEX which is a oral antibiotic. Once my son started to take the oral antibiotic, I noticed that he started to have another reaction and little small pimples appeared on the same arm and wrist with the dark patch. We went to the emergency room on May 15, 2022 and they prescribe my son prednisone and doxycycline. Once my son finished his prescribe meds his skin started to clear up but once he went and got his second dose the skin reaction happened again.
LAB_DATA: Antibiotic ointment mupirocin, prednisone, doxycycline, KEFLEX

All_symptoms: Chills Influenza virus test negative Pain in extremity Pyrexia Rash
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On Sunday, June 26, woke up from nap (3:30 pm, Day 1 Time 0) with a 103.8F fever. We treated her with Motrin (5 mL) and the fever came down under 100F. In the evening (Day 1 Time 3h40m), the fever spiked again to 103F and receded following a dose of Children's Tylenol (5 mL). On Monday, June 27 (Day 1 time 16h30m) again woke up with a fever over 103F and a small rash near her right knee that she was itching. Over the next hour, the hive-like rash spread over her legs and arms, and by noon had spread to her face. At a pediatric urgent care facility, was tested for COVID-19 and flu and given Zyrtec (2.5 mL) and Motrin (6 mL) (given at 1pm, Day 1 time 22h30m). The fever came down but the rash continued to spread, changing from hives into splotches that covered 80% of her body from head to toe, including face, neck, and chest. We returned to urgent care that night (10:30 pm, Day 2 time 7h) to be examined for possible serum sickness. 5.5 mL Benadryl and 6 mL Motrin were administered (11:30 pm, Day 2 time 8h). Slept until 9 am (Day 2 time 17h30m). On Tuesday, June 28, again woke up with a 103F temperature, and the splotchy rash had gone back to just being hives. We administered Motrin (6 mL) and Zyrtec (2.5 mL). Was also complaining that her fingers hurt, and she was favoring her left leg when walking. By noon (Day 2 time 20h30m) the fever had only gone down to 102.5F, though the itching had abated. We were seen by pediatric practice, then administered Tylenol (5 mL) before nap (3:30 pm, Day 3 time 0), which brought the temperature down to 101F by 6 pm (Day 3 time 2h30m). At 11 pm (Day 3 time 7h30m) woke up shivering uncontrollably with a 103F fever; we administered Motrin (6 mL) and the shivering subsided. Today, Wednesday June 29,  woke up at 8:15 am with a slightly lower fever (102.5F) and the hives have almost completely subsided.
