The routine is he will be sick for 5 days, he will be okay for a couple of weeks and he will be sick for 5 days. When he gets so dehydrated, we take him to the ER for IVs. He has been to numerous doctors/specialists for a diagnoses but they can't find anything wrong. We feed him purified food which he has difficulty swallowing. Water, PEDIALYTE, juice is all difficult for him to swallow. He was tested for allergies and he is very allergic to certain medicine and unable to process.

Was able to have patient walk back into room and started vitals.  Patient looked pale but was talking, breathing comfortably and able to walk on own to room.  HR 76 and other first set  Of vitals were stable.  Was told patient had recent bagel for lunch.  Due to concern this could have been anxiety driven decided to monitor.  Juice and crackers offered.  Dads report no reaction to any previous vaccines.  No past medical history.  Denies any known allergies or medication she takes on regular basis.   ~10:25 patient said left arm was hurting and report some tightening in throat.  HR was now variable.  Within minute patient reported trouble breathing (reporting throat tightness without being asked) and dizziness.  Cyanosis was noted around mouth and HR dipped to 57 beats/min. At 10:27 epi was given.  HR increase.  Ambulance was called.  Please see repeat vital signs.  Beside sore left leg where epi pen was given patient seemed to improve and vitals were more stable   ~10:40 Ambulance arrived.  Sign out was given.  Patient was transferred to ER for further observation and work up.

All_symptoms: Ageusia Amnesia Blood test normal COVID-19 Confusional state
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Symptoms 5/21/2022 began with allergy type symptoms, runny nose; coughing; congestion; sneezing, The next day her symptoms were worse and she was running a fever. The highest was 101F. They continue to get worse and on 5/22/2022 we tested at home and it was positive. 5/23/22 I contacted her rheumatologist and PCP. PCP wanted her tested again, and asked us to come in for the test. It was positive. She also started having confusion; loss of taste; nauseous. Because of her symptoms and that she is immunosuppressed he wanted to her get remdesivir infusion, which needed to be done at the hospital. Her PCP had her directly admitted. They did blood work on her the basic lab and to check her kidneys before the infusion. She was in from 5/23/2022- 5/25/2022. While in hospital, her nauseous and fever subsided. They cold like symptoms gradually improved. Her confusion, memory loss lasted for about 2 weeks.
LAB_DATA: 22MAY2022 at home COVID-19 positive; 23MAY2022 COVID-19, positive; 23MAY202 blood work, as far as I know it was normal.

She went to school the next day however she did come home early. At day 3 post vaccine she started to have diarrhea as well. On Friday she started to feel better however continued to have diarrhea. On Saturday she was feeling back to normal. Went to a swimming class and in the late afternoon she began to vomit again and have diarrhea as well. We took her to ER and they did all the tests including COVID-19 tests and all were negative. They believe that it was due to a viral infection. The doctors did not believe it was due to the vaccine. She had IV fluids and was sent home. She has started feeling much better as of Saturday.
LAB_DATA: COVID-19 test: negative.

All_symptoms: Aortic dilatation Blood glucose normal Chest X-ray abnormal Cough Diarrhoea
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Runny nose and cough beginning 7/9/22. Elevated temperature ~99.6 but never higher for a couple days. Negative PCR test for COVID on 7/10/22. On 7/12/22 she began having difficulty breathing in the morning and very rapid heartbeat along with loose stool. Taken to Pediatrics urgent care in at noon on 7/12/22 where she then vomited. Pediatrics detected pulse ox ~94 and administered zofran for the vomiting and albuterol nebulizer along with an oral steroid. Urgent care recommended transfer to the ER, and she was taken to the hospital in the late afternoon on 7/12/22. They gave additional albuterol nebulizers and continuous monitoring. At the hospital she test negative for COVID, RSV, and Flu A/B. She was admitted overnight with respiratory distress and put on low flow oxygen overnight. She responded well to the O2 oxygen and was discharged from the hospital late morning 7/13/22 with home treatment steroid and albuterol inhaler.   At follow up with pediatrician on 7/14/22 vitals were good but detected wheezing, possible asthma. Prescribed 4 day course of prednisone and follow up visit. The patient is slowly getting better but with wheezy cough. The cough is now productive and discharging mucous.
LAB_DATA: Urgent care tested blood sugar, normal. Negative flu, RSV, COVID at hospital. X-ray at hospital: ""FINDINGS: The lungs show mild diffuse groundglass opacities bilaterally suggestive of pneumonitis without segmental consolidation or effusion. Cardiac size is normal with no vascular congestion. Aorta is insignificantly ectatic."" SpO2 evening of 7/12/22 at hospital was ~94-95 awake and dipped to ~87 when asleep, prior to administration of oxygen.

All_symptoms: Acute sinusitis COVID-19 Computerised tomogram head abnormal Dystonia Gaze palsy
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Discharge Provider: MD  Primary Care Physician at Discharge: MD Admission Date: 7/16/2022  Discharge Date: 07/19/2022  Headache [R51.9] Acute intractable headache, unspecified headache type [R51.9]   HOSPITAL COURSE:   Patient is a 12 y.o. male with PMHX significant for shunted hydrocephalus (Strata 1.0; last revised 2017), left temporal arachnoid cyst,  vision impairment (legally blind), and migraine headache presenting with headache and vomiting in setting of COVID infection..    Mother reports she initially started to have cold-like symptoms starting Monday (7/11/2022). Patient then started to have symptoms of headache, rhinorrhea, congestion and vomiting starting roughly two days prior to presentation. Family tested positive for COVID at home. Initially seen at ED on 7/14 with concern for headache believed likely secondary to COVID infection. Head CT without increase in ventricular size (slightly decreased); although noting acute sinusitis. No concerns for shunt malfunction. Provided IV fluids and discharged with Reglan for nausea/vomiting x2. Continued to have headaches at home with continued nausea/vomiting. Again seen at ED on 7/16 and provided migraine cocktail with Toradol, Reglan, Compazine, Benadryl and a x1 NS bolus. Continued to have headaches and nausea/vomiting despite interventions and was admitted under Neurosurgery service. Headache located in frontal area, constant, and associated with photophobia. Follows with neurology for migraines.   Inpatient was evaluated by Peds Neurology who recommended migraine regimen with Toradol, magnesium, benadryl and compazine. He developed dystonic reaction to compazine with increased tone in neck, arms, wrists, and hands, and twitching of lips. He also experienced episodes of dysconjugate gaze. PO benadryl did not help but rapidly improved after iv benadryl. Discontinued Compazine and Reglan and monitored mental status. Headache resolved, pediatric hospitalist team took over as primary team as neurosurgery had no concerns for shunt malfunction. Dystonic episodes slowly improved, did not hinder oral intake, and patient was felt to be stable for discharge. Will send home with migraine regimen per neurology in case headaches return, and benadryl for dystonia.
HISTORY: Arachnoid cyst  ETD (eustachian tube dysfunction)  Hydrocephalus   Legally blind  History of neurological testing - DO NOT EDIT  ADHD (attention deficit hyperactivity disorder), combined type  Disruptive behavior disorder  Anxiety and fearfulness of childhood and adolescence  Hydrocephalus with operating shunt   COVID-19

All_symptoms: Electrocardiogram normal Fatigue Heart rate increased Pain in extremity
SYMPTOM_TEXT: On July 20, the day after the vaccination, my son experienced general tiredness and pain in his arm.  He spent most of the day sitting around and reading/watching tv.  Around 5:00 PM, he mentioned that he felt like his heart was beating fast even though he was sitting on the couch.  He took some deep breaths and seemed better.  He didn't mention his heart again until the morning of July 23.  He was swimming and I noticed his hand over his heart after he had swum a lap.  I asked him if he was okay and he said he felt like his heard was beating too fast.  Since he had just been swimming, I though it was from the intense exercise.  He rested and seemed better.  Then after going to bed on July 23, he got up to go to the bathroom and told me that he felt like his heart was beating fast when he was trying to go to sleep.  He further said that since the COVID-19 vaccine, his heart hasn't felt right.  After further questioning, he said he had been having similar episodes 2-3 times a day since the vaccine.  I called Health nurse line and was advised to take my son to the emergency room.  We went to Health's Hospital where they checked his vital signs and administered and EKG.  The EKG was normal so my son was sent home with instructions to rest and take fluids.  Assuming no prolonged heart palpitations, we are to follow-up with the pediatric cardiologist on July 25 if the periodic heart palpitations continue.  If he has prolonged heart palpitations, we are to return to the emergency room.
LAB_DATA: July 24 3:00 AM - EKG - Normal.

All_symptoms: Acute respiratory failure Blood electrolytes COVID-19 COVID-19 pneumonia Chest X-ray normal
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Admission Date: 7/16/2022  Discharge Date: 7/22/2022  Acute respiratory failure with hypoxia [J96.01] Fever, unspecified fever cause [R50.9]   HOSPITAL COURSE: Patient is a 11 y.o. male with PMHx Lennox-Gastaut, spastic CP, OSA, nephrocalcinosis, ketogenic diet, and G-tube dependence who was admitted on 7/16/2022 for acute hypoxic respiratory failure in the setting of COVID-19.    On arrival to the emergency department vital signs are obtained which reveal the patient be febrile to 38.7° C for which Tylenol was given.  He was ill-appearing on initial evaluation but in no acute distress. Patient was placed on 2 L nasal cannula and had improvement in his increased work of breathing. CMP demonstrated stable electrolytes.  Procalcitonin was not elevated.  Complete blood count was not indicative of infection other than a slight left shift.  Urinalysis was not indicative of infection.  Respiratory PCR panel was negative for RSV, influenza and covid.  Chest x-ray did not demonstrate any focal findings.  Patient was admitted to the hospitalist service for acute hypoxic respiratory failure.   On admission, patient continued to be mildly tachypneic and was kept on 0.5 L of nasal cannula.  Chest physiotherapy was scheduled for 3 times a day with hypertonic saline to be used as needed for increased secretions. Patient did become tachypneic and tachycardic when febrile but this was quickly resolved with defervesce.  Patient was restarted on his home feeds and IV fluids were discontinued.  Patient was continued on home medications.     On 7/22, the patient became persistently hypoxic, tachycardic, tachypeic, and had an increased work of breathing. He was placed on HFNC 20L/min with 40% FiO2. Xopenex therapy was started q3h. Chest physiotherapy was increased to q3h and his hypertonic saline treatments were increased in frequency to q8h. Remdesivir was started as well as 4 mg of decadron daily. Patient was made NPO when high flow. Patient did meet sepsis criteria today with tachypnea, tachycardia, fever, and a known source of infection with COVID pneumonia.   Patient's LFTs were followed while he was receiving remdesivir because he has a history of liver failure. His LFTs never indicated acute liver failure while taking remdesivir. Patient only required one day of HFNC. The next day he was weaned down to 0.5L NC. Patient was started on Pulmicort 0.5 mg BID which he will continue as an outpatient. Each day, patient's CPT, hypertonic saline therapy, and xopenex therapy were decreased in frequency because patient showed improvement in his clinical status since 7/22. Patient was started back on continuous feeds after being NPO and was slowly transitioned to his regular home feeding regimen. Patient tolerated three days of being on room air during the day. Patient does require 0.5L of oxygen while he is sleeping per his baseline. Patient received the full five day course of remdesivir before being discharged. He also received five days of decadron while hospitalized.    Patient was discharged with an asthma action plan that was created by the pulmonology team. He will continue xopenex 1.25 mg q4 during the day, HTS 3% TID, QID CPT during the day, cough assist twice a day, two more days of decadron. Patient should continue these therapies while he has increased secretions. Patient's mother can titrate his robinul at home as needed. Patient should continue his previous home medications as well. Patient's mother understands and agrees with the plan. Patient was discharged in a stable condition.
HISTORY: Patient on ketogenic diet  Dietary counseling  Spastic quadriplegic cerebral palsy  Infantile spasms  Epileptic spasms, not intractable, without status epilepticus  Dysphagia, oropharyngeal phase  History of neurological testing - DO NOT EDIT  Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, intractable, without status epilepticus  Sleep apnea  Gastrostomy status  Intractable epilepsy  Nephrocalcinosis  Ineffective airway clearance  Altered mental status  Chronic brain syndrome  Global developmental delay  Seizure  Lennox-Gastaut syndrome  Abdominal mass, left upper quadrant  Dependence on enabling machine  History of kidney stones

All_symptoms: Blood test abnormal Chest X-ray Chest pain Echocardiogram Hypotension
SYMPTOM_TEXT: My son received his second Pfizer vaccination for COVID-19 on 7/9/2022. On about 7/12/2022, he began complaining of chest pains. I had previously had him examined by a cardiologist, who said that his heart was in ""perfect"" condition, so I didn't think there was anything seriously wrong. I thought that maybe he was just having a panic attack and that he would be okay. He continued complaining of chest pains on 7/13/2022 and 7/14/2022, however. On the morning of 7/15/2022, he collapsed in the shower. I walked into the bathroom and found him unconscious and leaning over the edge of the tub. I got him up, got him out of the shower, set him on the toilet, called 911, and tried to cover him up as much as I could. The ambulance came and checked his pulse and blood pressure. They found that his blood pressure was very low, so they decided to transport him to the ER. When he got to the ER, he underwent various tests, including a chest X-ray, a chest ultrasound, and bloodwork. The doctor told me that my son was diagnosed with myocarditis. He also asked me if my son had received a COVID-19 vaccine. When I answered in the affirmative, the doctor then told me that 3 other young men had been diagnosed with myocarditis that week after receiving the vaccines. My son was not admitted to the hospital, but the ER doctor did call my son's cardiologist to inform him that my son needed a follow-up visit. My son was prescribed a medication to treat the myocarditis. It may have been methylprednisolone, but I'm not sure. The doctor advised us that the myocarditis would eventually go away on its own. My husband and my son went to his cardiologist for the follow-up on or about 7/18/2022. My son underwent an echocardiogram. I don't recall the exact findings of the echocardiogram, but they must not have been serious, since the cardiologist told us that it would be safe for my son to take a plane trip out of state. Since my son received his diagnosis and was treated, he has not complained anymore about chest pains.
LAB_DATA: On or about 7/15/2022 chest X-ray, chest ultrasound, blood work myocarditis detected.
HISTORY: Autism; Microcephaly; Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder; Bipolar Disorder; Asthma; Epilepsy; Muscular Dystrophy; Eosinophilic Esophagitis; Schizoaffective Disorder; Oppositional Defiant Disorder.

All_symptoms: Body temperature increased COVID-19 Chest X-ray normal Heart disease congenital Oxygen saturation decreased
SYMPTOM_TEXT: Primary Care Physician at Discharge: MD  Admission Date: 7/23/2022 Discharge Date: 7/23/2022  PRESENTING PROBLEM: COVID [U07.1]   HOSPITAL COURSE: Miracle is a 9 year old female with history significant for HLHS s/p Norwood with BT shunt on 7/10/2013, s/p bidirectional Glenn on 12/18/2013, most recently s/p extracardiac fenestrated Fontan on 6/6/2018; she went for cardiac catheterization on 10/22/2020 and underwent device closure of fenestration. She also has history significant for seizures and multiple thromboses secondary to being homozygous for MTFHR.  Miracle presented to ED on 7/22 with concerns for desaturations while sleeping into the upper 80s, patient's family positive for COVID and Miracle also had positive COVID test in the ED. Upon arrival to the ED she remained in RA with appropriate saturations >90%, she was hemodynamically stable, CXR did not demonstrate consolidation, effusions or pneumo. Following discussion with cardiology team she was admitted for observation following COVID diagnosis in the setting of complex congenital heart disease. Overnight she remained in RA with no increased WOB or shortness of breath, no chest pain, she rested comfortably, low grade temperature was responsive to Tylenol, she continued to take in adequate fluids with no changes to appetite. Discussed patient with ID regarding possibility of antiviral medications, however, due to her reassuring clinical status she was not deemed candidate for this treatment.  She was discharged to home the following morning and will continue supportive care at home. Parents instructed to contact cardiology with any changes in respiratory status or if clinical status changes.   Discharge instructions reviewed with dad at bedside who verbalized understanding.
HISTORY: Status post Fontan procedure  Thrombosis of internal jugular vein, right (HCC)  Hypoplastic left heart  Seizures (HCC)  Methylene THF reductase deficiency and homocystinuria (HCC)  History of neurological testing - DO NOT EDIT  S/P Norwood operation  S/P bidirectional Glenn shunt  History of Hemorrhage of choroid plexus  Abnormal MRI of head  Cerebral palsy, monoplegic, spastic, LLE  Acute renal failure (HCC)  Metabolic acidosis  Fluid overload  History of venous thrombosis  Abnormal gait  Congenital coxa valga  Contracture of Achilles tendon  Hydronephrosis  Hemiplegic cerebral palsy (HCC)  Convulsions, epileptic (HCC)  Hypotonic cerebral palsy (HCC)  HLHS (hypoplastic left heart syndrome)  Astigmatism  Migraine  Neurocognitive disorder  COVID

All_symptoms: Cataract Headache Laboratory test normal Ocular hyperaemia Photophobia
SYMPTOM_TEXT: After receiving the Covid-19 vaccine on 5/16/2021, Pt started to complain of light sensitivity and headache on 6/4/2021. The symptoms worsened and on 6/5/2021 she was presenting with  light sensitivity,  headache, and bloodshot eyes. On 6/6/2021 we brought her to urgent care and she was misdiagnosed with an eye infection and prescribed antibiotics.  On 6/10/2021 we saw Dr., who diagnosed Pt with Uveitis and referred us to Uveitis specialist, Dr. and Dr. Dr. prescribe Pred Forte, which Pt used for 2 weeks, however, no improvement was seen, so Dr. prescribed Durazol. We attempted to wean Pt off of Durazol 3 times between July 2021 and February 2022, but the Uveitis did not clear and Pt continued to experience flare ups. In February 2022, we switched to Methotrexate when Pt began to develop cataracts from the Durazol and the continued Uveitis flares. We were able to fully end Durazol drops in May 2022 with the Methotrexate treatment. Trace cells continued to persist into June 2022 with exclusive Methotrexate treatment, so we increased the dosage to the maximum. In July 2022 Pt was nearly clear of all trace cells on the maximum dosage of Methotrexate, which we inject weekly. Our plan is to continue this treatment for 2 years or more if needed.  Our hope is that we will eventually be able to wean Pt off of the Methotrexate. We are hoping that she does not experience any of the very sever potential complications from Methotrexate. We are monitoring  the cataracts effect on Pt's vision and will begin to meet with doctors to discuss future cataract surgery. At this time the final outcome of Pt's vaccine induced Uveitis event is unknown.
LAB_DATA: Full panel of rheumatology tests ordered by Dr. showed no underlying conditions related to Uveitis.

She does seem to know when her traponions are elevated, as both times she was not feeling well she asked to go to the hospital.  She has not been able to go back to her regular child life and activities as she has been told by the cardiologist not to stress out her heart.   I have all supporting documentations.

SYMPTOM_TEXT: New onset urticaria and angioedema; New onset urticaria and angioedema; This is a spontaneous report received from a contactable reporter(s) (Physician). The reporter is the parent.  A 12-year-old male patient received BNT162b2 (BNT162B2), on 24Jun2022 as dose 1, single (Batch/Lot number: unknown) at the age of 12 years intramuscular, in left arm for covid-19 immunisation. The patient's relevant medical history included: ""if covid prior vaccination: Yes"" (unspecified if ongoing), notes: if covid prior vaccination: Yes. The patient's concomitant medications were not reported. The following information was reported: ANGIOEDEMA (medically significant), URTICARIA (non-serious) all with onset 05Jul2022, outcome ""not recovered"" and all described as ""New onset urticaria and angioedema"". The events ""new onset urticaria and angioedema"" required physician office visit and emergency room visit. Therapeutic measures were taken as a result of angioedema, urticaria.  Clinical course: On 15Jul2022 patient took dose 2 covid-19 Pfizer vaccine through intramuscular, left arm location, lot number was not available or not provided to reporter at the time of report completion. Antihistamines, Montelukast, prednisone, Xolair are the treatment received for the adverse events. Prior to COVID Patient took vaccination. No Covid test was performed post vaccination. No known allergies. Other medications in two weeks: No. Facility type vaccine: Pharmacy or Drug Store.  The information on the batch/lot number for BNT162b2 has been requested and will be submitted if and when received.; Sender's Comments: Based on the current available information and the plausible drug-event temporal association, a possible contributory role of the suspect product BNT162B2 to the development of the reported event urticaria and angioedema Cannot be excluded.  The impact of this report on the benefit/risk profile of the Pfizer product is evaluated as part of Pfizer procedures for safety evaluation, including the review and analysis of aggregate data for adverse events. Any safety concern identified as part of this review, as well as any appropriate action in response, will be promptly notified to regulatory authorities, Ethics Committees, and Investigators, as appropriate.

He had several fevers between 8/1/2022-8/2/2022 and his heart rate slowly decreased but was still high and they continued to treat with ibuprofen and Tylenol interchangeably for fevers and monitor hear rate, he was given saline on 8/2/2022 after labs show n he had ketones in his urine from dehydration ( he was eating solids foods Or drinking water during this time. He was taken off of the saline on 8/3/2022 but still struggle to eat, fevers finally subsided and heart rate appeared to stabilize but his eating and drinking was still impacted and was kept an additional day for monitoring. He was released on 8/5/022 with recommendations to follow up with cardiologist and primary care doctor. Both were contacted. He saw pcp on 8/4/2022 and awaiting follow up appointment with cardiology to be scheduled by that office.
